policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Government/public buildings
policy_description: The City of Montgomery closes access for the public to municipal facilities. All City employees continue report to work as usual.

policy_subtarget: Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: The Capital City Fire/Rescue in partnership Bartlett Regional Hospital initiates a temporary “quarantine at home” protocol for certain 911 transports. When 911 is called to request an ambulance, one will be dispatched. In compliance with CDC guidelines, a trained medical professional will evaluate the situation and provide immediate care as necessary. If the professional suspects a case of COVID-19, they may recommend an at-home quarantine.
The Juneau Police Department institutes social distancing measures that include restricting public access to municiple police facilities.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Government/public buildings; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Effective 03/16/2020 all indoor City of Phoenix recreation activities were closed. All classes and programs, such as sports leagues, were suspended. Gatherings and events in city parks were closed. Several museums are closed.  After-school care and partnered programs were also canceled.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public transportation
policy_description: The City of Phoenix closes access of public to the following municipal buildings beginning on 03/23/2020 to appointment-only access. The affected municipal buildings are Phoenix City Hall, Calvin C. Goode Building and Phoenix Public Transit Building. Additionally, customer service windows at four local transit centers are closed until further notice.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: All senior centers in the City of Phoenix are closed. The City of Phoenix Retiree's Nationwide office is currently closed. The Office of Youth and Education has closed AARP literary program.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Outdoor recreation or space; Public transportation; Housing sector
policy_description: The City of Phoenix lists 27 facilities and services that have been limited or closed due to social distancing measures.

Pima County will provide a public website available via www.pima.gov through which any person may file a written complaint alleging noncompliance with this Resolution at any establishment that is open to the public. The Pima County Health Department will investigate complaints and take enforcement action where appropriate.
Implements a curfew between 10pm and 5am.
Implements measures to allow people to postpone their City Court appearances.

policy_subtarget: Pharmacy; Grocery store; Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Veterinary clinics; Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Notary
policy_description: Outlines facilities not affected by the private sector closures.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: Encourages some businesses defined in Governor Doug Ducey's executive order as essential to close such as personal hygiene. Details included in order.
The City will not issue special event permits with an expected attendance of 50 persons or more.
All public meetings and City-sponsored gatherings where the public is invited are suspended.
All meetings of Boards, Committees, and Commissions are suspended.
Ends section 2 of the March 17 Proclamation.
All out-of-city travel for employees on business is suspended.
Little Rock city buildings are closed to the public starting 03/18/2020.
On 03/25/2020, the Mayor of Little Rock announced that he would tighten the city-wide curfew that was previously instituted for 12 a.m. to 5 a.m. starting on 03/18/2020.
Starting on 03/30/2020, a daytime city-wide curfew for minors will take place from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. this will continue until 04/17/2020.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Childcare, camps and educational/recreational programs that provide care may resume operations. Only children of people who are allowed to work outside of their homes are eligible.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Childcare, camps and educational/recreational programs that provide care may resume operations. Only children of people who are allowed to work outside of their homes are eligible.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor recreational activities may resume with some limitations.

County residents may engage in certain Highly Regulated Vehicle-Based Gatherings.  A Highly Regulated Vehicle-Based Gathering is a gathering where during the entirety of the gathering every participant remains in a fully enclosed motorized vehicle parked at least six feet apart from other vehicles and where all occupants of each enclosed vehicle are members of a single household. The gathering must have a designated organizational host who is responsible for ensuring compliance with this Order and the Shelter in Place Order during the gathering. Hosts must develop and provide the local law enforcement, upon request, with a Highly Regulated Vehicle Based Gathering Plan Each gathering is limited to no more than 200 vehicles and can be no longer than 3 hours. If any of the windows on a vehicle is open, the occupants of the vehicle must wear a face covering in conformance with the Face Covering Order. Attending a Highly Regulated Vehicle-Based Gathering will be considered an Essential Activity as defined by the Shelter in Place Order.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor recreation areas, including golf courses, skate parks, and athletic fields, may be open with restrictions to ensure social distancing.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food); Manufacturers
policy_description: Businesses that may resume operations at this time include: • Retail stores for curbside or storefront pickup, and/or delivery only • Manufacturing businesses permitted to operate under the state Resilience Roadmap • Logistics and Warehousing permitted to operate under the state Resilience Roadmap
Some outdoor businesses, including plant nurseries, agricultural operations, landscaping services, and garden centers may resume operations.

Small outdoor gatherings are permitted for people belonging to the same Social Bubble. • A Social Bubble is defined as a group of 12 or fewer people from different households • A Social Bubble should be maintained for a minimum of 3 weeks • Participation is restricted to only one Social Bubble at a time • Members of a Social Bubble are strongly encouraged to comply with Social Distancing Requirements and wear face covering to the extent feasible.
Childcare providers to provide care to all children, not just children of essential workers.
Certain businesses providing services with limited person-to-person contact, including appliance repair, and pet grooming services, to resume operations.
Libraries to open for curbside pickup of books and other media
All dog parks may open with some restrictions.
Outdoor museums, outdoor historical sites, and publicly accessible gardens may reopen to the public with some restrictions.
Retail and shopping centers may reopen with restrictions.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Outdoor fitness classes may resume with restrictions.

policy_subtarget: Higher education; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: College sports teams may resume training or including non-contact practices, conditioning, or drills outdoors in groups of up to 12 team members and one coach.
Restaurants may reopen for outdoor dining. Outdoor dining guidelines must be followed.
Religious and cultural ceremonies may resume with restrictions.
Outdoor events where residents and community members are exercising their First Amendment Rights are permitted. Everyone should wear a face covering and stay at least 6 feet apart.
Zoos may open with restrictions.
Professional sports teams may resume practices, games, and tournaments in Alameda County subject to approval from the county Health Officer.
Alameda County wineries may resume wine tastings with restrictions.
Personal services providers, including Skin Care and Waxing services, non-medical massage providers, tattoo parlors, and non-medical electrolysis may resume services with restrictions.
Outdoor pools may reopen with restrictions.
Hair salons, barbershops, and nail salons may provide services indoors with some restrictions.

Outdoor recreational activities, such as miniature golf, batting cages, driving ranges, and kart racing facilities may reopen in accordance with the Family Entertainment Centers Guidance published by County Department of Public Health.
Museums, historical sites, zoos or publicly accessible gardens may open indoor areas to the public. Capacity must be limited to 25% of the maximum capacity of the indoor space.
All Libraries may resume indoor operations in accordance with the Retail Guidance published by the County Department of Public Health.
Operators of arts and entertainment venues may film, stream, or otherwise broadcast outdoors without an audience.
Gyms, Fitness Centers, Dance Studios, and Other Exercise Facilities may open in accordance with the Fitness Facilities Guidance published by the CDPH and DIR
Hotels, lodging, and short-term rentals may resume operations with restrictions.

All Elementary Schools (Transitional Kindergarten through Sixth Grade) may open according to CDPH’s COVID-19 and Reopening In-Person Schools Framework as well as the California Department of Education’s school reopening guidelines. Secondary schools must remain closed and continue distance learning.
All confirmed or suspected cases of COVID-19 are required to self-isolate. These individuals are to be given isolation instructions from healthcare providers.

policy_subtarget: Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Individuals considered close contacts of confirmed or suspected COVID-19 cases are required to quarantine.  Close contacts to persons with COVID-19 are defined as individuals who: • Live in or have stayed at the individual’s residence OR • Are intimate sexual partners of the individual OR • Provide or provided care to the individual without wearing a mask, gown, and gloves. This contact would also have had to occur while the individual was determined to be infectious. An individual is infectious from 48 hours before their symptoms began and until they are released from isolation.

All long-term care facilities, skilled nursing facilities and other congregate living settings and agencies in the County must implement health screenings for all entrants including staff and essential visitors and keep a log of all staff present each day. All staff must wear face coverings. Communal activities must be cancelled.
Individuals experiencing homelessness who are unsheltered and living in encampments should, to the maximum extent feasible, abide by 12 foot by 12 foot distancing for the placement of tents.
All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a household or living unit are prohibited, with some exceptions.

All individuals currently living within the County of Alameda are ordered to shelter at their place of residence. Individuals may leave their residences only for Essential Activities and outdoor recreational activities. Individuals leaving their residence must abide by social distancing requirements.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food); Manufacturers
policy_description: Retail stores now open for curbside pickup and reopened manufacturing plants and warehouses must must implement Site Specific Protection Plans, as required by California’s Resilience Roadmap, as well as any local guidance issued by the Alameda County Department of Public Health for adaptation and mitigation measures.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All businesses allowed to operate--Essential Businesses and Outdoor Businesses--must devise, post, and implement a social distancing protocol. These businesses must follow industry specific guidelines issued by the county Health Officer.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Childcare facilities must limit groups to 12 children or fewer. Children must be assigned to fixed groups. No mixing of groups may occur. Childcare employees shall remain with one group only.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Childcare facilities must limit groups to 12 children or fewer. Children must be assigned to fixed groups. No mixing of groups may occur. Childcare employees shall remain with one group only.

All businesses with a facility in the county, except those deemed Essential Businesses or Outdoor Businesses, must cease all activity at locations within the county, except "Minimum Basic Operations."  Minimum Basic Operations are defined as the minimum necessary activities to maintain the value of the business’s inventory, ensure security, process payroll and employee benefits, or for related functions and/or the minimum necessary activities to facilitate employees of the business being able to continue to work remotely from their residences.
Indoor and outdoor religious and cultural ceremonies must be limited to fewer than 100 people or 25% of the building/area capacity, whichever is lower.

policy_subtarget: Higher education; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: College sports team members and coaches should maintain a separation of at least six feet from other individuals and avoid the use of shared equipment, and all shared equipment should be sanitized between uses. Coaches shall wear face coverings at all times. Team members shall wear face coverings except when engaged in distance running or other high-intensity aerobic activity. Participants should limit their participation to one sport or activity and shall remain members of one stable group of up to 12 team members and one coach. Locker rooms, weight rooms, or other indoor facilities may not be used at this time.

All persons at dog parks must wear masks. People must maintain six feet of social distancing from people and animals from outside of their household. Visitors must not use common water facilities in the park, and should bring water for themselves and their dogs.

Retail and shopping centers must limit capacity to 50% of normal maximum capacity or the number of people who can always maintain six feet of distance from each other, whichever is lower. The store must employ reasonable efforts to ensure that its customers and employees comply with Face Coverings and Social Distancing Requirements while in the store. The store must limit the number of employees in enclosed areas, to ensure at least six feet of separation between employees to limit COVID-19 transmission, and shall comply with the requirements of the Retail Industry Guidance published by the California Department of Public Health (“CDPH”) and the Department of Industrial Relations (“DIR”).

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Outdoor fitness classed must be limited to 12 persons, including the instructor. The instructor and all participants must wear face coverings at all times, except when engaged in high-intensity aerobic activity. The instructor and all participants must arrange themselves to provide adequate social distancing of at least 6 feet at all times. Greater distance is recommended for high-intensity aerobic activity. No member of the class may share equipment, and equipment should be sanitized between uses. The instructor of or organizer for the classes must obtain any required use authorizations from the owner or manager of the outdoor space, including permits for using parks required by any city, county, or district before undertaking the fitness classes.

Outdoor seating arrangements must be limited to 6 people per table, all from same household or social bubble. Tables must be spaced at least 6 feet apart. Patrons are required to wear a face covering except when eating or drinking at a dining table. Alcohol may only be served with a meal. Restaurants must post near each entrance and restroom door in a manner readily visible to the public and employees the written Site-Specific Protection Protocol. Restaurants must designate a COVID-19 supervisor(s) in charge of ensuring the implementation of the food facilities’ Site-Specific Protection Plan.

Outdoor museums, outdoor historical sites, or publicly accessible gardens must prohibit members of the public from accessing any indoor facilities except to use restrooms, which must be frequently cleaned. All business and transactions involving members of the public must occur outdoors. Businesses operating under this category must implement measures to ensure that social distancing of at least six feet is maintained at all times other than between members of the same household.

Professional sports team must submit a proposed plan, detailing the sanitation, social distancing, health screening, and other procedures that will be implemented to minimize the risk of transmission among players and staff, to the County Health Officer. Teams may only resume practices, games, and tournaments, upon approval of the plan. In the event of inconsistencies between directives and orders of the Health officer and the approved plan, the approved plan controls.

Zoos must ensure that attendance remains below the lesser of 50% of the maximum capacity for the outdoor space ; or the capacity based on the ability of Personnel and patrons to comply with the Social Distancing Requirements. Employees and visitors must wear masks. Zoos must prohibit members of the public from accessing indoor areas associated with the facility, except to use restrooms, which must be cleaned frequently. Zoos must close interactive exhibits such as petting zoos, outdoor rides, playgrounds, and theaters. All business and transactions involving members of the public must occur outdoors.

Public outdoor pools must have at least one staff member in addition to a lifeguard on duty at all times to ensure compliance with state and County Orders. Outdoor pool facilities must require individuals to wear masks when out of the water and unable to maintain 6 feet of social distancing. Indoor areas including locker rooms and snack bars must remain closed. Hot tubs, saunas, and steam rooms must remain closed.

Personal service providers, including skin care and waxing services, non-medical massage providers, tattoo parlors, and non-medical electrolysis, may only provide service by appointment. Service providers must call customers in advance regarding COVID-19 symptoms and exposure. Service Providers and Customers must wear face coverings at all times. Services requiring removal of masks are prohibited. Providers must wear face coverings; glasses goggles, or face shields; disposable or washable smocks (laundered between use with different clients); and disposable gloves if appropriate for the service provided. To the extent possible, facilities must erect barriers such as plexiglass screens to separate the customer from the service provider. Dual services, in which two or more providers attend a single customer at the same time, are prohibited.

Wine tastings must be arranged by appointment. Patrons must not mix with individuals from other households or social bubbles. Winery staff must serve the wine, as patrons are prohibited from touching the bottles. Wineries must discontinue use of communal dump buckets, spit buckets, or other such vessels, and must provide patrons with individual, disposable containers to avoid splash contamination between guests. Indoor areas must remain closed. Patrons must maintain social distancing and may only remove face coverings when necessary for eating and drinking.

Hair salons, barbershops, and nail salons must provide services by appointment only. These services must call customers in advance regarding COVID-19 symptoms and exposure. Service Providers and customers must wear face coverings at all times. Services requiring removal of masks are prohibited. Providers must wear face coverings; glasses goggles, or face shields; disposable or washable smocks (laundered between use with different clients); and disposable gloves if appropriate for the service provided. To the extent possible, facilities must erect barriers such as plexiglass screens to separate the customer from the service provider. Dual services, in which two or more providers attend a single customer at the same time, are prohibited.

Gym, fitness center, dance studio, or other exercise facilities must limit capacity to 10% of the maximum capacity of the facility. Face coverings must be worn by employees and patrons at all times. Individuals engaged in exercise that increases the rate or intensity of breathing must maintain at least 12 feet of distance from others. Those engaged in activities that do not increase the rate or intensity of breathing must maintain at least six feet of distance from others. Patrons may not engage in exercise that requires the participation of other patrons, such as spotting. Facilities providing indoor group fitness activities must ensure that the shared space has doors and windows that can open to provide additional airflow. Classes must be staggered to allow for sanitization of the space and equipment between groups. Disinfectant sprays and wipes must be conveniently located near equipment for use by patrons. Facilities must post signage instructing patrons to spray and/or wipe down equipment stations before and after use. Locker room and shower facilities may only open to the extent necessary to provide restroom access. Benches, showers, and other shared spaces must be closed.

Hotel, lodging, and short-term rentals must operate in accordance with guidelines published by the CDPH and DIR. Facilities must close convention and meeting rooms, and any other space where people typically gather. Facilities must limit occupancy of lobbies and reception areas to 25% of maximum capacity or the number necessary to maintain six feet of distance between occupants. Facilities must install plexiglass separators at reception and concierge desks. Hotel fitness centers must monitor usage or remove or disable equipment to manage capacity. Facilities must close indoor pools, spas, steam rooms, and hot tubs.

Arts and entertainment venues conducting audience-less filming or broadcasting must conduct symptom screening of all participants prior to production, educate all participants regarding COVID-19 protocols, and communicate notification process if there is a positive and potential exposure as outlined in the Site-Specific Protection Plan. Performers and other participants must wear face coverings whenever not performing, and to the greatest extent practicable while performing. Performers unable to wear a face covering while performing must adhere to a minimum of 8 feet of distance from persons who are not members of the same household, unless the performers are separated from others person by Plexiglas or other impermeable barriers. Live streaming, recording, or broadcasting outdoor performances should not be done in a location or in a manner that might encourage the public to gather. The venue must take measures to prevent the public from gathering to view the performance, such as limiting the performance to private and secured property or taking other steps to limit access to the performance area.

"People must use public transit only for purposes of performing Essential Activities or to travel to and from work to operate Essential Businesses or maintain Essential Governmental Functions. People riding on public transit must comply with Social Distancing Requirements as defined in the order, to the greatest extent feasible."
Alpine county schools are closed and residents must adhere to Governor Newsom's executive order directing all California residents to stay home.

Some short-term vacation rentals in Alpine county are continuing to operate despite Governor Newsom's stay-at-home order. Alpine county businesses are warned of the crime must prohibit operation and will face fines, imprisonment, or both if they continue.
All persons may leave their residences only for essential activities, or to operate essential businesses as defined within the order and are encouraged to remain open.
People shall use public transit only for essential activities purposes and must comply with social distancing when they do.
All non essential businesses must close and may continue operations consisting exclusively of employees performing activities at their own residences.
All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a household are prohibited.

Individuals without symptoms must isolate for 10 days from the date of a positive test and individuals with symptoms must isolate at least 24 hours after all symptoms have recovered or at least 10 days since symptoms have started.

All individuals who are close contacts must quarantine themselves. Close contact is an individual who was in close proximity with an individual with COVID-19 for a prolonged period during the infectious period which begins 48 hours before symptoms began and ends when they are released from isolation.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases
policy_description: All individuals at risk to spread COVID-19 must isolate themselves and follow Amador public health guidance. These include individuals who were tested for and is awaiting results of tests, and those diagnosed with COVID-19.
Butte county to expand testing
County community testing site now open

" Due to the 2020 North Complex West Zone wildfire, the State’s COVID-19 testing site OptumServe, located at the Silver Dollar fairgrounds, has been required to relocate operations and is temporarily unavailable"
As per state guidance counties that have met the criteria for accelerated re opening can reopen hair salons and barbershops. Butte county will reopen barbershops and hair salons.

policy_subtarget: Casinos/gambling facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Restaurants/bars; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The following may open: Cardrooms, Satellite Wagering Facilities and Racetracks, Family Entertainment Centers, Restaurants, Bars and Wineries, Fitness Facilities, Museums, Galleries, Zoos and Aquariums
Butte County may move to tier 2. Approved businesses may open.
Schools may open under tier 2 if Butte county remains in tier 2 for 2 weeks.
Butte county moves to tier 3.

Barber shops and hair salons must - Maintain a log of customers and contact info for 14 days  - suspend walk in appointments - implement virtual check in technology  - ask customers to wait in their cars and ensure physical distancing  - after implementing mitigation meassures salons should print the butte county self certification placard
Business permitted to open must  have the local self certification window placards, and maintain a log of customers and participants and their contact information and time of visit
Alcohol may only be sold at the same time as a meal
Bars, brewpubs, breweries, pubs must close all operations indoors and outdoors unless offering meals

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; General population (inclusive); Restaurants/bars
policy_description: "The following businesses in Butte County must close operations unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up: - Gyms and fitness centers - Places of worship - Protests - Offices for non-critical infrastructure sectors - Personal care services (including nail salons, massage parlors, and tattoo parlors) - Hair salons and barbershops - Malls"
The Health Officer's May 1, 2020 Second Amended Order and Emergency Regulations Implementing Governor's March 4, 2020 Executive Order in Calaveras County is hereby rescinded.

The Health Officer's March 26, 2020 Order entitled "Clarification of Governor's and State Health Officer's 'Stay-at-Home' Order as related to lodging Facilities" is hereby rescinded. The rescission of this order is a part of Calaveras County's efforts to move into Stage 2 of reopening.
Outlines guidelines for Golf Course and Pro Shop operations.
intended_duration: Remains in place until the Governor's March 26, 2020 Order is rescinded, unless it is extended, terminated, or modified by the Health Officer in writing prior to that date.

policy_description: Dine-in restaurants must close indoor seating to customers. During this closure all dine-in restaurants may continue to utilize outdoor seating and must comply with the guidance for dine-in restaurants.

Family entertainment centers and movie theaters must close indoor services and attractions to customers. Drive-in theaters and family entertainment centers providing services outdoors may continue to operate if abiding by state public health guidelines.
Cardrooms must close indoor services to customers and must follow the guidance for cardrooms.
Indoor attractions at zoos and museums must close to visitors. Zoos and museums may continue to operate outdoor attractions.

For individuals who meet testing criteria but do not have an order from their doctor, can be tested by OptumServe at their testing sites. OptumServe will process and report data in accordance with California code regulations.

All facilities listed in this order (congregate living facilities) must begin testing all residents for COVID-19, provided the residents give consent and the tests can be performed safely, by July 6th, 2020. All test results should be recorded and all positive tests should be reported immediately to the Department of Health Services.

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: All private healthcare facilities in Contra Costa County must provide COVID-19 tests to essential workers, those with symptoms and those exposed to the virus, beginning no later than October 8, 2020.

The West County Health Center is organizing a mass testing event to support the Latinx community in the area that has been disproportionately hit by the recent increase in COVID-19 cases. Attendees will wear face coverings and move through a socially-distanced line to outdoor stations where nurses or volunteers will provide free COVID-19 tests and flu vaccinations.

The regional Shelter-in-Place order has been extended until further notice in Contra Costa County. Residents should only leave their homes for essential activities, outdoor activities, or additional activities such as indoor retail shopping, business offices, small social gatherings, protests, and others.

Essential businesses may continue operating while following their industry guidelines. They should operate at the minimum necessary capacity in order to ensure social distancing between employees/customers. Construction projects and outdoor business can continue operating at restricted capacity.

Non-essential businesses such as indoor retail shopping and businesses, places of worship and religious centers, office workplaces if telework is not possible, outdoor museums, libraries for curbside pickup, and drive-in theaters may open, provided they follow social distancing requirements and face coverings.

Outdoor dining, outdoor swimming pools, and campgrounds may now open to the public, provided they follow social distancing requirements and face covering guidelines set forth by the state of California.
As many as 100 people are now allowed to attend a funeral or other religious service at an indoor place of worship, provided they follow the state social distancing guidelines.
Hair salons and barbershops can open for operation provided they follow social distancing requirements and face covering recommendations.

Gyms and fitness facilities, personal care services that do not involve touching the client's face may open limited operations outdoors. Hotels and short term rentals may now open their operation to tourists and individual travel.

Following state guidelines, barber shops and hair salons can open indoor services, indoor malls can open at 25% capacity with the food courts closed, and gyms and fitness centers can open outdoor operations.

The Health Officer eases the restrictions on gatherings to allow for specified activities involving children and youth, allows mining and logging businesses to operate, and clarifies that vehicle gatherings remain an exception to the prohibition on gatherings involving persons from more than one household.

Healthcare and essential workers are exempt from this order, given that they inform their employer about the worker’s close contact to a confirmed case, the worker is asymptomatic, and the worker’s employer determines, based on staffing needs, that the worker needs to report to work, and the worker returns to work

In simplifying the plan for reducing the spread of COVID-19 in Contra Costa, the following businesses are allowed to open according to state guidelines: personal care services that involve close contact with the face may begin operating outdoors, except for tattooing, piercing and nonmedical electrolysis; racetracks and cardrooms may operate outdoors; music, television and film production may resume; professional sports without live audiences may resume.
Private social gatherings of up to 25 persons or three households are now allowed, provided that the gatherings conform to the State Gathering Guidance.
All physical school campuses will remain closed through the end of the 2019-2020 academic year and only offer distance learning.

policy_subtarget: Homeless shelters/homeless individuals; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: All individuals who are not residents/patients in a facility (defined by the order) must submit to a temperature screening prior to entry, self-evaluate for symptoms, and wear a mask at all times in the facility. If said individual presents with symptoms or a fever above 100.0 degrees F. they will be denied entry at that time.

All Shelter employees must suspend the intake of individuals to reside at the Shelter. They may continue offering services while socially distanced but any person who is not a resident as of April 14, 2020 at 2:00pm may not stay overnight.

Updates that all individuals with a positive lab test for COVID-19 must self isolate in their residence for a period of 7-10 days after onset of symptoms or positive test result. They may not leave their residence unless for necessary medical care and must notify any individuals they have come in close contact with.

Quarantine order remains in effect and close contact definition is updated to include being within six feet of a positive case for at least 15 minutes. All individuals must self-quarantine for a duration of 14-days if they come in close contact with an individual who has COVID-19. Close contact is defined as lived/stayed the night at the confirmed cases residence, been an intimate sexual partner with, or provided care without proper PPE to said case. Exceptions apply only to health care workers and first responders who have had close contact with a confirmed case but are asymptomatic and have informed their employer.
Non-essential business openings that were planned for July 1st, 2020, such as bars, indoor dining, and gyms, will be delayed until COVID-19 can be better contained in the County.

Any person who has had close contact with someone that has COVID-19 (lives with them, has been within 6 feet of case, etc.) must quarantine themselves in their homes for 14 days, with the exemption of healthcare workers and first responders, provided that they notify their work, are asymptomatic, and are determined necessary at work.

Restaurants in the County are not allowed to seat patrons indoors, and face coverings must be worn outdoors unless actively eating or drinking. Indoor religious ceremonies and celebrations are prohibited, and outdoor ceremonies may be conducted according to State guidelines. Outdoor protests are allowed, but indoor protests are forbidden. All residents over the age of 2 must wear face coverings while in public, except when eating or drinking.

All barber shops, hair salons, personal care facilities, offices for non-essential businesses, and shopping malls must close to the public unless they can move their operations outdoors or for pick-up.

All individuals who have tested positive for COVID-19 must isolate themselves for the following durations: if no symptoms were present, for 10 days following the positive test; if symptoms were present, for 24 hours since recovery and at least 10 days since the symptoms started; for those who were hospitalized, for 24 hours since recovery and at least 20 days since the symptoms started.

All persons in Contra Costa County who have come into contact with a case of COVID-19 must quarantine themselves in their home for 14 days from the date they last saw the person and isolate themselves if symptoms arise.

All persons who have had contact with a Case of COVID-19, including those who attended a social gathering with a Case, must quarantine. The same exemptions stated in the Mass Quarantine Order on September 14th apply.

The following non-essential businesses must follow the restrictions set forth: indoor operations for restaurants, movie theaters, and places of worship must be limited to 25 percent of the maximum capacity or 100 persons, whichever is less; all indoor operations for card rooms and wagering locations are prohibited; all operations for outdoor bars are prohibited, except to the extent that alcohol is served with dine-in meals.
Attendance at professional and collegiate sporting events must be limited to no more than 25 people from a maximum of three different households.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food); Grocery store; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Higher education
policy_description: The following non-essential businesses must follow the restrictions set forth: indoor retail stores now have a maximum occupancy of 50%; grocery stores can operate at full capacity; indoor shopping malls must reduce their occupancy to 50% and reduce the occupancy of food courts to 25% or 100 people, whichever is fewer; office workspaces must operate remotely; higher education institutions must keep indoor lectures and student gatherings to 25% occupancy or 100 people, whichever is fewer; gyms and fitness centers must scale back their indoor occupancies to 10%; communal indoor pools must close; indoor family entertainment centers must close their indoor operations; amusement parks cannot operate; most live outdoor theatrical, musical or artistic performances are prohibited.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education; Churches/places of worship; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: As the county moves back into the purple tier, the following restrictions will apply: social gatherings involving people from different households are permitted outdoors only, with a maximum of three households and 25 people; K-12 schools may not reopen for in-person instruction and higher education must move all indoor lectures outdoors; worship services must now be held outdoors only; movie theaters, museums, and exhibit spaces may operate outdoors only.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Indoor dining, concessions at indoor movie theaters, and indoor activities at gyms and fitness centers are prohibited.

The California State Regional Stay at Home Order will be applied in Contra Costa County. All gatherings with members outside your household are prohibited and everyone should remain at home except for essential activities. Retail and essential businesses may remain open indoors, but only at 25% capacity.

Del Norte County Public Health and the Office of Emergency Services have partnered with the Del Norte Unified School District, State of California, and Verily to open a new community- based testing site (CBTS) to expand COVID-19 testing for Del Norte residents. Drive thru testing will begin this week, Friday and Saturday, May 29th and 30th, from 9am to 2pm at Del Norte High School.  Beginning next week, testing will take place Mondays thru Wednesdays, and in the future it is hoped to expand the program to bring testing to our outlying communities. This is a free service to help protect the public health and safety of our community. You must register online before coming to the test site.  Starting today, residents can go through the online registration process including screening of symptoms, whether they are experiencing any or not, and make an appointment online for testing using the Baseline COVID-19 Program online screener and appointment scheduling system found at www.projectbaseline.com/COVID19.  Eligible persons must be 18 years or older, live in Del Norte County, and be willing to electronically sign the COVID-19 Public Health Authorization Form and Lab Consent. Based on the COVID-19 screener and testing appointment availability, individuals will be provided a testing location appointment. Please visit www.projectbaseline.com/COVID19 to learn more. For those individuals without online access or who are not English-proficient, the Department of Health and Human Services is providing assistance via telephone or in person.
Non-essential travel is strongly discouraged. 14 day self-quarantine is advised for those traveling from beyond the immediately adjacent counties.

Prior to opening, every business must complete and submit the Business-Specific COVID 19 Operations Plan form  A business that has submitted its COVID-19 Operations Plan may “self-certify” that it is ready to open, and open its location pending approval by the Public Health Department. A self-certified business must place the Self-Certification Window Placard in its window.    After Public Health has reviewed the COVID-19 Operations Plan and has approved, the business will be contacted by Public Health or by a representative of Public Health. It is unknown at this point how long the review process will take. A certificate will be given to the business, stating that the business's COVID-19 Operations Plan has been approved and that the location is certified to open and has met all requirements of COVID-19 transmission mitigation.   Businesses may self-certify to reopen upon submitting the COVID-19 Operations Plan as follows:   f. Parks: Golf courses, non-congregate portions of public parks and trails may open, but services are limited and social distancing strictly maintained.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Except those workers employed in essential sectors, as defined by N-33-20, all persons age 65 or older, and those under the age of 65 who have elevated risk, should continue to shelter in place.

policy_subtarget: Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Retail stores (not including food); Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Outdoor recreation or space; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Prior to opening, every business must complete and submit the Business-Specific COVID 19 Operations Plan form  A business that has submitted its COVID-19 Operations Plan may “self-certify” that it is ready to open, and open its location pending approval by the Public Health Department. A self-certified business must place the Self-Certification Window Placard in its window.    After Public Health has reviewed the COVID-19 Operations Plan and has approved, the business will be contacted by Public Health or by a representative of Public Health. It is unknown at this point how long the review process will take. A certificate will be given to the business, stating that the business's COVID-19 Operations Plan has been approved and that the location is certified to open and has met all requirements of COVID-19 transmission mitigation.   Businesses may self-certify to reopen upon submitting the COVID-19 Operations Plan as follows:   a. Medical Offices: Elective surgeries may resume service under the advised guidelines and current recommendations from CDC and CDPH.  b. Clothing Stores: Clothing-thrift stores, and fashion stores can reopen with limits on customers per hour, with social distancing in lines and entrances. In-store fittings would be discouraged, and home fittings that are returned would be shelved for a minimum of 3 days. Thrift donations should be set aside and "aged" at normal temperature and humidity for at least 5 days to avoid persistent virus contamination.  c. Furniture: Furniture stores can re-open with appointment only and social distance no sales from the floor; warehouse only, unless a floor item can be held in the warehouse for at least 5 days.  d. Auto dealers: Auto dealers may resume sales, with appointments only and social distancing design of offices and showrooms. Social distance rules to be applied both inside and outside.   e. Daycare: Daycare can resume with protective masks for staff. Recommend smallest management groups in shared space, with child group cohorts.   f. Parks: Golf courses, non-congregate portions of public parks and trails may open, but services are limited and social distancing strictly maintained.   g. Offices: Office-based businesses may reopen, though telework is strongly encouraged  h. Landscape gardening  I. Pet-grooming  j. Tanning facilities  k. In-restaurant dining

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Retail stores (not including food); Private sector
policy_description: May 14, 2020, Del Norte County submitted the local variance plan and attestation for businesses and organizations in Stage Two to open at a quicker pace than the rest of the state. Today, the state approved the variance.   Clothing Stores  Thrift Stores  Furniture Stores  Auto Dealership  Childcare  Golf Courses  Public Parks, non-congregate portions and trails  Office-Based Businesses, though telework is still encouraged whenever possible  Limited Services of landscape gardening, pet grooming, and tanning facilities  Dine-In Restaurants  All businesses must have a written COVID-19 Operations Plan to mitigate the risk of transmission of COVID-19.

Beginning June  19th, businesses that conduct Massage, Tattoos, and Facial and Manicure services may resume,  provided the local health department has certified that the county has the continued resources to allow  further relaxation of restrictions. Facial and Manicure services include a long list of items that will now  be allowed, some of which involve customers not wearing masks.  We are recommending that for these encounters, salon owners and stylists consider using an N95  respirator, rather than a typical cloth mask. A respirator is designed to protect the user more than it  protects others, and for an encounter with an unmasked customer, the extra protection may be well  worth the effort. Respirators can be safely reused if allowed to sit unused for 5 days. There is a  common-sense approach to reusing respirators, just put them in a paper bag so they can “breathe” and  dry out, and they can be safely reused 5 days later. Coronavirus will not last that long on a respirator.

This revision adds that hotels can now reopen to full capacity, but must retain one (1) un-booked room for every thirty (30) rooms in the hotel in the event a guest should become ill. It also allows museums, galleries and family entertainment to reopen. Businesses must continue to turn in their reopening plan to Public Health.

In this revision of the order has added that additional Fitness Center services (weight machines, cardio machines, etc.) can begin the reopening process using the fitness center guidance provided by CDPH. No other changes were made from the previous order.

Re-opening of new authorized businesses. All other retailers are allowed to have an online component to their business and do curbside pick up or delivery.
intended_duration: The City of Fresno will continue to monitor public health indicators in the community and adjust the Authorized Business program as necessary.  If there is a spike in the number of infections that could be traced to the re-opening or if our local healthcare system is projected to reach capacity, the City may choose to slow down or even roll back the program.  If public health indicators stay flat or improve, the City could accelerate this program.

policy_description: On May 21, 2020, the Fresno City Council adopted Emergency Ordinance No. 2020-020 to assist restaurants and other businesses that are unable to operate at full indoor capacity due to Covid-19. Under this Ordinance, businesses may temporarily operate in parking lots and common outdoor areas of shopping centers in order to remain open while ensuring compliance with State requirements and CDC recommendations for distancing.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: This ordinance allows the opening of restaurants, beauty parlors, and hair and nail salons based on specific dates and guidelines. In addition, other businesses are not to operate based on the state's guidance. Currently,the State of California says the following businesses are not permitted to operate, including but not limited  to:  personal  services  such  as  hair  and  nail  salons,  tattoo  parlors,  gyms  and fitness  studios; hospitality  services  such  as  bars,  nightclubs,  wineries,  tasting  rooms and  lounges;  entertainment  venues,  such  as  movie  theaters,  gaming,  gambling,  and arcade  venues,  and  pro  sports,  indoor  museums  and  gallery  spaces,  zoos,  and libraries; public events and gatherings; community centers, public pools, playgrounds and picnic areas; convention centers; concert venues; live audience sports; festivals;theme parks; and hotels and lodging for leisure and tourism.
intended_duration: This order shall remain in effect until it is repealed, modified or suspendedor the sooner of one of the following occurs: 1) The Governor  and/orState Health Officer end the State’s Stay at Home Order; or 2) All businesses in the City of Fresno have the ability to safely and responsibly reopen.

Upon  confirmation  of  a  positive  COVID-19  case  among  an  employee   or   customer   of   a   business,   the   employer   shall   notify   all   employees  of  the  possible  exposure  within  24  hours.    Such  notification  shall  maintain  confidentiality  of  the  individuals  involved  or  affected,  in  compliance  with  Americans  with  Disability  Act  and  privacy  laws. policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Public sector/government employees; Private sector
policy_description: As a requirement for schools which have or will re-open, each school district including private schools and charters, shall conduct COVID-19 surveillance testing of a representative sample of its personnel who have contact, will make contact, or potentially may have contact with students. Personnel includes certificated, classified, and contracted staff of the district.  School districts may select which of their personnel will be tested to ensure a representative cross-section of schools and geographic locations are sampled. All surveillance testing shall be laboratory polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing only.

Play structures and group picnic shelters within the parks and campgrounds will remain closed until further notice.

policy_description: Any business wishing to re‐open, expand operations, or do business in the County of Fresno, must follow State guidelines for ensuring safety of workers and customers during the COVID‐19 crisis. If a business does not believe it can meet the State guidelines, the business must contact the Fresno County Department of Public Health with an alternate plan to meet health and safety guidelines.  Department of Public Health, and/or the Public Health Officer may modify agriculture employer guidance based on other factors.   The  Department  of  Public  Health,  the  Public  Health  Officer,  and  individual  business Employee Health Departments with the approval of the Health Officer, may modify employer screening, reporting, return to work clearance, and isolation/quarantine guidance based on other factors.
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_description: That State of California has announced that Fresno County is among the Counties approved to allow for the modified reopening of barbershops and hair salons as the County moves further into Stage 2 of COVID-19 recovery. Those businesses looking to reopen will do so with appropriate measures in place to protect the health and safety of employees and customers in a continued effort to help mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Private sector; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Workers may return to work: i.After 10 days have passed since positive COVID test date, if they remain asymptomatic. ii. After 10 days have passed since ONSET of COVID-19 symptoms and 24 hours since recovery from these symptoms, if they are symptomatic. iii. Immunocompromised   workers   (as   determined   by   their   physician   or   DPH   Medical Investigations Team) may be asked to wait until 14-20 days have passed since symptom onset, in  concordance  with  current  recommendations  from  the  Centers  for  Disease  Control  and Prevention (CDC). This determination will be made on an individual basis.
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_description: Any business wishing to re‐open, expand operations, or do business in the County of Fresno, must follow State guidelines for ensuring safety of workers and customers during the COVID‐19 crisis. If a business does not believe it can meet the State guidelines, the business must contact the Fresno County Department of Public Health with an alternate plan to meet health and safety guidelines.  Department of Public Health, and/or the Public Health Officer may modify agriculture employer guidance based on other factors.   The  Department  of  Public  Health,  the  Public  Health  Officer,  and  individual  business Employee Health Departments with the approval of the Health Officer, may modify employer screening, reporting, return to work clearance, and isolation/quarantine guidance based on other factors.
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Private sector; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: The following health guidelines have shifted from isolating for ten days after onset of symptoms and until 3 days after  improvement  of  symptoms  or  fever  without  the  use  of  fever-reducing  medications to 24 hours instead of the 3 days.  Health providers should tell patients with no exclusionary diagnosis to isolate themselves based on health guidelines. Employers should tell employees with signs of febrile respiratory illness to isolate themselves based on health guidelines. Residents should isolate themselves based on health guidelines if they have symptoms of COVID-19.
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_description: Multiple different sectors of the city are being reopened. Many of the reopenings are in limited capacities in order to limit spread of the novel coronavirus.
intended_duration: As long as the COVID-19 cases do not exceed a certain threshold in frenso, thus keeping fresno in the red tier, these reopenings will not be reversed.

policy_description: If you are an essential worker as defined by the State of California,you are not required to quarantine as defined in 6Fviand 6Fviiand you may return to work if you remain symptom free If it is determined that they are a close contact to a person positive with COVID-19, residents will quarantine until14 days have passed from the last known contact with the person with the COVID-19 positive test, OR,vii.If they develop symptoms of COVID-19 during the quarantine period, they will isolate...
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_description: Any business wishing to re‐open, expand operations, or do business in the County of Fresno, must follow State guidelines for ensuring safety of workers and customers during the COVID‐19 crisis. If a business does not believe it can meet the State guidelines, the business must contact the Fresno County Department of Public Health with an alternate plan to meet health and safety guidelines.  Department of Public Health, and/or the Public Health Officer may modify agriculture employer guidance based on other factors.   The  Department  of  Public  Health,  the  Public  Health  Officer,  and  individual  business Employee Health Departments with the approval of the Health Officer, may modify employer screening, reporting, return to work clearance, and isolation/quarantine guidance based on other factors.
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Private sector; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Direct the patient, if no exclusionary diagnosis is found, and they are found to have new or worsening symptoms of any COVID-19 symptoms, to isolate him/herself for 10 days after onset of symptoms and for 24 hours  after improvement of symptoms or fever without the use of fever-reducing medications UNLESS they subsequently test negative while symptomatic for COVID-19 Direct employee excluded from work to isolate All Residents shall Isolate themselves at home and separately from household members (if possible) if they have signs and symptoms of,or if they test positive for COVID-19  Guidelines for positive symptomatic and asymptomatic people, and people exposed to positive people are made here If they are evaluated by a health care provider and subsequently test negative while symptomatic for COVID-19, they may stop isolation after improvement of symptoms for 24 hours without the use of fever reducing medications
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_description: The Fresno County Library is closing all branches.
intended_duration: All branches of the Fresno County Public Library will close beginning March 18, 2020 through April 14, 2020. Closure dates are subject to change.

policy_description: Closure of the Assessor/Recorder's Offices and Limited/No Walk-in Services
intended_duration: Services for walk-in services will no longer be provided until further notice

policy_description: The article provides information on the various closures/modifications of county department offices
An authorization of procedural changes to the Department of Social Services in Fresno County to align with state and federal guidance.
intended_duration: For the duration of the pandemic.

Businesses must contact the Health Department and receive approval from the health officer before modifying the above guidance.

policy_description: Essential professions may be allowed to work provided that adequate workplace screening done by employer to exclude those with febrile respiratory illness.

intended_duration: The closure was initially effective Wednesday, April 1, 2020. The closure will now be in effect until further notice. Programs provided by the Division will continue through alternative methods.

intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_subtarget: Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Public sector/government employees; Private sector; General population (inclusive)

Direct the patient, if no exclusionary diagnosis is found, to isolate him/herself for seven days after onset of symptoms or three days after cessation of fever without the use of fever-reducing medications Direct employees excluded from work to isolate at home All residents shall isolate themselves if they have signs and symptoms for seven days after onset of symptoms, unless they should require further medical attention
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_description: This policy was extended. Contacts of patients, employees, and residents who are informed that they have come into close contact with a person suspected to have COVID-19 are to self quarantine for 14 days.
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

All employers, besides agricultural employers who follow different guidelines, must on a daily basis, while conducting business, screen all employees for febrile respiratory illness. Exclude from work all employees that report symptoms of febrile respiratory within guidelines
intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_subtarget: Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: The purpose of these Emergency Procedures is to prevent any individual who certifies that they have presented a symptom associated with COVID-19 from entering a County of Fresno (County) facility or worksite in order to ensure the safety and health of employees and the public.
intended_duration: These Emergency Procedures shall be effective immediately and shall remain in effect until the County Administrative Officeradvises that they are no longer operative due to the end of the present public health emergency.

policy_description: The purpose of these Emergency Procedures is to ensure the health and safety of working conditions for all County employees by using telework to the greatest extent possible while continuing to provide essential services to our constituents. Ensuring healthy and safe working conditions and the health and safety of employees is a business necessity for the County.
intended_duration: These Emergency Procedures shall be effective immediately and shall remain in effect until the County Administrative Officer advises that the procedures are no longer operative due to the end of the present public health emergency.

policy_description: The purpose of these Emergency Procedures is to ensure the health and safety of working conditions for all County employees through adherence to physical distancing and cleaning and disinfecting principles and best practices. Ensuring both healthy and safe  working  conditions,  and  the  health  and  safety  of  employees,  is  a  business necessity for the County
intended_duration: These Emergency Procedures shall be effective immediately and shall remain in effect until the Chief Administrative Officer advises that the Emergency Procedures are no longer operative due to the end of the present public health emergency.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space; Government/public buildings
policy_description: The purpose of these Emergency Procedures is to ensure healthy and safe working conditions for all County employees through adherence to federal, state, and local cleaning  and  disinfecting  requirements,  recommendations,  and  best  practices intended to limit exposure to the virus that causes COVID-19. Ensuring healthy and safe  working  conditions  and  the  health  and  safety  of  employees is  a  business necessity for the County.
intended_duration: These Emergency Procedures shall be effective immediately and shall remain in effect until the County Administrative Officeradvises that they are no longer operative due to the end of the present public health emergency.

policy_description: Venues that are currently authorized to provide off sale beer, wine, and spirits to be consumed off premises and do not offer sit-down, dine-in meals shall follow the guidance for retail operations  and offer curbside sales only, until local and/or statewide rules allow additional retail activity. Producers of beer, wine, and spirits shall follow the guidance for manufacturing operations. This Order does not apply to wineries and wine tasting rooms provided that the winery complies with the required Guidance for tasting rooms. In addition, these freedoms are not granted to entertainment venues.
intended_duration: This policy is meant to be in effect until further notice

policy_description: Brewpubs, breweries, bars, and pubs, shall close until those establishments are allowed to resume operation per state guidance and local permission, unless they are offering sit-down, dine-in meals. Alcohol can only be sold in the same transaction as a meal. Dine-in restaurants, brewpubs, breweries, bars, and pubs that provide sit-down meals shall follow the dine-in restaurant guidance and should continue to encourage takeout and delivery service whenever possible.Bar areas within a dine-in restaurant that cannot follow the dine-in restaurant guidance shall close.  Various other definitions and restrictions are explained
intended_duration: This policy is meant to be in effect until further notice

policy_description: Retail alcohol sale is permitted. Any business with outdoor operations/can operate curbside can follow guidelines to continue operations. Entertainment venues are not provided these freedoms. Producers of alcohol must follow guidance for manufacturing operations.
intended_duration: This policy is meant to be in place until further notice.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space; Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Casinos/gambling facilities
policy_description: All indoor and outdoor operations of bars and related businesses are to be closed. The following is for the indoor spaces of these establishments. Restaurants are to be closed, as well as their bars. Family entertainment centers are to be closed as well. All movie theaters are to be closed. All museums and zoos are to be closed. All cardrooms are to be closed. All wineries and wine tasting rooms are to be closed. Entertainment venues are to continue to be closed. Any places open but providing entertainment need to stop doing so.
intended_duration: This policy is meant to be in place until further notice.

intended_duration: Until Fresno County has come off the State’s Monitoring List for fourteen (14) consecutive days.

Temperature screenings are also done during health screenings.

intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

intended_duration: This Order shall remain in full force and effect until terminated, superseded, or amended.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Public services; Government/public buildings
policy_description: Fresno County has announced the temporary closure of the Board of Supervisors, Clerk of the Board and Administrative Offices and directed staff to quarantine following the positive COVID-19 test of    the County Supervisor
intended_duration: These closures are temporary and are to continue until further notice.

policy_subtarget: Non essential workers (inclusive); Private sector; Non essential business (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Restaurants/bars; Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: The following non-essential businesses in Glenn County are authorized to reopen under Phase 3B: gyms & fitness facilities, bars & wineries, travel, outdoor recreation including pools and campgrounds, cardrooms, satellite wagering facilities, and racetracks (no spectators), day camps, museums, galleries, zoos, and aquariums, family entertainment centers (arcades, bowling, movie theaters etc.).

These non-essential businesses are allowed to open in the following manner: restaurants may reopen for indoor operations at 25% capacity; places of worship may reopen for indoor operations at 25% capacity or less than 100 people (whichever is less); retail may increase to 50% capacity; gyms and fitness centers may reopen to indoor operations at 10% capacity.
Glenn County strongly encourages all people to maintain 6 feet of distance between them at small gatherings and in public places.
The Glenn County Sheriff's Office and Probation Office will be closed to the public.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Non essential workers (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Public services
policy_description: All Senior Nutrition Centers in Glenn County have been closed entirely.
No visitors will be permitted at the Glenn County Jail.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Home isolation is recommended for seniors 65 years and older and individuals with chronic conditions.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Visitation allowances to care facilities for the elderly in Glenn County will be restricted to essential activities and end of life for family members only.
All mass gatherings in Glenn County should be cancelled or rescheduled. Any type of public gathering should be avoided and residents should instead promote social distancing and isolation.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: All restaurants in Glenn County should switch to drive-through, pick-up, and delivery services. Seated dining should be closed entirely and social distancing measures need to be put in place.
All residents of Glenn County are encouraged to stay at home, except for essential needs such as healthcare, groceries, work, going to the bank, etc.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Family entertainment centers must close all indoor activities and limit visitors to outdoor activities (ex. mini golf) only. Museums, zoos, and cardrooms must either modify to outdoor operations or close entirely.
All breweries, wineries, pubs, bars, and brewpubs in Glenn County must close.
Glenn County requires all restaurants to remove indoor dining options and use only outdoor dining, takeout, and delivery options.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Personal care facilities; Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Glenn County requires that the following non-essential businesses close their entirely or move to outdoor operations only: personal care facilities, gyms and fitness centers, places of worship, malls, and offices for non-critical infrastructure sectors.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Churches/places of worship; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Restaurants, places of worship, gyms and fitness centers, bars, and family entertainment centers may only be open for outdoor operations. The retail industry, including shopping malls, may open indoors at 25% capacity. Personal care facilities may continue indoor operation and professional sports may continue without a live audience.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Glenn County encourages all individuals, especially those above the age of 65 or with underlying conditions, to limit travel to essential activities such as work, grocery shopping, healthcare, etc.

policy_description: First responders, government officers, investigators, medical personnel, and law enforcement officers are not restricted from carrying out their duties and accessing sites outlined in this order.

policy_description: Continuation of policy outlined in March 31, 2020 order: First responders, government officers, investigators, medical personnel, and law enforcement officers are not restricted from carrying out their duties and accessing sites outlined in this order.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Essential workers (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: Continuation of policy outlined in March 31, 2020 order: First responders, government officers, investigators, medical personnel, and law enforcement officers are not restricted from carrying out their duties and accessing sites outlined in this order.

Update to previous policy: No medical examination or other record is required for COVID Exposed Persons to be released from the 14 day quarantine, and no verification is required to return to work. Further, no clearance testing for COVID-19 is required.

Update to the previous policy: No medical evaluation is required for COVID Positive Persons to be released from isolation after the criteria for fevers and initial testing dates are met. Further, no verification is required for return to work.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Essential workers (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: Continuation of policy outlined in March 31, 2020 order: First responders, government officers, investigators, medical personnel, and law enforcement officers are not restricted from carrying out their duties and accessing sites outlined in this order.

All residents of the county should continue to stay at home, with the exception of maintaining essential business operations or engaging in activities deemed permissible by the California Department of Public Health in public health order, the state's Resilience Roadmap, and the county's Roadmap to Recovery.

policy_description: Continuation of policy outlined in March 31, 2020 order: First responders, government officers, investigators, medical personnel, and law enforcement officers are not restricted from carrying out their duties and accessing sites outlined in this order.

All residents of the county should continue to stay at home, with the exception of maintaining essential business operations or engaging in activities deemed permissible by the California Department of Public Health in public health order, the state's Resilience Roadmap, and the county's Roadmap to Recovery.
Continuation of previous order: Businesses impacted by this order are encouraged to post a copy of the order onsite and to provide a copy to members of the public.

policy_description: Continuation of the previous policy: Families visiting entities within the county, such as businesses, should refrain from visiting these entities in groups and should limit the number of visitors to one per family.

Under  the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, all institutions of higher education shall conduct remote operations. However, indoor operations for specialized courses, such as labs or studio arts, where participants are physically distanced based on the nature of the work, may resume indoors. All other indoor operations will remain closed.

policy_description: Continuation of policy outlined in March 31, 2020 order: First responders, government officers, investigators, medical personnel, and law enforcement officers are not restricted from carrying out their duties and accessing sites outlined in this order.
