policy_description: Continuation of the previous policy: Families visiting entities within the county, such as businesses, should refrain from visiting these entities in groups and should limit the number of visitors to one per family. Individuals are only permitted to gather based on the guidelines set forth in this order.
Continuation of previous order: Businesses impacted by this order are encouraged to post a copy of the order onsite and to provide a copy to members of the public.

All residents of the county should continue to stay at home, with the exception of maintaining essential business operations or engaging in activities deemed permissible by the California Department of Public Health in public health order and the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Hotels/lodging; Manufacturers; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Public transportation; Retail stores (not including food); Non-governmental organizations; Public services
policy_description: All businesses in the county should continue to stay closed, with the exception of essential businesses and those permitted to reopen as outlined by the Resilience Roadmap set by the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) and the county's Roadmap to Recovery.  Businesses permitted to reopen should follow the industry-specific safety guidelines outlined by the State Public Health Officer and CDPH. If the county varies from the state's Resilience Roadmap, the county Health Officer must ensure that all readiness criteria have been met. Businesses impacted by this order are encouraged to post a copy of the order onsite and to provide a copy to members of the public.

All residents of the county should continue to stay at home, with the exception of maintaining essential business operations or engaging in activities deemed permissible by the California Department of Public Health.
Businesses impacted by this order are encouraged to post a copy of the order onsite and to provide a copy to members of the public.

All residents of the county should continue to stay at home, with the exception of maintaining essential business operations or engaging in activities deemed permissible by the California Department of Public Health in public health order, the state's Resilience Roadmap, and the county's Roadmap to Recovery.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Hotels/lodging; Manufacturers; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Public transportation; Retail stores (not including food); Non-governmental organizations; Public services
policy_description: Extension of prior policy: All businesses in the county should continue to stay closed, with the exception of essential businesses and those permitted to reopen as outlined by the Resilience Roadmap set by the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) and the county's Roadmap to Recovery.  Businesses permitted to reopen should follow the industry-specific safety guidelines outlined by the State Public Health Officer and CDPH. If the county varies from the state's Resilience Roadmap, the county Health Officer must ensure that all readiness criteria have been met. Businesses impacted by this order are encouraged to post a copy of the order onsite and to provide a copy to members of the public.

Places of worship may reopen with the following restrictions: 1. Singing and group recitation is not permitted in indoor facilities; 2. Rituals such as the kissing of objects, the use of common cups, and the use of other common items shall be discontinued;  3. Activities such as communion may continue via pre-packaged items placed on seats prior to the service; 4. Members of the congregation may bring their own books or worship materials; 5. Congregates may place donations in containers set up by the places of worship--the use of offering plates is discontinued; 6. Children must remain with their families at all times, and as such, Sunday schools and other children's services shall be discontinued.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Families visiting entities within the county, such as businesses, should refrain from visiting these entities in groups and should limit the number of visitors to one per family.
Continuation of previous order: Businesses impacted by this order are encouraged to post a copy of the order onsite and to provide a copy to members of the public.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Hotels/lodging; Manufacturers; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Public transportation; Retail stores (not including food); Non-governmental organizations; Public services
policy_description: Continuation of prior policy regarding practices for businesses that reopen. Additionally, entities that offer curbside pickup and delivery shall not allow visitors inside of their buildings. Businesses are encouraged the implement and maintain teleworking practices. Businesses shall comply with the face covering guidance issued by the California Department of Public Health.

Update to the previous policy: The COVID Positive Person's medical provider shall determine whether the COVID Positive Person is immunocompromised, and whether the person has mild, moderate, severe, or critical illness or is asymptomatic. Requirements are detailed for providing COVID Positive Persons with copies of the appropriate health officer's orders. These individuals shall isolate at home and notify those with whom they have come into contact. COVID Positive Persons who are not immunocompromised or who experienced mild or illness shall isolate for at least 10 days since the symptoms occurred, at least 24 hours since the last fever occurred, and the symptoms have improved. COVID Positive Persons who have a positive laboratory test and who are immunocompromised, but who do not exhibit symptoms, may discontinue isolation 10 days after their positive test if they do not develop symptoms.
Libraries may reopen, provided that they follow the county and state's guidance for retailers, and the state's guidance for libraries.

Indoor operations for specialized courses, such as labs or studio arts, where participants are physically distanced based on the nature of the work, may resume indoors. All other indoor operations will remain closed.
Racetracks may operate without spectators; indoor operations must remain closed.

policy_subtarget: Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Essential business (inclusive); Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Government/public buildings; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Personal care facilities; Hotels/lodging; Manufacturers; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Public transportation
policy_description: Under the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, the entities and sectors outlined in section 3, part a, of this order may reopen to full capacity, unless this order otherwise restricts this.

Under the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, all schools and school-based programs shall conduct remote operations, unless this order states otherwise. Schools and school-based programs must adhere to industry programs, and school-based programs must be limited to 14 children and 2 supervising adults for each designated area.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Minors and children
policy_description: Under the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, childcare programs and providers, and day camps, may reopen indoor and outdoor operations to full capacity. These entities must comply with additional guidance from the state, including limitations of no more than 14 children and 2 supervising adults in a group. The children and supervising adults in one group cannot physically interact with those of the other group, or with other staff and parents of the children in other groups.

Under the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, retail stores, shopping malls, libraries, gas stations, and similar entities may reopen indoor and outdoor operations up to 25% capacity, unless there are other restrictions specified.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Under the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, the entities and sectors outlined in section 3, part d, of this order may reopen outdoor operations only, unless this order states otherwise.
Under the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, all office workplaces must adhere to the industry guidelines and conduct indoor operations, except for essential infrastructure sectors.
Under the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, grocery stores may reopen indoor and outdoor operations up to 50% capacity, and they must adhere to retail industry guidelines.

Personal care facilities such as nail salons and electrologists may operate indoor business, provided they adhere to guidelines for personal care services. Other personal care facilities, such as body waxing studios, skincare services, and massage therapy studios, may only conduct business outdoors. Tattoo, non-medical electrolysis, and piercing facilities must remain closed.

Private gatherings are permitted, provided that no more than three households, and no more than 16 individuals, attend the gathering. Activities such as singing, chanting, shouting, and playing wind instruments is not permitted during private gatherings.
Individuals may gather for the provision of services, provided that they maintain 6 feet minimum of distance from others at all times possible.

Entities operating the following personal care facilities are permitted to reopen indoor operations, provided that they follow the guidelines for expanded personal care services: body waxing studios, electrologists, estheticians, massage therapy studios, nail salons, piercing shops, skincare/cosmetology services, and tattoo parlors.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: All businesses in the county are ordered to close, except for those businesses deemed essential by the California Department of Public Health. Businesses impacted by this order are encouraged to post a copy of the order onsite and to provide a copy to members of the public. Businesses are encouraged to consult the California Department of Public Health website daily for updates.
All residents of the county are ordered to stay at home, with the exception of essential workers. Residents may leave for activities deemed permissible by the California Department of Public Health.

All persons diagnosed with, or exhibiting symptoms of, COVID-19 ("COVID Positive Persons"), must isolate in their residences to slow the spread of COVID-19. Individuals who have symptoms but are not hospitalized may discontinue isolation after at least at least three consecutive days pass without a fever, without the use of fever-reducing medication, and at least ten days after the symptoms appear. Individuals with positive lab tests but without symptoms may discontinue isolation after at least ten days pass since the date of the positive COVID-19 test, if the individual does not develop subsequent symptoms. COVID Positive Persons should also provide individuals with whom they have had close contact with the health officer's quarantine order.

Any person in close contact with a COVID Positive Person is considered a COVID Exposed Person. Close contact is defined as being within 6 feet of a COVID Positive Person for more than 10 minutes, or having contact with bodily fluids/secretions (coughs, sneezes, etc.) of a COVID Positive Person. COVID Exposed Persons must quarantine themselves for 14 days after the date of last close contact with the COVID Positive Person. COVID Exposed Persons may leave their residences to receive necessary medical care; if they do not exhibit symptoms, they may leave their residences to procure food and necessities if they maintain at least 6 feet of distance and wear a face covering at all times. The COVID Exposed Person may attend work if they are a part of the essential workforce only if they do not exhibit symptoms, if the employer screens employees and visitors, and if the exposed person wears a face covering at all times and maintains 6 feet of distance.

policy_subtarget: Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: A COVID Positive Person's medical provider must supply the individual with a copy of this order regarding isolation and must notify the county Health Officer and/or his representative of the positive case. The medical provider must produce written confirmation that the COVID Positive Person received a copy of this order. If hospitalized, the medical provider must complete the Discharge Plan for Confirmed COVID-19 Cases. The medical provider must also supply a copy of the county's quarantine order, and should instruct the individual to share the quarantine order with individuals with whom they have been in close contact. Additionally, the county health officer shall provide a copy of this order to the COVID Positive Person.

Gatherings are permitted for the provision of essential services when these services cannot otherwise be provided. Individuals gathering for such a situation must maintain 6 feet of distance from others and wear face gatherings. All other gatherings of those that are not in the same residence are prohibited. The county and cities within the county, through a collaboration with law enforcement, shall educate the community on the permitted and prohibited gatherings.

Places of worship are encouraged to continue offering virtual services. Indoor services are not permitted, and outdoor services must be limited to 100 individuals with a distance of 6 feet between individuals. Singing and group recitation is discouraged for in-person services, and face coverings must be worn when singing or group recitation occurs. Additionally, the guidelines from the prior ordinance regarding ritual objects, common cups, offering plates, and children's services are still in effect.
All county-owned and operated parks will be closed. Cities within the county are encouraged to close city-owned and operated parks.
Amendment to previous policy: singing and group recitation is not allowed at in-person services.

Update to the previous policy: The COVID Positive Person's medical provider shall determine whether the COVID Positive Person is immunocompromised, and whether the person has mild, moderate, severe, or critical illness or is asymptomatic. Requirements are detailed for providing COVID Positive Persons with copies of the appropriate health officer's orders. These individuals shall isolate at home and notify those with whom they have come into contact. COVID Positive Persons who are immunocompromised or who experienced severe or critical illness shall isolate for at least 20 days since the symptoms occurred, at least 24 hours since the last fever occurred, and the symptoms have improved. COVID Positive Persons who have a positive laboratory test and who are immunocompromised, but who do not exhibit symptoms, may discontinue isolation 20 days after their positive test if they do not develop symptoms.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Hotels/lodging; Manufacturers; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Public transportation; Retail stores (not including food); Non-governmental organizations; Public services; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Continuation of prior policy regarding practices for businesses that may reopen. Additionally, entities that offer curbside pickup and delivery shall not allow visitors inside of their buildings. Businesses are encouraged the implement and maintain teleworking practices. Businesses shall comply with the face covering guidance issued by the California Department of Public Health, and with the industry-specific guidance for each industry. Finally, indoor operations shall remain closed for nearly all public services, including fitness facilities and hair salons.

Bars, brewpubs, breweries, and pubs must close indoor and outdoor operations, unless these establishments offer sit-down, outdoor meals for dining on the entity's property. Alcohol can only be served when a meal is served.

Places of worship and providers of cultural or religious services shall still remain closed for indoor operations. Additionally, faith-based facilities are only considered "offices" for the individuals who use such a place as their regular place of work. Therefore, non-employees are not permitted to gather.
Indoor operations for all personal care services must remain closed. Additionally, tattooing, piercing, and electrolysis services shall remain closed.
Under the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1, concert venues, convention centers, festivals, live theaters, nightclubs, and theme parks shall remain closed.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Hotels/lodging; Manufacturers; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Public transportation; Retail stores (not including food); Non-governmental organizations; Public services; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Businesses and similar entities (nonprofits, government agencies) in the county shall remain closed, with the exception of essential critical infrastructure sectors and sectors designated by the state as critical to protecting health and well-being. Additionally, entities permitted to reopen as designated by the state's Blueprint for a Safer Economy - Tier 1 shall be subject to additional regulations set by the state and local entities, and as set forth in this order. Businesses and similar entities are encouraged to utilize telecommuting and other measures that minimize in-person contact.
Private gatherings are restricted to no more than 16 individuals. Additionally, activities such as singing, chanting, shouting are prohibited.

If the ICU bed capacity in the Southern California Region is below 15%, everyone in the county must abide by the state's Regional Stay at Home Order, which will supersede all other orders. When the regional Stay at Home Order is operative, it will remain in effect for 3 weeks at minimum, and until the four-week ICU bed capacity exceeds or is equal to 15%. The regional Stay at Home order requires that retailers can only operate indoors at 20% capacity or less, that gatherings with other households are prohibited, and that individuals must stay home except to operate critical infrastructure. When the regional Stay at Home Order is not in effect, residents and visitors to the county shall abide by the November orders of the health officer.

Inyo County Reopening: more businesses permitted to reopen 1. Restaurants – May open indoors at 25% capacity or 100 people, whichever is fewer, with modifications. 2. Personal Care Services – Nail Salons, Massage, Tattoo Parlors, Indoors with modifications 3. Gyms & Fitness Centers – Indoors with modifications, 10% of capacity, with modifications 4. Movie Theaters – Indoors with modifications, 25% of capacity or 100 people, whichever is fewer 5. All retail – Indoors with modifications, 50% capacity 6. Places of Worship – Indoors with modifications, 25% of capacity or 100 people, whichever is fewer INYO COUNTY 7. Hotels and Lodging – may open Fitness Centers at 10% of capacity 8. Museums, Zoos and Aquariums – Indoors with modifications, 25% of capacity 9. Malls, Destination Centers and Swap Meets – Indoors with modifications, 50% of capacity, common areas remain closed

Inyo county reopening guidelines (orange tier):  1. Restaurants: 50% capacity or 200 people 2. Bars: Open outdoors with modifications, indoor alcohol can be served with food following restaurant guidelines 3. Family Entertainment Centers (i.e. Bowling Alley): Open for naturally distanced activities with modifications 4. Gyms and Fitness Centers: 25% capacity with modifications, and indoor pools are allowed to open with modifications 5. Movie Theaters: 50% capacity or 200 people whichever is fewer, with modifications 6. All Retail: Increased capacity limit as long as modifications can be met 7. Hotels and Lodging: Fitness centers 25% capacity, and indoor pools open with modifications 8. Museums, Zoos and Aquariums – 50% capacity with modifications 9. Malls, Destination Centers and Swap Meets – Increased capacity limit as long as modifications can be met; common areas are still closed
In light of the COVID-19 pandemic, Inyo County restricts walk-in services at several public offices. Full closure was applied to all campground as well as all County library branches.

This order reinforces California's executive stay at home order N-33-20 by explicitly enforcing temporary closure of non-essential businesses.  Non-exhaustive list of businesses that will close in accordance with this order:  •	Gyms, health clubs, and other fitness facilities shall be closed. •	Pubs, bars, cocktail lounges, wineries, breweries, distilleries, tap rooms, and nightclubs shall be closed, except for venues that include meals provided by a full kitchen. Venues with a full kitchen shall adhere to restaurant guidance and provide only delivery or pickup options. •	Wineries, breweries, distilleries, and tap rooms that do not serve food or are not licensed to sell bottled or packaged alcohol for consumption off the licensed premises shall be closed. •	Movie theaters, live performance theaters, bowling alleys, gambling venues, hot springs, museums, arcades, and other attractions shall be closed. •	Restaurants shall be closed for seated dining, and should be open only to drive-through or other pick-up/delivery options.
All individuals who have been diagnosed with, or who are likely to have, COVID-19 must isolate themselves.

All household contacts, intimate partners, caregivers, and other individuals who have been in close contact with a person diagnosed with, or likely to have COVID-19, must quarantine themselves for 14-days.

All businesses operating during the COVID-19 must disallow any employee, agent, or contractor in the workplace if they are experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 and direct said employee to stay home and self-isolate as set forth in the Health Officer’s March 27th Order.

In support with Inyo Public Health Director, Dr. James Richardson, County Superintendent, Barry Simpson has ordered closure of all schools in Inyo County for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.   *The closure has been extended to 2020-2021 as all school transition to a distance learning model for this school year.

The fireworks shows in Bishop and Independence for 2020 will be modified to be “Stay at Home Shows”, meaning that no central viewing areas will be provided or available. Instead the public is encouraged to enjoy the 2020 fireworks shows with household members from their yards.

Inyo County Red Tier Assignment: restrictive measures  1. Restaurants – Reduced to 25% capacity or 100 people, whichever is fewer, with modifications 2. Bars – Closed. Bars serving food may operate and serve alcohol following restaurant guidelines 3. Personal Care Services – Open with Modifications 4. Family Entertainment Centers – Open for outdoor activities only with modifications; indoor activities (e.g. bowling alleys) are closed 5. Gyms and Fitness Centers –Reduced to 10% capacity with modifications 6. Movie Theaters –reduced to 25% capacity or 100 people whichever is fewer, with modifications 7. All Retail – Reduced to 50% indoor capacity 8. Places of Worship –Reduced to 25% capacity or 100 people, whichever is fewer, with modifications 9. Hotels and Lodging – Open with modifications; fitness centers reduced to 10% capacity, and indoor pools closed 10. Museums, Zoos and Aquariums – Reduced to 25% capacity with modifications 11. Malls, Destination Centers and Swap Meets – Reduced to 50% capacity with modifications, common areas closed and reduced capacity for food courts consistent with restaurant 12. Offices – Non-critical infrastructure offices moved to remote 13. Schools-remain open subject to local determination
The Health Officer Order issued effective April 2, 2020 at 12:00 a.m. is rescinded. The Health Officer Order amended and reissued on April 16, 2020 at 12:00 a.m. remains in effect.

All persons arriving in the country from international locations identified on the CDC Warning Level 2 or 3 Travel Advisory are subject to 14-day home quarantine and self-monitoring. Additionally, persons exhibiting mild to moderate symptoms of COVID-19 are to self isolate in their place of residence unless seeking medical treatment.
All businesses shall enact social distancing, increased sanitation standards, and shall make every effort to use telecommuting to its workforce.
All gyms and fitness centers shall be and shall remained closed.

All bars, wineries, breweries, pubs and other business establishments that serve alcohol and do not serve food shall remain closed. All restaurants and other business establishments that serve food shall close all on-site dining, though delivery and pick-up or drive-thru is permitted with social distancing.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: All persons who are 65 years old or older, have a chronic underlying condition, or have a compromised immune system should self-quarantine themselves at home or in their place of residence.

All public or private "gatherings" are prohibited. A "gathering" is considered any event that brings together people in a single room or single space at the same time (with the exclusion of essential public transportation, airport travel, shopping at the store, or charitable food pantries).

EMS personnel must wear respiratory protection for every EMS response. They also must institute a one-crew member "scout" procedure to determine the nature of the EMS contact and the appropriate level of PPE.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: All staff in health care facilities caring for suspected or confirmed COVID-19 patients must wear a respirator, eye protection, gloves and gowns. All staff in healthcare facilities must wear N95 respirators or higher level respirator while caring for suspected or confirmed COVID-19 patients when likely to engage in aerosol-generating procedures.

Kings County will launch a testing site in Hanford, CA. This new site is one of 80 testing sites powered through a partnership with OptumServe, the federal government health services business of Optum, a leading health services innovation company. Testing will be by appointment only through OptumServe directly. The County will release additional information when appointments become available.

The Kings County Health Officer has determined that the recent outbreak of COVID-19 cases related to employees of Central Valley Meat Company is currently the top priority for the testing center. Individuals that are currently or were recently employed at the Central Valley Meat facility in Hanford, as well as their family members, should register to be tested immediate

Testing through the State’s contracted OptumServe site is now be open to the general public. Testing is free for all individuals, including those who are uninsured or undocumented, and results are confidential. Testing is available Monday through Friday, 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM (Address: 1520 Kings County Dr. Hanford, CA 93230)

Starting the week of June 8, testing will be available in Hanford, Lemoore, Corcoran, Avenal, Kettleman City, and Stratford on a rotating basis throughout each week. The schedule will be posted on the County’s website at www.kingscovidinfo.com.

The testing site at 1520 Kings County Drive in Hanford will change its hours to Tuesday to Saturday, 7:00 AM to 7:00 PM, starting the week of August 18, 2020. The adjustment was made to accommodate Kings County residents that are unable to seek testing Monday through Friday.

Free mobile COVID-19 testing in Kings County will be provided starting Monday September 14.  The goal is to test as many essential workers and families as possible, to limit the spread of COVID-19 in these critical infrastructure workplaces and the surrounding community. Free COVID-19 scheduled tests and walk-ups will be accepted. Testing is available for adults and children ages 2 and above, Saturday – Thursday each week with hours adjusted depending on the location of the mobile site.

policy_subtarget: Public services; Public sector/government employees; Government/public buildings; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Many essential government services / offices in the county are directed to continue their services without changes in hours or lobby opening status, these include:  Public Safety, Road Repair/ Road Side Litter Requests
intended_duration: The County’s mitigation program will be reevaluated regularly and will continue until further notice

policy_subtarget: Public services; Public sector/government employees; Government/public buildings
policy_description: Many government services / offices in the county are directed to completely close and operate remotely, these include:   Administration Office & Natural Resources, Minors Advocacy, Behavioral Health & Recovery Services, Child Support Services, County Counsel, Elections, Finance Department and Property Tax Payments, 4-H Program, Human Resources, Human Services Agency, Libraries, Probation, Public Guardian/Veterans Services
intended_duration: The County’s mitigation program will be reevaluated regularly and will continue until further notice

policy_subtarget: Public services; Public sector/government employees; Government/public buildings
policy_description: Many government services / offices in the county are directed to operate with limited hours and staff (including offices by appointment only), these include:  Agricultural Commissioner’s Office, Assessor’s Office, Clerk-Recorder’s Office, Community Development Agency, District Attorney, Finance Department and Property Tax Payments, Fire Administration Office, Job Training Office, Law Library, Public Health, Public Works and Surveyors Office
intended_duration: The County’s mitigation program will be reevaluated regularly and will continue until further notice

policy_description: Signage shall be placed at each public entrance and throughout interior areas including customer service counters, elevators, lobbies, and employee work areas of County facilities to inform employees and the public.

During the Public Health Emergency, if an employee comes to work sick, is symptomatic, or has a medical diagnosis of COVID-19, the responsible manager must immediately send the employee home to Shelter in Place in order to manage the risk to other employees and to the public.
In the event an employee believes s/he has been exposed, s/he must quarantine up to 14 days and consult with his/her health care provider and follow medical advice.
County employees should be provided the option to wear gloves and of course, reminded of the need for frequent hand washing.
All non-essential travel, as defined by the Department Head, is canceled until further notice.

If a face to face meeting outside the office is required for an employee, they are to call ahead to determine if the individual(s) to be contacted are symptomatic or to determine whether they had been in contact with a person with confirmed COVID-19.
All County offices must supply Face Coverings, Disinfecting wipes or spray disinfectant and paper towels, Hand sanitizer, Gloves and Protective shields at customer service counters .
All in person meetings should be avoided when possible. Meetings should be conducted electronically.

In the event an employee believes s/he has been exposed, s/he must quarantine up to 14 days and consult with his/her health care provider and follow medical advice.
Most County offices will reopen on 06/01/2020 in addition to continuing remote accessibility to the offices.

Testing Notice must be updated and circulated at least once per month, and at least two days prior to when diagnostic testing will be next provided. Each Skilled Nursing Facility must publicly display an up-to-date Testing Notice at its main entrance and furnish a copy via email in response to an inquiry from any member of the public, media or government agencies.

All Skilled Nursing Facilities located within the City of Los Angeles must offer their residents, employees and contractors diagnostic testing for the COVID-19 virus, free of charge and administered by trained personnel at least once every month.

All Skilled Nursing Facilities must hand deliver written notice to all residents and workers at each facility listing the dates in which diagnostic testing had been previously offered and the date that testing will next be available at their facility  (“Testing Notice”).

All organizations that are subject to this Order must also comply with the April 24, 2020 Order of the Los Angeles County Public Health Officer regarding Prevention of COVID-19 Transmission in Licensed Congregate Health Care Facilities.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Non-Essential Businesses. Businesses regarded under this Order as “non-essential” may be permitted to conduct minimum basic operations including inventory, security, custodial services, payroll and employee benefits processing, and any reasonable activity designed to maximize the ability for its employees to work remotely from their homes.
All persons living within the City of Los Angeles are ordered to remain in their homes.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted retail business must implement the County’s Protocols for Retail Establishments Opening for In-person Shopping.
All persons living within the City of Los Angeles are ordered to remain in their homes.
The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted auto dealer must implement the County’s Car Dealership Protocols.

Owners, managers or operators of professional sports leagues, teams and facilities must adopt the County’s Protocol for Professional Sports Leagues and Facilities Opening for Training Sessions and Spectator-Free Events.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All outdoor shooting facilities must adopt the County’s Outdoor Shooting Facility Protocols.

The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted warehouse business, any permitted logistics business, or any permitted manufacturing business must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Warehousing, Manufacturing and Logistic Establishments.

The owner, manager or operator of Outdoor Museums, Open Air Galleries, Botanical Gardens and other Outdoor Exhibition Spaces must adopt the County’s Protocols for Opening for Outdoor Museums and Galleries.
All operators and participants of substance use disorder and mental health support groups must adopt the County’s Substance Use Disorder and Mental Health Support Groups Protocols.
The owner, manager, or operator of a place of worship or faith-based organization hosting in-person services must adopt the County’s Protocol for Places of Worship Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Non essential workers (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Studios, owners, managers, operators or participants in music, film or television production must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Music, Television and Film Production.
Owners, managers or operators of fitness facilities and gyms must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Gyms and Fitness Establishments.

policy_subtarget: Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Owners, managers or operators of businesses renting outdoor equipment for transportation or physical activity must adopt the County’s Protocols for Outdoor Equipment Rental Services.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to bike parks must adopt the County’s Bike Park Protocols.

The owner, manager, or operator of any business described in Paragraph 1 of the April 7, 2020 Worker Protection Order (Revised May 7, 2020), must prepare and post the County’s Social Distancing Protocol for each of their facilities within the City of Los Angeles.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to model airplane areas must adopt the County’s Model Airplane Protocols.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All visitors to beaches must adopt the County’s Beach Protocols.

policy_description: Non-Essential Businesses. Businesses regarded under this Order as “non-essential” may be permitted to conduct minimum basic operations including inventory, security, custodial services, payroll and employee benefits processing, and any reasonable activity designed to maximize the ability for its employees to work remotely from their homes.
The owner, manager or operator of hair salons and barbershops must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocols for Hair Salons and Barbershops.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to equestrian centers must adopt the County’s Equestrian Centers Protocols.

The operator of pools, hot tubs, and saunas that are in a multi-unit residence or part of a Homeowners’ Association must adopt the County’s Protocols for Reopening of Swimming Pools in Shared Residential Facilities.
Owners, managers or operators to campgrounds, TV parks and cabin rental units must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Campgrounds, RV parks and Cabin Rental Units.
The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted public and private golf courses must implement the County’s Golf Courses Protocols.
Owners, managers or operators of personal care establishments must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Personal Care Establishments.
The owner, manager, or operator of shopping centers or malls must adopt the County’s Shopping Center Operators Protocol.
The owner, manager or operator of small water vessel charters must adopt the County’s Protocols for Small Water Vessel Charters.
Owners, managers or operators of libraries must adopt the County’s Protocols for Libraries Opening for Curbside Pickup.
The owner, manager, or operator of a car wash must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Car Washes.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to community gardens must adopt the County’s Community Gardens Protocols.
The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted retail business must implement the County’s Protocols for Retail Establishments Opening for In-person Shopping.
Owners, managers or operators of hotels, lodging and short term rentals must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Hotels, Lodging and Short-Term Rentals.
All hosts and participants of vehicle-based parades or drive thru events must adopt the County’s Protocol for Vehicle Based Parades or Drive Thru Events.
The owner, manager, or operator of office-based businesses must adopt the County’s Office-Based Worksites Protocol.
Owners, managers or operators of museums, galleries, zoos and aquariums must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Museums, Galleries, Zoos, and Aquariums.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to tennis and pickleball courts must adopt the County’s Tennis Pickleball Courts Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: The owner, manager or operator of public swimming pools, including campground pools, club pools, commercial pools, health or fitness clubs, hotel pools, licensed day care facility pools, medical facility pools, mineral spring pools, motel pools, municipal pools, public or private school pools; recreational or mobile home park pools, resort pools, special purpose pools, and swim school pools must adopt the County’s Protocols for Reopening of Public Swimming Pools.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All hikers and visitors of trails  must adopt the County’s Trail Use Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Grocery store; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The owner, manager, or operator of any business engaged in Essential Activities shall prepare and post a Social Distancing Protocol for each of their facilities within the City of Los Angeles. All such businesses shall implement the Social Distancing Protocol and provide evidence of its implementation to any authority enforcing this Order upon demand.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Non-Essential Businesses. Businesses regarded under this Order as “non-essential” may be permitted to conduct minimum basic operations including inventory, security, custodial services, payroll and employee benefits processing, and any reasonable activity designed to maximize the ability for its employees to work remotely from their homes.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Grocery store; Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Retail stores (not including food); Hotels/lodging
policy_description: All employers of essential non-medical workers must implement social distancing measures for customers, visitors, and employees that provides a six-foot buffer, to the extent possible, between individuals.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Grocery store; Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Retail stores (not including food); Hotels/lodging
policy_description: Employers of all essential non-medical workers must permit their employees to wash their hands or use hand sanitizer at least every 30 minutes.

policy_subtarget: Grocery store; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Individuals and businesses that ship or deliver groceries, food, beverages or goods directly to residences or businesses, as well as taxis, ride sharing services, car rental companies, and other private transportation services must provide drivers non-medical grade face coverings and hand sanitizing agents, and do so at the expense of the business.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Grocery store; Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Retail stores (not including food); Hotels/lodging
policy_description: All employers of essential non-medical workers  must ensure that their employees have access to clean, sanitary restrooms, stocked with all necessary cleansing products; or sanitizing agents required to observe hand sanitation protocols recommended by the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health, provided at the employer’s expense.

The operator of pools, hot tubs, and saunas that are in a multi-unit residence or part of a Homeowners’ Association must adopt the County’s Protocols for Reopening of Swimming Pools in Shared Residential Facilities.
All operators and participants of substance use disorder and mental health support groups must adopt the County’s Substance Use Disorder and Mental Health Support Groups Protocols.
All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a residence are prohibited. This provision does not apply to gatherings within a single household or living unit.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: All businesses within the City of Los Angeles are ordered to cease operations that require in-person attendance by workers at a workplace. Indoor Malls and Shopping Centers can open to no more than 50% of overall shopping center capacity.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted public and private golf courses must implement the County’s Golf Courses Protocols.
The owner, manager, or operator of a place of worship or faith-based organization hosting in-person services must adopt the County’s Protocol for Places of Worship Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to bike parks must adopt the County’s Bike Park Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All visitors to tennis and pickleball courts must adopt the County’s Tennis Pickleball Courts Protocols.
All hosts and participants of vehicle-based parades or drive thru events must adopt the County’s Protocol for Vehicle Based Parades or Drive Thru Events.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to beaches must adopt the County’s Beach Protocols.

The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted warehouse business, any permitted logistics business, or any permitted manufacturing business must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Warehousing, Manufacturing and Logistic Establishments.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted retail business must implement the County’s Protocols for Retail Establishments Opening for In-person Shopping.
All persons living within the City of Los Angeles are ordered to remain in their homes.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All hikers and visitors of trails must adopt the County’s Trail Use Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to model airplane areas must adopt the County’s Model Airplane Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: The owner, manager, or operator of shopping centers or malls must adopt the County’s Shopping Center Operators Protocol.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted auto dealer must implement the County’s Car Dealership Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All outdoor shooting facilities must adopt the County’s Outdoor Shooting Facility Protocols.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to equestrian centers must adopt the County’s Equestrian Centers Protocols.

The owner, manager, or operator of any business described in Paragraph 1 of the April 7, 2020 Worker Protection Order (Revised May 7, 2020), must prepare and post the County’s Social Distancing Protocol for each of their facilities within the City of Los Angeles.
The owner, manager, or operator of a car wash must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Car Washes.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: The owner, manager or operator of Outdoor Museums, Open Air Galleries, Botanical Gardens and other Outdoor Exhibition Spaces must adopt the County’s Protocols for Opening for Outdoor Museums and Galleries.
The owner, manager, or operator of office-based businesses must adopt the County’s Office-Based Worksites Protocol.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All visitors to community gardens must adopt the County’s Community Gardens Protocols.

The owner, manager, or operator of office-based businesses must adopt the County’s Office-Based Worksites Protocol.

Owners, managers or operators of libraries must adopt the County’s Protocols for Libraries Opening for Curbside Pickup.
The owner, manager or operator of hair salons and barbershops must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocols for Hair Salons and Barbershops.
The owner, manager, or operator of any permitted auto dealer must implement the County’s Car Dealership Protocols.

Owners, managers or operators of satellite wagering facilities, and racetrack onsite wagering facilities must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Cardrooms, Satellite Wagering Facilities, and Racetrack Onsite Wagering Facilities.
Owners, managers or operators to campgrounds, TV parks and cabin rental units must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Campgrounds, RV parks and Cabin Rental Units.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: The owner, manager or operator of public swimming pools, including campground pools, club pools, commercial pools, health or fitness clubs, hotel pools, licensed day care facility pools, medical facility pools, mineral spring pools, motel pools, municipal pools, public or private school pools; recreational or mobile home park pools, resort pools, special purpose pools, and swim school pools must adopt the County’s Protocols for Reopening of Public Swimming Pools.
The owner, manager, or operator of a car wash must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Car Washes.

The owner, manager or operator of Outdoor Museums, Open Air Galleries, Botanical Gardens and other Outdoor Exhibition Spaces must adopt the County’s Protocols for Opening for Outdoor Museums and Galleries.

policy_description: All visitors to equestrian centers must adopt the County’s Equestrian Centers Protocols.

policy_description: Owners, managers or operators of businesses renting outdoor equipment for transportation or physical activity must adopt the County’s Protocols for Outdoor Equipment Rental Services.

The owner, manager, or operator of any business described in Paragraph 1 of the April 7, 2020 Worker Protection Order (Revised May 7, 2020), must prepare and post the County’s Social Distancing Protocol for each of their facilities within the City of Los Angeles.
All hosts and participants of vehicle-based parades or drive thru events must adopt the County’s Protocol for Vehicle Based Parades or Drive Thru Events.

Owners, managers or operators of professional sports leagues, teams and facilities must adopt the County’s Protocol for Professional Sports Leagues and Facilities Opening for Training Sessions and Spectator-Free Events.

Owners, managers or operators of hotels, lodging and short term rentals must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Hotels, Lodging and Short-Term Rentals.
Owners, managers or operators of personal care establishments must adopt the County’s Reopening Protocol for Personal Care Establishments.

policy_description: All visitors to beaches must adopt the County’s Beach Protocols.

policy_description: All visitors to bike parks must adopt the County’s Bike Park Protocols.

policy_description: All hikers and visitors of trails  must adopt the County’s Trail Use Protocols.

policy_description: All visitors to model airplane areas must adopt the County’s Model Airplane Protocols.
The owner, manager or operator of small water vessel charters must adopt the County’s Protocols for Small Water Vessel Charters.
The owner, manager, or operator of shopping centers or malls must adopt the County’s Shopping Center Operators Protocol.

The operator of pools, hot tubs, and saunas that are in a multi-unit residence or part of a Homeowners’ Association must adopt the County’s Protocols for Reopening of Swimming Pools in Shared Residential Facilities.
