(2) Social distancing of at least six feet is required between all protest participants from different households, living units or Stable Bubbles; (3) Facial coverings must be worn at all times, unless participants are unable to for health-related reasons or due to barriers to access;

All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring with members of multiple households or living units (including but not limited to professional, social and community purposes) in a shared or group experience in a single room, space or place are prohibited except for the limited purposes expressly permitted in this Order because they pose an especially high danger of transmission and spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: People at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 and people who are sick are ordered to stay in their residence to the extent possible except as necessary to seek medical care.
Skilled nursing facilities should follow State guidelines regarding visitation with their residents.

Per the Governor’s Resilience Roadmap, before reopening (and every two (2) weeks), all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must: (1) Perform a detailed risk assessment and implement a site-specific protection plan (which plan should be in writing and kept on site for easy reference for employees and presented to authorized County officials upon request); (2) train employees on how to limit the spread of COVID-19, including how to screen themselves for symptoms and stay home if they have them; (3) implement individual control measures and screenings; (4) implement disinfecting protocols; and (5) implement physical distancing guidelines.

Restaurants and other facilities that prepare and serve food, must close indoor operations, and may open but only for outdoor dining, delivery, drive through, or carry-out of meals and must follow the specific COVID-19 Industry Guidance: Restaurants providing outdoor dining, takeout, drive-through, and delivery (https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-outdoor-restaurants.pdf) which includes requirements for worksite specific COVID-19 prevention plan, comprehensive risk assessment of all work areas, employee training, individual control measures and screening, cleaning and disinfection protocols, and social distancing guidelines.
Wineries and tasting rooms must close indoor operations.

For purposes of this Order, “Social Distancing Requirements” include maintaining at least six feet of social distancing from other individuals, frequently washing hands with soap and water for at least twenty seconds as frequently as possible or using hand sanitizer that is recognized by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as effective in combatting COVID-19, covering coughs or sneezes (into the sleeve or elbow, not hands), regularly cleaning high-touch surfaces, not shaking hands, wearing a facial covering when out in public, to the extent required by the separate Health Officer Orders regarding Facial Coverings, and avoiding all social interactions outside the household when sick with a fever, cough, or other COVID-19 symptoms.
Clothing sold in businesses allowed to operate under this Order, shall not be sold in any manner which allows the customer to try on before a purchase is made.

Only businesses designated by the State Public Health Officer as Essential Workforce at (https://covid19.ca.gov/essentialworkforce/) and those businesses allowed to reopen statewide pursuant to the State Resilience Roadmap and for Variance Counties, subject to State COVID-19 Industry Guidances (See https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance; https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/), are permitted to operate, subject to the additional requirements outlined in this Order.

“Stable Bubble” means either a Stable Group of 6 individuals who form a Household Support Unit or a Stable Group of 12 individuals who form a Childcare Unit or a Children’s Extracurricular Activity Unit for the purposes of engaging in those activities allowed under this Order.

All businesses that are operating at facilities in the County visited or used by the public or personnel must, as a condition of such operation, follow the COVID-19 Industry Guidance identified statewide (https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance) and for Variance Counties (https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/); and prepare (or continue to maintain) and post a “Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol” for each of their facilities in the County, provided, however, that construction activities shall instead comply with the Construction Project Safety Protocols set for in Appendix B and not the Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol.

These personal care services may open with strict adherence to the COVID-19 Industry Guidance: Expanded Personal Care Services Provided Outdoors (https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-outdoor-personal-care--en.pdf), including, but not limited to the “Additional Considerations” for each particular field, as noted in the Guidance, and the following requirements: (1) Workers must wear a face covering throughout the entire interaction with the customer. Customers must face coverings at all times while in the facility, except when the face covering must be removed for the performance of services involving that part of the face. Facilities should provide clean face coverings for all staff and make them available to customers, if possible. (2) Personal care service businesses are required to take additional measures to protect the worker from exposure when working on a customer’s head, face, or mouth. These measures must be in addition to and not a substitute for the use of facial coverings. Such additional protective measures may include installing plexiglass or other physical barrier, or the wearing of face shields by the worker, i.e., a piece of rigid, clear plastic attached to a headband which covers the entire face extending from the forehead to below the chin. (3) Salons should not perform a service that would require a customer to have to enter the establishment.

To engage in religious services or cultural ceremonies at Places of Worship, which follow COVID-19 Industry Guidance: Places of Worship and Providers of Religious and Cultural Services, (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-places-of-worship.pdf), provided that participants wear facial coverings (pursuant to the Health Officer and Statewide Facial Covering Orders) and social distancing of at least six feet is required by all participants from different households, living units, or Stable Bubbles.

policy_description: In strict compliance with Statewide Public Health Officer Order Dimming Entire State effective July 13, 2020,(https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%20Dimming%20Entire%20State%207-13-2020.pdf), the Health Officer closes all indoor operations effective 11:59 p.m. on Friday, July 24, 2020, of the following types of businesses/events/activities (churches, gyms and fitness facilities, malls, personal care facilities, offices for non-critical infrastructure, funeral services)  except that such businesses/events/activities may conduct outdoor operations under a tent, canopy, or other sun shelter, (if no more than one side is closed), allowing sufficient air movement.

Government agencies and other entities operating shelters and other facilities that house or provide meals or other necessities of life for individuals experiencing homelessness must take appropriate steps to help ensure compliance with Social Distancing Requirements, including the adopting and posting of a Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol and adequate provision of hand sanitizer, soap and water, or other disinfectant.

Alcohol can be sold until 8:00 p.m., and only in the same transaction as a meal and when operating outdoors, bars, pubs, brewpubs, and breweries must follow the dine-in restaurant guidance (https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-dine-inrestaurants.pdf).

In strict compliance with Statewide Public Health Officer Order Dimming Entire State effective July 13, 2020 (https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%20Dimming%20Entire%20State%207-13-2020.pdf) both indoor and outdoor operations of bars, brewpubs, breweries, and pubs, must close statewide effective immediately, except that bars, pubs, brewpubs, and breweries, may operate outdoors if they are offering sit-down, outdoor, dine-in meals.

If a quarantined person becomes sick with fever, cough, or shortness of breath (even if their symptoms are very mild), they should seek medical care, and if indicated, seek coronavirus testing from their medical provider or County Public Health, and isolate themselves at home and away from other people and follow the “Home Isolation Instructions,” posted at https://www.mendocinocounty.org/community/novel-coronavirus/healthorder and attached to this Order.

Businesses which were authorized to operate under any Health Officer order prior to May 28, 2020 must complete the same steps and file the self-certification in order to continue operating.

Clothing sold in businesses allowed to operate under this Order, shall not be sold in any manner which allows the customer to try on before a purchase is made.

Isolated individuals must isolate themselves in a residence and follow all directions in this Order until they are no longer at risk for spreading COVID-19 based on the following criteria: 1. Individuals with a positive test who never develop symptoms must isolate for 10 days from date of test. OR 2. Individuals with symptoms consistent with COVID-19 must isolate until: a. At least 3 days (72 hours) have passed since recovery, defined as resolution of both fever without anti-pyretic (the use of fever-reducing medications) and improvement of cough, shortness of breath and other symptoms; AND b. At least 10 days have passed since the date of test; whichever is later. AND c. When released from isolation by individual’s health care provider and/or appropriate public health authority.
Skilled nursing facilities should follow State guidelines regarding visitation with their residents.

Quarantined individuals must carefully review and closely follow all requirements listed in the “Home Quarantine Instructions,” at https://www.mendocinocounty.org/community/novelcoronavirus/health-order.

Alcohol can be sold until 8:00 p.m., and only in the same transaction as a meal and when operating outdoors, bars, pubs, brewpubs, and breweries must follow the dine-in restaurant guidance (https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-dine-inrestaurants.pdf).
Each Permissible Higher Risk Business must prepare a Safe Business Reopening Plan which will be accessible to the public at https://www.mendocinocountybusiness.org/self-certified-businesses/.

These personal care services may open with strict adherence to the COVID-19 Industry Guidance: Expanded Personal Care Services Provided Outdoors (https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-outdoor-personal-care--en.pdf), including, but not limited to the “Additional Considerations” for each particular field, as noted in the Guidance, and the following requirements: (1) Workers must wear a face covering throughout the entire interaction with the customer. Customers must face coverings at all times while in the facility, except when the face covering must be removed for the performance of services involving that part of the face. Facilities should provide clean face coverings for all staff and make them available to customers, if possible. (2) Personal care service businesses are required to take additional measures to protect the worker from exposure when working on a customer’s head, face, or mouth. These measures must be in addition to and not a substitute for the use of facial coverings. Such additional protective measures may include installing plexiglass or other physical barrier, or the wearing of face shields by the worker, i.e., a piece of rigid, clear plastic attached to a headband which covers the entire face extending from the forehead to below the chin. (3) Salons should not perform a service that would require a customer to have to enter the establishment.
Family entertainment centers (for example: bowling alleys, miniature golf, batting cages and arcades), must close indoor operations.

In strict compliance with Statewide Public Health Officer Order Dimming Entire State effective July 13, 2020 (https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%20Dimming%20Entire%20State%207-13-2020.pdf) both indoor and outdoor operations of bars, brewpubs, breweries, and pubs, must close statewide effective immediately, except that bars, pubs, brewpubs, and breweries, may operate outdoors if they are offering sit-down, outdoor, dine-in meals.

Childcare and other programs providing care or supervision for children of all ages within Childcare Units or Children’s Extracurricular Activity Units (as defined in section 9.d.ii and iii) pursuant to the COVID-19 Updated Guidance: Child Care Programs and Providers (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-childcare.pdf), unless operating as a Day Camp and to that extent should follow the Guidance for the same (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-daycamps.pdf).
Zoos and museums must close indoor operations.

With the exception of unlicensed campgrounds (e.g., rentals of private land for tourist-based camping, glamping and RV travelers) and short term rentals of space within occupied units (e.g., occupied units with shared facilities) which are not permitted, all Transient lodging (defined as the provision of lodging services for a period of thirty (30) calendar days or less) and including Vacation Rentals (defined as the short-term rental of unoccupied single dwelling units, e.g., house, apartment, duplex, condominium, cottage, yurt, etc.), for tourism and individual travel, may open with strict adherence to the COVID-19 Industry Guidance for the same (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-hotels-lodgingrentals.pdf) and pursuant to further restrictions listed within the order.

Campgrounds operated by governmental entity (e.g., California State Parks) or privately owned campgrounds permitted pursuant to Mendocino County Code Chapter 20.176 or Chapter 20.468, as applicable and for camping with members of one household, living unit, or Household Support Unit (defined in Section 9.d.i) are allowed to operate with strict adherence to the COVID-19 Industry Guidance (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-campgrounds.pdf).
All individuals who have been diagnosed with or are likely to have COVID-19 must tell their close contacts that they need to quarantine themselves for 14 days after their last contact with them.

For purposes of this Order, “Social Distancing Requirements” include maintaining at least six feet of social distancing from other individuals, frequently washing hands with soap and water for at least twenty seconds as frequently as possible or using hand sanitizer that is recognized by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as effective in combatting COVID-19, covering coughs or sneezes (into the sleeve or elbow, not hands), regularly cleaning high-touch surfaces, not shaking hands, wearing a facial covering when out in public, to the extent required by the separate Health Officer Orders regarding Facial Coverings, and avoiding all social interactions outside the household when sick with a fever, cough, or other COVID-19 symptoms.

Government agencies and other entities operating shelters and other facilities that house or provide meals or other necessities of life for individuals experiencing homelessness must take appropriate steps to help ensure compliance with Social Distancing Requirements, including the adopting and posting of a Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol and adequate provision of hand sanitizer, soap and water, or other disinfectant.

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Retail stores (not including food); Churches/places of worship; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: In strict compliance with Statewide Public Health Officer Order Dimming Entire State effective July 13, 2020,(https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%20Dimming%20Entire%20State%207-13-2020.pdf), the Health Officer closes all indoor operations effective 11:59 p.m. on Friday, July 24, 2020, of the following types of businesses/events/activities (churches, gyms and fitness facilities, malls, personal care facilities, offices for non-critical infrastructure, funeral services)  except that such businesses/events/activities may conduct outdoor operations under a tent, canopy, or other sun shelter, (if no more than one side is closed), allowing sufficient air movement.
All individuals currently living within Mendocino County are ordered to shelter at their place of residence.

Any business providing food, whether in retail establishment or restaurant, may not allow the provision of food by self-service from the customer, including the handling of shared utensils by customers for self-service of bakery items, deli items, soups, salads, shared condiment dispensers, or other similar food items, which cannot be washed by the customer prior to consumption.

Only businesses designated by the State Public Health Officer as Essential Workforce at (https://covid19.ca.gov/essentialworkforce/) and those businesses allowed to reopen statewide pursuant to the State Resilience Roadmap and for Variance Counties, subject to State COVID-19 Industry Guidances (See https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance; https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/), are permitted to operate, subject to the additional requirements outlined in this Order.

To engage in political protest, pursuant to statewide guidance strongly recommending those exercising their right to engage in political expression utilize alternative channels, such as online and broadcasting platforms available in the digital age. In the event of any in-person political protest, participants must adhere to all of the following requirements: (1) Per Statewide Public Health Officer Order Dimming Entire State effective July 13, 2020, (https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID19/SHO%20Order%20Dimming%20Entire%20State%207-13-2020.pdf), the Health Officer closes all indoor protests effective 11:59 p.m. on Friday, July 24, 2020. For outdoor protests, there are no capacity limits by this Order. (2) Social distancing of at least six feet is required between all protest participants from different households, living units or Stable Bubbles; (3) Facial coverings must be worn at all times, unless participants are unable to for health-related reasons or due to barriers to access;

Campgrounds operated by governmental entity (e.g., California State Parks) or privately owned campgrounds permitted pursuant to Mendocino County Code Chapter 20.176 or Chapter 20.468, as applicable and for camping with members of one household, living unit, or Household Support Unit (defined in Section 9.d.i) are allowed to operate with strict adherence to the COVID-19 Industry Guidance (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-campgrounds.pdf).

Individual massage therapy provided that both therapist and patient are wearing a facial covering and the therapist, clinic, and/or business ensures only one massage occurs per room at a time and establishes frequent disinfection, including between each massage. Additionally, massage therapists should follow all applicable health and safety protocols found at https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/.
Family entertainment centers (for example: bowling alleys, miniature golf, batting cages and arcades), must close indoor operations.

When people need to leave their places of residence, they should at all times reasonably possible comply with Social Distancing Requirements as defined in Section 11, and are also required to wear facial coverings as provided in the Health Officer’s July 3, 2020 Face Covering Order (“Face Covering Order”) and the Statewide Guidance on the Use of Face Coverings issued June 18, 2020, which broadly requires the use of face coverings in California when in public or common spaces

Childcare and other programs providing care or supervision for children of all ages within Childcare Units or Children’s Extracurricular Activity Units (as defined in section 9.d.ii and iii) pursuant to the COVID-19 Updated Guidance: Child Care Programs and Providers (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-childcare.pdf), unless operating as a Day Camp and to that extent should follow the Guidance for the same (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-daycamps.pdf).

All businesses that are operating at facilities in the County visited or used by the public or personnel must, as a condition of such operation, follow the COVID-19 Industry Guidance identified statewide (https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance) and for Variance Counties (https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap-counties/); and prepare (or continue to maintain) and post a “Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol” for each of their facilities in the County, provided, however, that construction activities shall instead comply with the Construction Project Safety Protocols set for in Appendix B and not the Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol.

In strict compliance with Statewide Public Health Officer Order Dimming Entire State effective July 13, 2020 (https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%20Dimming%20Entire%20State%207-13-2020.pdf) both indoor and outdoor operations of bars, brewpubs, breweries, and pubs, must close statewide effective immediately, except that bars, pubs, brewpubs, and breweries, may operate outdoors if they are offering sit-down, outdoor, dine-in meals.
Skilled nursing facilities should follow State guidelines regarding visitation with their residents.
Clothing sold in businesses allowed to operate under this Order, shall not be sold in any manner which allows the customer to try on before a purchase is made.

Prior to re-opening all businesses must complete the self-certification form including any required attached Safe Business Reopening Plan (for Permissible Higher Risk Businesses and Campgrounds) which must include the details outlined in the applicable State of California COVID-19 Industry Guidances and any additional information as outlined for that industry in this Order. The self-certification form with required attachments must also be filed with the County, either through the website located at: https://www.mendocinocountybusiness.org, or by mailing a completed certification form (with any required attachments) to: County of Mendocino Environmental Health, 860 N. Bush Street, Ukiah, CA 95482. Businesses which were authorized to operate under any Health Officer order prior to May 28, 2020 must complete the same steps and file the self-certification in order to continue operating.

To engage in religious services or cultural ceremonies at Places of Worship, which follow COVID-19 Industry Guidance: Places of Worship and Providers of Religious and Cultural Services, (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-places-of-worship.pdf), provided that participants wear facial coverings (pursuant to the Health Officer and Statewide Facial Covering Orders) and social distancing of at least six feet is required by all participants from different households, living units, or Stable Bubbles.

All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring with members of multiple households or living units (including but not limited to professional, social and community purposes) in a shared or group experience in a single room, space or place are prohibited except for the limited purposes expressly permitted in this Order because they pose an especially high danger of transmission and spread of COVID-19

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Retail stores (not including food); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: In strict compliance with Statewide Public Health Officer Order Dimming Entire State effective July 13, 2020,(https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%20Dimming%20Entire%20State%207-13-2020.pdf), the Health Officer closes all indoor operations effective 11:59 p.m. on Friday, July 24, 2020, of the following types of businesses/events/activities (churches, gyms and fitness facilities, malls, personal care facilities, offices for non-critical infrastructure, funeral services)  except that such businesses/events/activities may conduct outdoor operations under a tent, canopy, or other sun shelter, (if no more than one side is closed), allowing sufficient air movement.

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: Chiropractic, Acupuncture and related therapy provided that both the doctor/clinician and patient are wearing a facial covering and the doctor/clinician, clinic, and/or business ensures only one appointment occurs per room at a time and establishes frequent disinfection, including between each appointment. Additionally, doctor, clinic, and/or business should follow all applicable health and safety protocols found at https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance/.

All recreational sites, including parks, playgrounds, beaches, and navigable waterways for recreational purposes may be opened for those outdoor activities allowed under this Order under this conditions that (1) the owner, operator and/or agency responsible for the recreation site has chosen to allow the recreation site to be open, and (2) the owner, operator and/or agency responsible for the recreation site has adopted a social distancing protocol for each such recreation area, which it has publicly posted at the recreational site.

“Stable Bubble” means either a Stable Group of 6 individuals who form a Household Support Unit or a Stable Group of 12 individuals who form a Childcare Unit or a Children’s Extracurricular Activity Unit for the purposes of engaging in those activities allowed under this Order.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: People at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 and people who are sick are ordered to stay in their residence to the extent possible except as necessary to seek medical care.
Wineries and tasting rooms must close indoor operations.

Alcohol can be sold until 8:00 p.m., and only in the same transaction as a meal and when operating outdoors, bars, pubs, brewpubs, and breweries must follow the dine-in restaurant guidance (https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-dine-inrestaurants.pdf).
Movie theaters must close indoor operations.
Zoos and museums must close indoor operations.
Each Permissible Higher Risk Business must prepare a Safe Business Reopening Plan which will be accessible to the public at https://www.mendocinocountybusiness.org/self-certified-businesses/.

Government agencies and other entities operating shelters and other facilities that house or provide meals or other necessities of life for individuals experiencing homelessness must take appropriate steps to help ensure compliance with Social Distancing Requirements, including the adopting and posting of a Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol and adequate provision of hand sanitizer, soap and water, or other disinfectant.

All outdoor gatherings specifically allowed pursuant by this Order (e.g., outdoor Place of Worship religious services or cultural ceremonies, outdoor funerals or memorials, and protests), are limited to a maximum of 50 persons.

Per the Governor’s Resilience Roadmap, before reopening (and every two (2) weeks), all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must: (1) Perform a detailed risk assessment and implement a site-specific protection plan (which plan should be in writing and kept on site for easy reference for employees and presented to authorized County officials upon request); (2) train employees on how to limit the spread of COVID-19, including how to screen themselves for symptoms and stay home if they have them; (3) implement individual control measures and screenings; (4) implement disinfecting protocols; and (5) implement physical distancing guidelines.

For purposes of this Order, “Social Distancing Requirements” include maintaining at least six feet of social distancing from other individuals, frequently washing hands with soap and water for at least twenty seconds as frequently as possible or using hand sanitizer that is recognized by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as effective in combatting COVID-19, covering coughs or sneezes (into the sleeve or elbow, not hands), regularly cleaning high-touch surfaces, not shaking hands, wearing a facial covering when out in public, to the extent required by the separate Health Officer Orders regarding Facial Coverings, and avoiding all social interactions outside the household when sick with a fever, cough, or other COVID-19 symptoms.

With the exception of unlicensed campgrounds (e.g., rentals of private land for tourist-based camping, glamping and RV travelers) and short term rentals of space within occupied units (e.g., occupied units with shared facilities) which are not permitted, all Transient lodging (defined as the provision of lodging services for a period of thirty (30) calendar days or less) and including Vacation Rentals (defined as the short-term rental of unoccupied single dwelling units, e.g., house, apartment, duplex, condominium, cottage, yurt, etc.), for tourism and individual travel, may open with strict adherence to the COVID-19 Industry Guidance for the same (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-hotels-lodgingrentals.pdf) and pursuant to further restrictions listed within the order.

These personal care services may open with strict adherence to the COVID-19 Industry Guidance: Expanded Personal Care Services Provided Outdoors (https://files.covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-outdoor-personal-care--en.pdf), including, but not limited to the “Additional Considerations” for each particular field, as noted in the Guidance, and the following requirements: (1) Workers must wear a face covering throughout the entire interaction with the customer. Customers must face coverings at all times while in the facility, except when the face covering must be removed for the performance of services involving that part of the face. Facilities should provide clean face coverings for all staff and make them available to customers, if possible. (2) Personal care service businesses are required to take additional measures to protect the worker from exposure when working on a customer’s head, face, or mouth. These measures must be in addition to and not a substitute for the use of facial coverings. Such additional protective measures may include installing plexiglass or other physical barrier, or the wearing of face shields by the worker, i.e., a piece of rigid, clear plastic attached to a headband which covers the entire face extending from the forehead to below the chin. (3) Salons should not perform a service that would require a customer to have to enter the establishment.
August 28, 2020 Stay at Home Order

Each school that opens for distance learning should develop a written COVID-19 Remote Learning Protocol addressing interactions between school staff and students, parents, or other members of the public. Protocol measures required to be addressed are outlined in the order.

All individuals living in Mendocino County are currently ordered to stay home at their place of residence except for permitted work, local shopping, or other permitted errands or activities which are identified in this Order and as set forth by the State Public Health Officer and State Shelter Order, including the State Stay Home Q&A.

For purposes of this Order, any business providing food, whether in retail establishment or restaurant, may not allow the provision of food by self-service from the customer, including the handling of shared utensils by customers for self-service of bakery items, deli items, soups, salads, shared condiment dispensers, or other similar food items, which cannot be washed by the customer prior to consumption.

For purposes of this Order, all recreational sites, including parks, playgrounds, beaches, and navigable waterways for recreational purposes may be opened for those outdoor activities allowed under this Order under this conditions that (1) the owner, operator and/or agency responsible for the recreation site has chosen to allow the recreation site to be open, and (2) the owner, operator and/or agency responsible for the recreation site has adopted a social distancing protocol for each such recreation area, which it has publicly posted at the recreational site.

All businesses must also post (prominently at entrance) additional County signage regarding required social distancing and use of facial coverings (in both English and Spanish), attached as Appendix A-2.

All businesses that are operating at facilities in the County visited or used by the public or personnel must, as a condition of such operation, follow the COVID-19 Industry Guidance identified statewide (https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance) and according to the Blueprint for a Safer Economy (https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/); and prepare (or continue to maintain) and post a “Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol” for each of their facilities in the County.

Government agencies and other entities operating shelters and other facilities that house or provide meals or other necessities of life for individuals experiencing homelessness must take appropriate steps to help ensure compliance with Social Distancing Requirements, including the adopting and posting of a Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol and adequate provision of hand sanitizer, soap and water, or other disinfectant.

“Work Group” means a Stable Group of 6 individuals over a four week period who engage in certain work-related activities, such as employment, volunteer activities, and the live-streaming or video recording of events.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All outdoor swimming pools in the County are allowed to open with strict adherence to the “Additional Considerations for Swimming Pools/Aquatic Venues” referenced in the Industry Guidance: Fitness Facilities (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-fitness.pdf) and as to Outdoor Recreation (https://covid19.ca.gov/pdf/guidance-campgrounds.pdf).

Before reopening and on a monthly basis all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must: train employees on how to limit the spread of COVID19, including how to screen themselves for symptoms and stay home if they have them

All individuals must strictly comply with Social Distancing Requirements, except to the limited extent necessary to provide care (including childcare, adult or senior care, care to individuals with special needs, and patient care); as necessary to carry out the work of for Essential Workforce as defined by the State at (https://covid19.ca.gov/essential-workforce/), Essential Governmental Functions, or for Minimum Basic Operations; or as otherwise expressly provided in this Order.

Before reopening and on a monthly basis all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must: (1) Perform a detailed risk assessment and implement a site-specific protection plan (which plan should be in writing and kept on site for easy reference for employees and presented to authorized County officials upon request)
Before reopening and on a monthly basis all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must: implement physical distancing guidelines

Individuals may engage in activities permitted by this Order within Stable Groups (Household Support Group/ Childcare Group/ Children’s Extracurricular Group) as described herein. Stable Groups are not required to engage in social distancing from each other when they are engaging in activities permitted under this order, but they should continue to comply with all other applicable requirements (i.e., staying home while sick, obeying quarantine and isolation orders, etc.).

Further, as a condition of operating under this Order, all businesses allowed to operate under this Order shall follow industry specific guidance issued by the State (https://covid19.ca.gov/industryguidance), any local industry specific guidance that may be developed in the County, and prepare or update, post, implement, and distribute to their personnel, a Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol as described in Section 8d. and attached Appendix A-1, at each of their facilities at which they are maintaining operations.

For gatherings which are permitted by the State, (e.g., faith-based services and cultural ceremonies), providers of such services and ceremonies must maintain a sign-in sheet for attendees of services and cultural ceremonies for at least 14 days after each such event for the limited purpose of facilitating COVID-19 case investigation and contact tracing. Sign-in sheets should include the name and contact information for attendees and should be shared with public health officials (only upon request) for the limited purpose of COVID-19 case investigation and contact tracing connected to the event.
For purposes of this Order, clothing sold in businesses allowed to operate under this Order, shall not be sold in any manner which allows the customer to try on before a purchase is made.
Before reopening and on a monthly basis all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must: implement individual control measures and screenings

Congregational areas in recreation sites, such as picnic tables, canopy areas, and playground equipment are closed, and must be designated as such before a recreational site is opened pursuant to a social distancing protocol.

All public and private gatherings of any number of people bringing together persons from multiple households, living units or Stable Groups, at the same time for a shared or group experience in a single room, space or place are prohibited (except for the limited purposes expressly permitted by State Orders) because they pose an especially high danger of transmission and spread of COVID-19.

Prior to re-opening all businesses must complete the self-certification form including any required attached Safe Business Reopening Plan which must include the details outlined in the applicable State of California COVID-19 Industry Guidances and any additional information as outlined for that industry in this Order.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: People at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 and people who are sick are ordered to stay in their residence to the extent possible except as necessary to seek medical care.
Before reopening and on a monthly basis all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must: implement disinfecting protocols

A business activity is allowed to open and operate in the County if the activity is in a sector that is open in the Tier of the State Blueprint for a Safer Economy (https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/) which applies to the County and the business activity conforms to the applicable State COVID-19 Industry Guidances (See https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance).

All operators of Transient Lodging (defined as the provision of lodging services for a period of thirty (30) calendar days or less) and Campgrounds must have an individual caretaker/manager available on-call 24 hours per day (and to be onsite within one hour) to monitor and adhere to COVID-19 Industry Guidance and for COVID-19 related issues.

All businesses that are operating at facilities in the County visited or used by the public or personnel must, as a condition of such operation, follow the COVID-19 Industry Guidance identified statewide (https://covid19.ca.gov/industry-guidance) and according to the Blueprint for a Safer Economy (https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/); and prepare (or continue to maintain) and post a “Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol” for each of their facilities in the County.

Before reopening and on a monthly basis all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must: train employees on how to limit the spread of COVID19, including how to screen themselves for symptoms and stay home if they have them

All businesses must also post (prominently at entrance) additional County signage regarding required social distancing and use of facial coverings (in both English and Spanish), attached as Appendix A-2.

Further, as a condition of operating under this Order, all businesses allowed to operate under this Order shall follow industry specific guidance issued by the State (https://covid19.ca.gov/industryguidance), any local industry specific guidance that may be developed in the County, and prepare or update, post, implement, and distribute to their personnel, a Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol as described in Section 8d. and attached Appendix A-1, at each of their facilities at which they are maintaining operations.
November 3, 2020 stay at home order

All operators of Transient Lodging (defined as the provision of lodging services for a period of thirty (30) calendar days or less) and Campgrounds must have an individual caretaker/manager available on-call 24 hours per day (and to be onsite within one hour) to monitor and adhere to COVID-19 Industry Guidance and for COVID-19 related issues.

Outdoor private gatherings of up to 3 households as referenced in the State Guidance for the Prevention of COVID-19 Transmission for Gatherings released on November 13, 2020, will be allowed in all tiers. However, the Health Officer requires such gatherings be limited to a maximum of 12 people.

Prior to re-opening all businesses must complete the self-certification form including any required attached Safe Business Reopening Plan which must include the details outlined in the applicable State of California COVID-19 Industry Guidances and any additional information as outlined for that industry in this Order.

policy_subtarget: Homeless shelters/homeless individuals; Public sector/government employees; Non-governmental organizations
policy_description: Government agencies and other entities operating shelters and other facilities that house or provide meals or other necessities of life for individuals experiencing homelessness must take appropriate steps to help ensure compliance with Social Distancing Requirements, including the adopting and posting of a Social Distancing and Hygiene Protocol and adequate provision of hand sanitizer, soap and water, or other disinfectant.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: People at high risk of severe illness from COVID19 and people who are sick are ordered to stay in their residence to the extent possible except as necessary to seek medical care.
Clothing sold in businesses allowed to operate under this Order, shall not be sold in any manner which allows the customer to try on before a purchase is made.

All individuals living in Mendocino County are currently ordered to stay home at their place of residence except for permitted work, local shopping, or other permitted errands or activities which are identified in this Order and as set forth by the State Public Health Officer and State Shelter Order, including the State Stay Home Q&A. (https://covid19.ca.gov/stay-home-except-for-essential-needs/)
Individuals may engage in activities permitted by this Order within Stable Groups (Household Support Group/ Childcare Group/ Children’s Extracurricular Group) as described herein.

All recreational sites, including parks, playgrounds, beaches, and navigable waterways for recreational purposes may be opened for those outdoor activities allowed under this Order under this conditions that (1) the owner, operator and/or agency responsible for the recreation site has chosen to allow the recreation site to be open, and (2) the owner, operator and/or agency responsible for the recreation site has adopted a social distancing protocol for each such recreation area, which it has publicly posted at the recreational site.

All public and private gatherings of any number of people bringing together persons from multiple households, living units or Stable Groups, at the same time for a shared or group experience in a single room, space or place are prohibited (except for the limited exceptions for faith-based services, cultural ceremonies, and protests expressly permitted by State Orders).

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Restaurants/bars; Essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Individuals may leave their residence to engage in activities, volunteer, perform work, and obtain healthcare services  pursuant to the Tier assigned to Mendocino County (https://covid19.ca.gov/safer-economy/), and designated by the State Public Health Officer as Essential Critical Infrastructure Workforce, (https://covid19.ca.gov/img/EssentialCriticalInfrastructureWorkers.pdf), or to otherwise carry out activities specifically permitted in this Order, including Minimum Basic Operations.

Any business providing food, whether in retail establishment or restaurant, may not allow the provision of food by self-service from the customer, including the handling of shared utensils by customers for self-service of bakery items, deli items, soups, salads, shared condiment dispensers, or other similar food items, which cannot be washed by the customer prior to consumption.
Implements isolation requirements for individuals diagnosed with or likely to have COVID-19.
Implements quarantine requirements for close contacts of persons with COVID-19.
All travel for urgent matters and to perform work and activities allowed by this Order is permitted.
All travel for urgent matters and to perform work and activities allowed by this Order is permitted. All travel must comply with the Social Distancing Requirements in Section 11 of this Order.
All travel for urgent matters and to perform work and activities allowed by this Order is permitted. All travel must comply with the Social Distancing Requirements in Section 11 of this Order.
All travel for urgent matters and to perform work and activities allowed by this Order is permitted. All travel must comply with the Social Distancing Requirements in Section 11 of this Order.
All travel for urgent matters and to perform work and activities allowed by this Order is permitted. All travel must comply with the Social Distancing Requirements in Section 11 of this Order.

Individuals may leave their residence to travel for urgent matters and to perform work and activities allowed by this Order is permitted. All travel must comply with the Social Distancing Requirements above. Additionally, all Transit agencies and people riding on public transit must comply with Social Distancing Requirements to the greatest extent feasible, and personnel and passengers must wear facial coverings as provided by the Face Covering Order, unless otherwise exempted by that order.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced directing health care providers to report patients seen with febrile respiratory illness to the Merced County Department of Public Health; directing patients to isolate for 7 days and notify all close contacts to quarantine for 14 days; directing employers to screen for febrile respiratory illness and exclude from work all employees who report symptoms; and directing individuals living within the County to self-monitor for signs of COVID-19 and appropriately isolate. Also residents are strongly encouraged to wear a cloth face covering and are requirement to maintain at least 6 feet of social distancing. The order also defines 'febrile respiratory illness', 'close contact', 'isolation', 'quarantine', and 'social distancing', as well as outlines the symptoms of COVID-19.

The Merced County Department of Health is directing that all patients being discharged from acute care facilities to long term care facilities must be tested for COVID-19 within 72 hours of discharge. Additionally, long term care facilities cannot deny receipt or transfer of a patient based on COVID-19 status.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced repeals and replaces all previous Stay at Home and Stay Safe Orders issued by the Health Officer of Merced County. Private gatherings of over 10 people are prohibited with the exception of places of worship outlined in the Merced County Department of Public Health's COVID-19 Worship Services Safe Distancing Rules. Its guidance for Businesses and Organizations follows State directives.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced repeals and replaces all previous Stay at Home Orders issued by the Health Officer of Merced County, except for the Febrile Respiratory Illness Order (April 7).  It outlines requirements and guidance for further reopening of business sectors and additional activities. It also provides specific guidance to places of worship, youth sports activities, and golf clubs.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced directing all individuals living in the county to continue to stay at home or at their place of residence except to provide or receive certain essential services or engage in certain essential activities and work for essential businesses. It also mandates that all businesses and governmental agencies must cease non-essential operations at their physical locations. It prohibits all non-essential gatherings of any number of individuals. It orders the cessation of all non-essential travel.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced supersedes the April 8 Stay at Home Order. It clarifies, strengthens, and extends terms of the prior Order to increase social distancing and reduce person-to-person contact.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced supersedes the April 17 Stay at Home Order. It clarifies, strengthens, and extends terms of the prior Order to increase social distancing and reduce person-to-person contact. It also includes specific guidance for Worship Services, Golf Clubs, and Funeral Services.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced repeals and replaces all previous Stay at Home Orders issued by the Health Officer of Merced County, except for the Febrile Respiratory Illness Order (April 7).  It allows eligible businesses to resume modified operations as long as they follow specific safety measures. It continues to limit activities in public areas and prohibits all non-essential gatherings.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced repeals and replaces all previous Stay at Home and Stay Safe Orders issued by the Health Officer of Merced County, except for the Febrile Respiratory Illness Order (April 7).  It mandates the closure of high risk business sectors.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Order of the Health Officer of the County of Merced repeals and replaces all previous Stay at Home and Stay Safe Orders issued by the Health Officer of Merced County, except for the Febrile Respiratory Illness Order (April 7).  It mandates the closure of bars, pubs, breweries, wineries etc. whether indoor or outdoor, indoor restaurant dining, indoor family entertainment centers and movie theaters, among other indoor entertainment facilities. The amended Order also requires youth sports and activities to be closed. It also provides specific guidance to places of worship and golf clubs.

Any person who has tested positive for COVID-19 must upon request of a Public Health Investigator provide the names and contact information of individuals they have been in contact with. Employers of COVID- positive persons must provide names of other employees. The information shall only be used for public health purposes.
All Restaurants must have at least 30% of their full time employees tested for COVID-19. Testing will be provided free of charge by Mono County
The May 28, 2020 order is rescinded and campgrounds and RV parks must now adhere to requirements set forth in the State of California's Campground Guidelines.

Lodgings shall restrict occupancy levels to 75% of capacity over a 7-day period and are encouraged (but not required) to maximize the number of rooms/units that are left vacant for a 24-hour period between occupancy.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Private sector; Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: All-non essential gatherings or assemblies, regardless of size, are prohibited and all venues shall be closed.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Non essential business (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: All bars, restaurants, health clubs and gyms shall close. Coffee shops may continue to offer pick-up service but provide no seating for customers.

Workers experiencing sickness must stay home and employers must screen workers daily for illness. Violation of the order is punishable by a fine of up to $1,000 and/or by imprisonment for up to 90 days.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Employers must screen employees for symptoms of COVID-19 and all employees presenting illness must remain home. Employees may return to work after a seven days from the beginning of illness if they also had no fever for the last 72 hours.

Business tax certificate for a lodging property may be revoked if the property is found to have been rented on a short-term basis in violation of orders from the Governor or the County Health Officer.

All persons with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 must isolate themselves from other persons, other than immediate caregivers, for a minimum of 10 days. Infected persons must also be free of symptoms for 72 hours before ending quarantine.
intended_duration: It will remain in effect indefinitely, until rescinded by the Mono County Health Officer

policy_description: All businesses resuming operations as part of the California's Resilience Roadmap must comply with guidelines issues by the Local Health Officer.

Because of the Tiger Bar's failure to safely operate in-person dining and bar activities, they must close. The owner of the bar may submit a worksite-specific operations plan to the Mono County Environmental Health Manager in order to reopen.

All staff of bars must wear face coverings at all times and alcohol may only be served to seated customers. Customers shall not be seated unless six feet of distance is maintained and there is an impermeable barrier between customers and staff behind the bar.

All Restaurants shall screen each employee at the beginning of their shift and the screening must be documented and preserved. Sick employees must be excluded from work until cleared by a license health professional.

Restaurants in violation of county guidelines shall immediately close for a period of 72 hours. A second violation shall close the restaurant for 5 days, and subsequent violations will close the restaurant for 7 days.
Stellar Brew shall be closed immediately to protect public health and safety. All employees shall undergo COVID-19 testing.
intended_duration: The establishment must stay closed until permitted to re-open by the County Health Officer or his designee

policy_description: Wedding ceremonies restricted to 30 persons. Wedding receptions of people from different households are not permitted.
Religious and cultural gatherings may only be held outdoors as long as the officer order remains in effect
Persons from different households may not gather regardless of size.

Short-term lodging facilities must ensure a 24-hour vacancy period between each occupancy and all bedding and linens shall be laundered. All kitchen supplies shall be washed between guests and cleaning staff shall have adequate personal protective equipment.

Hotels and condo/hotels occupancy levels shall be limited to 70% capacity and all beddings and linens shall be laundered between occupancies. Appropriate sanitation methods must be used and each unit must be vacant for 24 hours between each occupancy.
Pool areas are restricted by members of a single household and hot tubs, saunas, and other similar facilities are to remain closed. Indoor fitness centers remain closed.
The order directs all laboratories conducting COVID-19 test to report all COVID-19 test results to the local and state Health Departments (including positive, negative and inconclusive results).
intended_duration: Until it is rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the County Health Officer

policy_description: Monterey County will launch two testing sites in Salinas and Greenfield as part of a partnership between the State of California and OptumServe (a Federal government health services business).   Testing will be by appointment only.
Free pop-up drive through COVID-19 testing sites will be available at rotating Monterey County locations in October.

The last day of testing at the Greenfield location will be Saturday, October 17th from 8 am to 7 pm. Unfortunately, the site in Greenfield has not been well utilized in the last couple of months and will be relocated

Beginning, Tuesday, October 20th, free COVID-19 testing will be available in Seaside Tuesday through Saturday from 8 am to 8 pm.  The testing site will be at Seaside High School at 220 Noche Buena Street.
The Order now allows hair salons and barber shops to reopen with modifications and protective measures taken to reduce COVID-19 transmission risk
The revised order allows restaurants to begin dine in service with modifications to service and limited capacity.
This supplement to the county shelter in place order defers all business reopenings to California State guidance. At the point it was issued, it was to fully move into stage 2 reopening.
intended_duration: As long as the May 26, 2020 shelter in place order is in effect

policy_description: Charter boats may resume operations given they maintain social distancing on board.

The policy provides guidance on “social circles,” (stable groups of less than 12 people) intended to allow individuals to interact more with family and friends, and for children to participate in extracurricular activities.

policy_subtarget: Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Jail facilities closed to all visitors except bail bond agents and others with essential business
intended_duration: For the duration of the county's Shelter in Place Order

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Memorandum defining legal cannabis businesses as falling into either agricultural activities or healthcare operations. Therefore they are essential businesses and can remain open under the county Shelter in Place Order.
Residents of the county are instructed to continue sheltering at their place of residence
All county beaches will closed or have limited access for the Fourth of July holiday weekend in order to avoid anticipated crowds.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: This order establishes new reporting requirements of COVID testing which include the prompt reporting of all positive, negative, and inconclusive test results to the California department of public health.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: This order modifies the shelter at home order to include increased essential activities and business openings under state guidelines while maintaining specific social distancing protocols.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: This order rescinds the order of April 24, establishing specific public health measured in licensed health facilities and agencies.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: This order prohibits gatherings of over 50 people
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer or upon termination of the local health emergency related to COVID-19

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: This order establishes public health measures in licensed health facilities and agencies such as temperature screenings, was requirements, and the restriction of communal activities.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: This directive gives guidelines on how to effectively quarantine if diagnosed with or likely to have COVID-19.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: This directive requires all persons likely diagnosed with or likely to have COVID-19 to isolate under specific quarantine guidelines.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: Self-quarantine is necessary if an individual has had close contact with a person who has a positive lab test for COVID-19, signs and symptoms that are consistent with COVID-19 within 14-days of being in close contact with a person who had or was believed to have had COVID-19, or has been informed by a Physician that they are likely to have COVID-19.

Allows for drive-through, drive-in, or other open facilities for COVID-19 testing and related COVID-19 medical activities on privately owned land as an accessory facility and accessory activity to an existing medical activity that is located within one thousand (1,000) feet of the proposed activity and to which the applicant demonstrates, in writing, it has legal rights to such proposed uses.

Allows City of Oakland Property Asset Manager to enter license agreements with testing services for outdoor COVID-19 testing services on City-owned property. Testing on city property also requires approval from the Alameda County Public Health Department.

Termination of order allowing for medical establishments to to operate outdoor COVID-19 testing on private property as an accessory service. Such activity must now be authorized by City Planning Director.
Reopening of select nonessential business permitted under Alameda County Order issued June 18, 2020
City of Oakland residents are to follow Alameda County Shelter in Place Order issued March 16, 2020.
City of Oakland residents are to follow Governor Newsom's March 19, 2020 Executive Order requiring non-essential workers to stay at home.
City of Oakland residents are to follow updated Alameda County Shelter in Place Order issued March 31, 2020.
City of Oakland residents are to follow updated Alameda County Shelter in Place Order issued April 29, 2020.
City of Oakland residents are to follow updated Alameda County Shelter in Place Order issued May 18, 2020.
City of Oakland residents are to follow updated Alameda County Shelter in Place Order issued June 5, 2020.
Authorization for use of Anaheim Convention Center parking lot for drive thru COVID-19 testing.

The County announces the launch of a County COVID-19 Testing Network to offer testing to residents who are experiencing COVID-19 symptoms but are unable to receive testing through a healthcare provider.

The County of Orange announces a partnership with the University of California Irvine to participate in a rigorous, large-scale, population-based study to generate a more accurate estimate of the true prevalence of the pandemic in the County, through serological testing of 5,000 residents.
The Orange County Health Care Agency launches a multifaceted community outreach and advertising initiative aimed at the country's most vulnerable populations
In a private-public partnership, the county will be able to increase testing capacity with the opening of a large scale drive-through testing site.
A second large-scale drive through testing facility/supersite will open at the OC Fair & Event Center in Costa Mesa.
The City of Santa Ana announces free COVID-19 testing at parks, high schools and Santa Ana College for all Santa Ana residents that does not require insurance or COVID-19 symptoms.
The County is now offering at-home COVID-19 testing kits for residents.

Adopt Healthy Communities Resolution approving County of Orange commitment  that school districts able to safely open, provide in-person instruction to the greatest extent possible without further delay.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: The Orange County Board of Supervisors voted to reopen parking lots at all County regional and wilderness parks.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: The County reopened limited parking at County-operated beaches.
The lobby of the police department has reopened to the public with face covering and physical distancing requirements of visitors.

The County Health Agency requires graduation event organizers to develop a written plan addressing adherence to guidance for event organizers and attendees. The event hosts, security personnel and attendees must adhere to County Health Officer Orders issued on May 22, 2020.
Restaurants and retail businesses are authorized to expand dining and retail operations onto all sidewalks and on-street parking spaces on City roads.
Tennis courts can reopen with modifications.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Primary education; Higher education; Secondary education
policy_description: All businesses, industries, and entities listed on the State’s website  that reopen in Orange County as part of the various Stages of the State’s Resilience Roadmap shall post their corresponding industry-specific checklist at a location visible to the public at the public entrance of each property.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Primary education; Higher education; Secondary education
policy_description: All businesses and activities allowed to open must post a separate document at a location visible to the public at the public entrance of the property that specifically includes an attestation by the business or activity owner and/or operator that it has done all the following prior to reopening: performed a detailed risk assessment and created a worksite-specific protection plan; trained employees on how to limit the spread of COVID-19; set up individual control measures and screenings; put disinfection protocols in place; and established physical distancing guidelines in accordance with CDPH.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Primary education; Higher education; Secondary education; Casinos/gambling facilities; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Churches/places of worship; Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Housing sector; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Personal care facilities; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Manufacturers; Retail stores (not including food); Public transportation; Hotels/lodging
policy_description: All businesses and activities allowed to open must post a separate document at a location visible to the public at the public entrance of the property that specifically includes an attestation by the business or activity owner and/or operator that it has done all the following prior to reopening: performed a detailed risk assessment and created a worksite-specific protection plan; trained employees on how to limit the spread of COVID-19; set up individual control measures and screenings; put disinfection protocols in place; and established physical distancing guidelines in accordance with CDPH.

policy_description: All businesses, industries, and entities listed on the State’s website  that reopen in Orange County as part of the various Stages of the State’s Resilience Roadmap shall post their corresponding industry-specific checklist at a location visible to the public at the public entrance of each property.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Primary education; Higher education; Secondary education; Casinos/gambling facilities; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Churches/places of worship; Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Housing sector; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Personal care facilities; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Manufacturers; Retail stores (not including food); Public transportation; Hotels/lodging
policy_description: All businesses, industries, and entities listed on the State’s website  that reopen in Orange County as part of the various Stages of the State’s Resilience Roadmap shall post their corresponding industry-specific checklist at a location visible to the public at the public entrance of each property.

Bars, pubs, breweries, and brewpubs that offer sit-down, dine-in meals and bars, pubs, breweries and brewpubs that do not offer sit-down, dine-in meals themselves but contract with another vendor to provide that service, shall close their indoor operations but may continue their outdoor operation.

Food trucks are now allowed to use private parking lots and certain City owned parking lots for vending activities, and the requirement of a Land Use Certificate to operate in these such is suspended.

Additional businesses are authorized to operate outdoors including barbers, hair salons and expanded personal care services. Services that require touching a client's face (facials, waxing), esthetics, skin care, cosmetology, nail services and massage therapy may operate outdoors within the guidelines produced by the City for operating a business outdoors.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: City pool hours will expand.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Churches/places of worship; Hotels/lodging; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Restaurants/bars; Casinos/gambling facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Private sector
policy_description: Only those businesses and activities allowed to open under the tier assigned to Orange County may open, provided that such businesses and activities comply with all applicable restrictions for that tier. As of September 8, 2020, Orange County is assigned to the Red/Substantial/Tier 2.

The indoor operations of museums, gyms, dance studios, yoga studios, zoos and aquariums may not exceed their corresponding listed capacity for a tier or 100 individuals (including employees and other staff) whichever is less. Capacity is defined and determined by the applicable Building Code.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Churches/places of worship; Hotels/lodging; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Restaurants/bars; Casinos/gambling facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Private sector
policy_description: All businesses and activities allowed to open shall operate in accordance with their applicable industry guidance.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Churches/places of worship; Hotels/lodging; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Restaurants/bars; Casinos/gambling facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Private sector
policy_description: All businesses and activities allowed to open must post a separate document at a location visible to the public at the public entrance of the property that specifically includes an attestation by the business or activity owner and/or operator that it has done all the following prior to reopening: completely reviewed the industry guidance that applies to the business/activity; performed a detailed risk assessment and created a worksite-specific protection plan; trained employees on how to limit the spread of COVID-19; set up individual control measures and screenings; put disinfection protocols in place; established physical distancing guidelines; and established universal face covering requirements (with allowed exceptions) in accordance with CDPH.
Park playgrounds and fitness zones are open.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: To help mitigate the spread of COVID-19 in our community, indoor facilities and outdoor recreational spaces may be closed or have modified access until further notice. Outdoor park spaces remain open for passive use. Outdoor playgrounds, and athletic and recreational fields and courts, have reopened with modified access.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Public services; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Government/public buildings
policy_description: The City Senior Center will be closed, cancelling all classes and programs except for meals.
Gatherings of 50 persons or more will be suspended.
Libraries, community centers, recreational centers, police department headquarters and zoo will be closed to the public.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Homeless shelters/homeless individuals
policy_description: The County has identified a placement site for sheltered homeless persons who are older but not exhibiting any symptoms of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Parking lots and exercise zones at local parks are closed to prevent people from gathering.
Temporary ban on special event display permits.
Transportation in and out of the shelter has been limited to only verifiable appointments, in accordance with the state's "stay at home" order.
The City of Santa Ana is continuing to search for sites to expand housing options for homeless individuals and first responders needing quarantine or isolation.
The City of Santa Ana's Quality of Life Team (QOLT) and its contractor are conducting outreach to individuals experiencing homelessness, including daily health screenings for COVID-19 symptoms.
The City is canceling special events through July 31, including July 4th celebrations and the garage/yard sale weekend.
Persons that know they have been in close contact with a person diagnosed with or likely to have COVID-19 shall quarantine themselves in their home or another residence.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases
policy_description: Persons that have been diagnosed with COVID-19 or are likely to have COVID-19 shall immediately isolate themselves in their home or another residence.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases
policy_description: Residents and visitors who have been diagnosed with or are likely to have COVID-19 shall immediately isolate themselves in their home or another residence.
All bars, pubs, breweries and brewpub establishments that do not offer sit-down, dine-in meals shall close.
All County residents and visitors who know they have been in close contact with a person diagnosed with or likely to have COVID-19 shall quarantine themselves in their home or another residence.

Bars, pubs, breweries, and brewpubs that do not offer sit-down, dine-in meals themselves, but contract with another vendor to provide that service, may serve dine-in meals in their establishment if the dine-in vendor follows the dine-in restaurant guidance.

Venues that are currently authorized to provide sale of beer, wine, and spirits to be consumed off premises and do not offer sit-down, dine-in meals shall follow the guidance for retail operations and offer curbside sales only.
All bars, pubs, breweries and brewpubs can only offer alcohol with a sit-down, dine-in meal, and must follow the state dine-in restaurant guidance.
