All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to discontinue seating customers and/or groups at bar counters, sushi preparation bars, etc. where they cannot maintain at least six feet of distance. Physical barriers or partitions must be installed in areas where maintaining a physical distance of six feet is difficult.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure customers not stand in the restaurant, bar, winery, distillery or brewery except in the reception area while waiting for a table or to pick up take-out food. If customers cannot be socially distanced in the reception area they must wait in their cars or in a socially distanced line outside.

Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten ordered that until further notice the order that gyms and alcohol-serving businesses remain close.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten extended until further notice an order that schools at all levels (including higher education) must be closed.
Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten ordered that no gatherings take place until further notice, superseding an earlier order that limited gatherings to 10 people.

Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten extended indefinitely a 3/18 order that day care must be limited to groups of up to 10 children in the same room and they must remain in same group each day, with the same staff person

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten extended until further notice an order that no non-essential personnel nor essential personnel with COVID symptoms enter hospitals or assisted living facilities.

Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten extended until further notice an order that all businesses must observe social distancing, have employees work from home where possible, and suspend doctor verification for sick leave.
Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten extended until further notice an order that dine-in services close.
Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten ordered that individuals returning from international locations identified as CDC Warning Level 2 or 3 Travel Advisory be subject to a 14-day home quarantine.

Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten extended indefinitely a 3/23 order that, in order to enforce the county's distancing mandate and mass gathering restriction, government entities shut parks and beaches if they are not followed.

Suspected COVID-19 cases may not leave isolation until at least 3 days have passed since recovery from symptoms with out fever-reducing medications, received a negative FDA authorized COVID-19 test, or 10 days have passed without symptoms since a confirmed COVID-19 test.
People suspected of being COVID-19 positive must notify all persons that they have been in close contact with to quarantine themselves for 14 days from the point of contact.

All persons diagnosed, or likely to have COVID-19 must isolate in their home or another residence. They may not congregate with others even if they are living in a hotel or multi-unit setting. They may only leave for emergency medical service.

All persons who have had close contact with a COVID-19 patient must quarantine in their home or another residence. They may not congregate with others even if they are living in a hotel or multi-unit setting. They may only leave for emergency medical service.
All public or private gatherings are prohibited.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure the customers allowed at a table are limited to members of a single household or customers who have asked to be seated together at the time a table is requested.

All essential businesses that allow members of the public to enter a facility must prepare and post a “Social Distancing and Sanitation Protocol”. The protocol must be posted at or near the entrance of the relevant facility, and shall be easily viewable by the public and employees. A copy of the Social Distancing and Sanitation Protocol must also be provided to each employee performing work at the facility. All essential businesses shall implement the Social Distancing and Sanitation Protocol and provide evidence of its implementation to any authority enforcing this Order upon demand.

All persons arriving in the county from international locations identified on the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Warning Level 2 or 3 Travel Advisory must be subject to 14-day home quarantine and self-monitoring.
Self-serve food or drink options, such as buffets, salad bars, and drink stations are not allowed.
Dance floors will be closed and live performances such as musical or dance acts must be discontinued.

All reopened businesses, with the exception of restaurants, bars, wineries, distilleries and breweries which do not limit services to take-out or delivery, must prepare and post a “Safe Reopening Plan” and enforce it.
Shared entertainment items such as board games, arcade games and vending machines are prohibited and customers cannot have access to game and entertainment areas such as pool tables or darts.

Restaurants bars, wineries, distilleries and breweries which do not limit services to take-out or delivery, must prepare and post a “COVID-19 Restaurant Operating Protocol” for each restaurant in the county.
All public, charter and private schools may not hold classes on the school campus, and must conduct distance learning only as required by COVID-19.

Colleges and Universities cannot hold classes or other school activities where students gather on the school campus, except for research-related activities in colleges and universities and where necessary to train students who will serve as essential workers.
All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure the bar area of a restaurant may be used only for table service of meals.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: All businesses that do not meet the definitions of essential or reopened businesses must remain closed for the duration of this Order.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to discontinue seating customers and/or groups at bar counters, sushi preparation bars, etc. where they cannot maintain at least six feet of distance. Physical barriers or partitions must be installed in areas where maintaining a physical distance of six feet is difficult.

All persons must remain in their homes or at their place of residence, except for essential workers, customers of essential businesses, reopened businesses, essential activities, or to participate in individual or family outdoor activity.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Personal care facilities
policy_description: Non-essential personnel , are prohibited from entry into any hospital or long-term care facility. All essential personnel who are COVID-19 positive or show any potential signs or symptoms of COVID-19 are strictly prohibited from entry into hospitals or long-term care facilities, unless for treatment.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure discontinue open seating. All members of the party must be present before seating and the host must bring the entire party to the table at one time.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure alcoholic drinks only be served as part of a meal and are be sold and served in the same transaction as the meal. All meals shall be served by a food operator permitted by the San Diego County Department of Environmental Health. This restriction shall not be applicable to outdoor service of wine at a winery or spirits at a distillery.

A reopened business must include in its Safe Reopening Plan all of the industry guidance mandatory measures, including, but not limited to, all of the requirements and guidance set forth in the Statewide Public Health Officer Order, issued by the California Department of Health Services on July13, 2020.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure customers not stand in the restaurant, bar, winery, distillery or brewery except in the reception area while waiting for a table or to pick up take-out food. If customers cannot be socially distanced in the reception area they must wait in their cars or in a socially distanced line outside.
A person under quarantine may not come within 6 feet of any person, excluding a treating medical professional, law enforcement enforcing this Order, authorized personnel, or a caretaker.

Anyone who has had close contact with a COVID-19 patient must quarantine themselves in their residence for 14 days after the last contact with the patient. The person may leave their residence only to receive emergency medical care.

Restaurants bars, wineries, distilleries and breweries which do not limit services to take-out or delivery, must prepare and post a “COVID-19 Restaurant Operating Protocol” for each restaurant in the county.

All reopened businesses, with the exception of restaurants, bars, wineries, distilleries and breweries which do not limit services to take-out or delivery, must prepare and post a “Safe Reopening Plan” and enforce it.
All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure the bar area of a restaurant may be used only for table service of meals.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure the customers allowed at a table are limited to members of a single household or customers who have asked to be seated together at the time a table is requested.
Dance floors will be closed and live performances such as musical or dance acts must be discontinued.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure discontinue open seating. All members of the party must be present before seating and the host must bring the entire party to the table at one time.

All essential businesses that allow members of the public to enter a facility must prepare and post a “Social Distancing and Sanitation Protocol”. The protocol must be posted at or near the entrance of the relevant facility, and shall be easily viewable by the public and employees. A copy of the Social Distancing and Sanitation Protocol must also be provided to each employee performing work at the facility. All essential businesses shall implement the Social Distancing and Sanitation Protocol and provide evidence of its implementation to any authority enforcing this Order upon demand.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure alcoholic drinks only be served as part of a meal and are be sold and served in the same transaction as the meal. All meals shall be served by a food operator permitted by the San Diego County Department of Environmental Health. This restriction shall not be applicable to outdoor service of wine at a winery or spirits at a distillery.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure no food or beverages will be served to or consumed by a customer who is not seated at a table designated by the restaurant for dining.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to ensure customers not stand in the restaurant, bar, winery, distillery or brewery except in the reception area while waiting for a table or to pick up take-out food. If customers cannot be socially distanced in the reception area they must wait in their cars or in a socially distanced line outside.

All restaurants, bars, wineries and breweries are required to discontinue seating customers and/or groups at bar counters, sushi preparation bars, etc. where they cannot maintain at least six feet of distance. Physical barriers or partitions must be installed in areas where maintaining a physical distance of six feet is difficult.

A reopened business must include in its Safe Reopening Plan all of the industry guidance mandatory measures, including, but not limited to, all of the requirements and guidance set forth in the Statewide Public Health Officer Order, issued by the California Department of Health Services on July13, 2020.
Shared entertainment items such as board games, arcade games and vending machines are prohibited and customers cannot have access to game and entertainment areas such as pool tables or darts.
Self-serve food or drink options, such as buffets, salad bars, and drink stations are not allowed.

Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten ordered that, for any cruise ships docked in San Diego harbor, no one may disembark if anyone onboard has tested positive. All ships shall notify the Public Health Officer of any emergency medical treatment required onboard, and follow all Public Health Officer directives.
Public Health Officer Wilma Wooten ordered that no cruise ships dock locally except to receive fuel and provisions. No one may disembark.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: The Facility must immediately report (within one hour) all positive testing results of Residents and Personnel as well as any other confirmed COVID-19 diagnoses or positive tests of Residents or Personnel to DPH Communicable Disease Control, any Skilled Nursing Facility or General Acute Care Hospital, and the California Department of Public Health Licensing and Certification District Office.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Suspected cases
policy_description: No test is permitted to be conducted on a Resident if the test cannot be administered safely, as determined by a physician providing care to the Resident or DPH. In the event of a conflict regarding whether a test can be administered safely, the decision of DPH controls.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Confirmed cases
policy_description: The Facility must share a Resident’s Testing results with that Resident (including the Resident’s Authorized Decision Maker) and must share a Personnel member’s Testing results with the tested person, consistent with DPH Guidance and as otherwise required by law.

policy_subtarget: Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Confirmed cases
policy_description: Healthcare Facilities in the City must, as applicable, continue to comply with the reporting requirements regarding testing results set forth in Health Officer Order No. C19-10 or any subsequent Health Officer order, as well as any additional reporting required or requested by the Health Officer.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Suspected cases
policy_description: The Facility must promptly (within 24 hours) notify DPH to obtain assistance if a Facility Resident is unable to be tested, is unwilling to comply with the requirements of this Order, or lacks capacity to make health care decisions and the Resident’s Authorized Decision Maker declines to consent to the testing or other requirements of this Order.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Suspected cases
policy_description: The Facility must document Testing results and any refusal to test or to have third-party Testing results disclosed to the Facility for Facility Personnel in a secure and confidential manner, and the Facility must maintain the confidentiality of information about Testing results of Personnel and may only share such information as permitted or required by law.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: If a Resident has an Authorized Decision Maker who is currently making health care decisions for the Resident, including but not limited to a conservator, the Facility must ask the Authorized Decision Maker of that Resident for consent to perform the test and must notify the Authorized Decision Maker that the Resident is required by this Order to have the test.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Suspected cases
policy_description: All Residents living at, and all Personnel working at, a Facility must submit to Testing as required by DPH or by the Facility in Cooperation, and each Facility must follow the direction of DPH regarding Testing of Residents and Personnel.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: All Facility Personnel must submit to testing, as directed by the Facility in Cooperation with DPH or as directed by DPH.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: All Testing must be done using tests that are approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Confirmed cases
policy_description: The Facility must document the Testing results for each Resident in the Resident’s medical record (or other individual care record if there is no medical record) kept by the Facility. If a Resident is unable to be tested or the Authorized Decision Maker refuses to consent to testing, that must be documented.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The testing may be conducted by DPH, by the Facility, or by a third party, as directed by DPH.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The Facility must share information about Testing with DPH as requested by DPH at any time.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The Facility in coordination with DPH, or DPH independently, may require Testing of Facility Residents and Personnel on an ongoing basis, including repeat testing. Such testing may include a random sample of Residents and Personnel.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: This Order requires Residents and Personnel to comply with Facility infection control and other protocols based on the results of any test, including as directed by DPH, as outlined in DPH Guidance, or as outlined by CDPH or CDC guidance.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Confirmed cases
policy_description: Each Facility must immediately (within one hour) report to DPH any positive test result of a Resident.The Facility must also otherwise report all test results as required by law.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Any member of Facility’s Personnel who is directed by the Facility or DPH to have a test must permit the test to be performed in the manner directed. A Facility must not permit any member of its Personnel to come to work or otherwise enter the Facility’s premises if that person refuses to be tested, unless expressly permitted by DPH.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Suspected cases
policy_description: Each Facility must immediately (within one hour) report any positive test result of a member of the Facility’s Personnel. The Facility must also otherwise report all test results as required by law.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Essential workers (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: If a Hospital learns that any member of its personnel who is, or within the two weeks prior was, working at the Hospital tests positive for SARS-CoV-2, then the Hospital must follow all applicable reporting requirements. If the Hospital determines that the member of its personnel was the suspected or confirmed source of infection of any patient with SARS-CoV-2, then the Hospital must immediately (within 1 hour) notify DPH Communicable Disease Control.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Before the removal of any human remains from a place of death in the City, transport of human remains from any location in the City, or preparation of human remains for burial, cremation, or other final disposition, each Funeral-Related Service that is acting or operating in the City must either confirm that Antemortem Testing was performed prior to the person’s death or arrange for Postmortem Testing of the human remains or confirm that such testing occurred.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Each person who dies in the City on or after the effective date of this Order, this Order requires either that the person must have been subjected to Antemortem Testing or the human remains of that person must undergo Postmortem Testing  before the remains may be transported out of the City or prepared for final disposition by any Funeral-Related Service in the City.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: A Funeral-Related Service must not attempt to collect reimbursement of the cost of any Postmortem Testing from a deceased patient’s family, next of kin, or estate.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Each Healthcare Facility in the City must provide Diagnostic Testing to any symptomatic person,  regardless of age, hospitalization status, co-morbidities, or other risk factors for COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Each Healthcare Facility in the City must provide Diagnostic Testing to any person who is referred to their provider for Diagnostic Testing by DPH.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Healthcare Facilities that are providing care to the patient must provide the Diagnostic Testing either on the same day the patient presents for care or the following calendar day. In the event a patient presents for care via telehealth or other remote methods, the Healthcare Facility must conduct or otherwise cause to be provided a Diagnostic Test no later than the end of the calendar day following the remote visit.

Each Hospital must update and continue to implement the written plan that was originally required by the prior version of this Order (the “COVID-19 Plan”). The Hospital’s existing COVID-19 Plan may be used while a new version is prepared, and the COVID-19 Plan should be updated no later than June 1, 2020. The plan must comply with applicable guidance from the CDC, CDPH, and DPH.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The operators of all Businesses allowed to operate  must complete a Social Distancing Protocol checklist for each of their facilities in the County frequented by Personnel or members of the public. The Social Distancing Protocol checklist must be posted at or near each public entrance of each of the Business facilities and must be easily viewable by the public and Personnel.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Business that is required to comply with the Social Distancing Protocol is prohibited from taking any adverse action against any Personnel for staying home in the circumstances listed in the Social Distancing Protocol.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: As a condition of operating under this Order, the operators of all Businesses allowed to operate must comply with the requirements of the Social Distancing Protocol.
Group care facilities for children who are not yet in elementary school may operate subject to, and to the extent permitted by, the health and safety requirements

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Primary education
policy_description: A district superintendent, private school principal/head of school, or executive director of a charter school may apply for an advance written waiver by the Health Officer of this restriction to allow the school to open for in person instruction for grades TK-6.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: All Businesses allowed to operate under this Order must follow any industry or activity-specific guidance issued by the Health Officer related to COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Educational or recreational institutions or programs that provide care or supervision for school-aged children and youth may operate subject to, and to the extent permitted by, the City's health and safety requirements.
Institutions of higher education may operate subject to, and to the extent permitted by, the City's health and safety requirements.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Facility must Cooperate with DPH by promptly taking and responding to telephone calls, emails, and other inquiries and requests by representatives of DPH, permitting DPH personnel onsite without advance notice, and responding to all DPH requests for information in a timely manner.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The Facility must follow DPH direction or any individual Health Officer order to test specific Residents or Personnel, whether performing the tests itself or working with DPH or another testing provider to conduct the tests.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Facility must go to the DPH websites at least weekly to check for any update to DPH Guidance applicable to the Facility, including but not limited to the “SNF Interim Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) Prevention and Management Protocol” and any updates to that document.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Facility must Cooperate with DPH by maintaining a bed hold for any Facility Resident who is transferred to another location as a result of the current local health emergency and facilitating the safe return of that Resident at an appropriate time consistent with DPH Guidance or other DPH direction and accepting a safe transfer of a new Resident to the Facility as directed by DPH, with DPH being the final decision maker as to whether the transfer is safe.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Suspected cases
policy_description: No member of the Facility’s Personnel may come to work or otherwise enter the Facility’s premises after receiving a positive test result except as permitted by DPH Guidance. If a member of the Facility’s Personnel is awaiting a test result, that person may only come to work or otherwise enter the Facility’s premises as permitted by DPH Guidance.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Facility must Report any information, as reasonably necessary to protect public health and the safety and well-being of Facility Residents and Personnel, as directed by DPH regarding the Facility and its operation.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Facility must Cooperate with DPH by enacting policies or procedures required by DPH, communicating with Residents, Resident decision-makers and loved ones, and Personnel as directed by DPH. Also, they must assist with the assessment of Facility resources, procedures, and physical layout when requested, including by providing Personnel who can show DPH staff any areas or required information.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive); Suspected cases
policy_description: The member of the Facility’s Personnel who was tested must take all steps necessary to ensure the Facility receives the result within 48 hours if negative and within 8 hours if positive, whether by providing a written copy of the test result to the Facility or by signing a release permitting the testing lab or ordering provider to share the result directly with the Facility. The Facility must prohibit each Personnel member who was tested from returning to work until the Facility receives proof of the test’s outcome within the timeframe required.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The Facility must facilitate Testing and respond to Testing results as appropriate, including taking action based on the results of Testing, pursuant to the Facility’s infection control protocols, DPH Guidance, and CDPH and CDC guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Facility must Cooperate with DPH by disclosing to DPH staff protected health information and other medical information that relates to the subject matter and facilitating the safe transfer of any Resident to another Facility or other level of care based on the context as directed by DPH or the Facility’s regulatory. entity

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: The personnel of each Hospital must exclude from entry or access to its Premises any Visitors and Non-Essential Persons including, family members of patients and authorized decision-makers. The only people exempt from this order are those that must visit for "necessary visitation".

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Hospital’s COVID-19 Plan must include a requirement that any employee or other personnel who is sick or does not pass the required screening must be immediately sent home and not return to work until permitted to return to work under CDC, CDPH, and DPH guidance.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Each Hospital must continue to monitor and limit the presence of Non-Essential Persons other than Visitors on Hospital Premises. Such Non-Essential Persons are prohibited from Hospital Premises except as allowed by the Hospital under its COVID-19 Plan.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: If the patient or the Visitor has a current suspected or confirmed COVID-19 diagnosis or SARS-CoV-2 infection, then the Hospital may only permit General Visitation or Necessary Visitation if the visit can be done in a manner that protects the health and welfare of the patient, the Visitor, and Hospital personnel, as determined by the Hospital.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Hospitals must screen each Visitor before each visit in a manner consistent with current guidance from CDC, CDPH, and DPH regarding screening.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: To the maximum extent possible, each Hospital must discourage Non-Essential Patient Movement onto, off of, and within the Hospital’s Premises, where feasible.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: A hospital or facility must not attempt to collect reimbursement of the cost of any Postmortem Testing from a deceased patient’s family, next of kin, or estate.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Each hospital or facility must document the occurrence of Antemortem Testing or Postmortem Testing, whether through existing or new documentation, in the deceased patient’s medical record.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: In relation to deaths under the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner's jurisdiction, will transport the deceased person’s remains to its own facility and will either confirm that Antemortem Testing was performed prior to the person’s death or ensure that Postmortem Testing is conducted.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Each hospital or facility must report positive SARS-CoV-2 test results within 24 hours, to the Department of Public Health’s Communicable Disease Control. Unit

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Each hospital or facility must report to any postmortem care worker from a Funeral-Related Service or Medical Examiner who is responsible for retrieval of the deceased patient’s remains the most recent SARS-CoV-2 test result, when known.

People riding or waiting to ride on public transit must follow any applicable directives issued by the County Health Officer and any applicable “COVID-19 Industry Guidance” issued by the California Department of Public Health.

All individuals currently living within the County are for the time being ordered to stay in their place of Residence to the extent possible. Homeless individuals are exempt from this order, but are encouraged to find shelter.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Primary education
policy_description: Transitional kindergarten (TK)-12 schools may not open for in-person instruction and must conduct distance learning only.
All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a single Household are prohibited.

When people leave their place of Residence, they must strictly comply with the Social Distancing Requirements, including maintaining at least six feet of social distance from other people not in the same Household.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: If a Business or governmental entity has three or more Personnel who test positive for COVID-19 within a two-week period, then the Business or governmental entity is required to call the San Francisco Department of Public Health to report the cluster of cases. Businesses and governmental entities must also comply with all case investigation and contact tracing measures by the County, including providing any information requested.

Essential Businesses, Outdoor Businesses, and Additional Businesses are allowed to operate in the County under this Order. All other Businesses are temporarily required to cease all activities at facilities located within the County except Minimum Basic Operations.

If, despite the mass gathering prohibition, people find themselves with members of other Households, they are required to follow the health guidelines for safer interactions set forth in the Tip Sheet for Safer Interactions During COVID-19 Pandemic.
Transit agencies and people riding or waiting to ride on public transit must comply with Social Distancing Requirements

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: All Businesses must continue to maximize the number of Personnel who work remotely from their place of Residence.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Businesses are required to allow Personnel to stay home if they have symptoms associated with COVID-19, and Personnel are prohibited from coming to work if they are sick and may only return to work as outlined in the Social Distancing Protocol.
Businesses that include allowed operations alongside other operations that are not yet allowed must, to the extent feasible, scale down their operations to the allowed components only.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Businesses and governmental entities must require that all Personnel immediately alert the Business or governmental entity if they test positive for COVID-19 and were present in the workplace within the 48 hours before onset of symptoms or within 48 hours of the date on which they were tested.

All public and private golf courses may open for limited operations provided that the courses fully implement state mitigation protocols and post and implement a Social Distancing Protocol at each facility where food is served. Social distancing is also required.
All businesses allowed to operate in San Joaquin County shall implement the industry specific State Guidance. All businesses must prepare and post a “Social Distancing Protocol."
The State of California has issued an order than all personal care services must occur outdoors. However, electrology, tattooing, and piercing services must occur indoors for sanitation reasons.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Youth sports may continue in San Joaquin County if they comply with the state issued Interim Guidance (from Aug. 3). All activities must occur outdoors and maintain physical distancing. If the sport does not allow for distancing, only physical training may occur. Tournaments, events, and competitions may not occur. Adult amateur team sports may not occur.
All places of worship and providers of cultural ceremonies and religious services are permitted to open if they operate under the state's guidelines for mitigation.
Wineries and personal care services may open with mitigation measures.

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Retail stores (not including food); Grocery store; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: The State of California has issued an order that has permitted a number of sectors to operate with outdoor capacity and allows other sectors to reopen for indoor operations with limitations. These indoor-allowed sectors include: critical infrastructure, hair salons and barbershops, all retail (at 25% maximum capacity, grocery stores (at 50% maximum capacity), shopping centers (at a maximum 25% capacity), and professional sports (without live audiences).
All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a household or living unit are prohibited, except for the limited purposes as expressly permitted.

All individuals living in San Joaquin County have been ordered are ordered to stay at home or place of residence. To perform explicitly defined exempt activities, individuals must implement social distancing and hygiene practices.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: The State of California provided guidance for day camps, schools, and school-based programs on June 5, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county.

The State of California provided guidance for hotels, lodgings, and short term rentals on June 5, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county.

The State of California provided guidance for campgrounds, RV parks, and outdoor recreation on June 5, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county.

The State of California provided guidance for cardrooms, satellite wagering facilities, and racetracks on June 5, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county.
The State of California provided guidance for Gyms and Fitness Centers on June 5, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county.

The State of California provided guidance for restaurants, bars, and wineries on June 5, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county.
The State of California provided guidance for personal care services on June 12, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county.

This order reinforces the Governor's and California State Public Health Officer's order that counties on the County Monitoring List must conform to certain closure/adaptation standards. This means all breweries, bars, brewpubs, and pubs must close.

This order reinforces the Governor's and California State Public Health Officer's order that counties on the County Monitoring List must conform to certain closure/adaptation standards. This means that San Joaquin County's dine-in restaurants, wineries & tasting rooms, and cardrooms may operate only in outdoor capacities with social distancing and face coverings.

The State of California provided guidance for personal care services, hair salons, and barbershops on July 13, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county. These businesses are to cease indoor operations, but may operate outdoors with mitigation measures.

The State of California provided guidance for worship services and protests on July 13, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county. These businesses are to cease indoor operations, but may operate outdoors with mitigation measures.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The State of California provided guidance for offices for non-essential sectors on July 13, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county. These businesses are to cease indoor operations, but may operate outdoors with mitigation measures.

The State of California provided guidance for indoor malls on July 13, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county. These businesses are to cease indoor operations, but may operate outdoors with mitigation measures.

The State of California provided guidance for fitness centers on July 13, 2020, and the San Joaquin County Public Health Officer approved these guidelines for implementation in the county. These businesses are to cease indoor operations, but may operate outdoors with mitigation measures.

Brews, brewpubs, bars, and breweries in San Joaquin County must follow state guidelines (as of July 13). These businesses may continue to operate with an outdoor service of alcohol only if it is served with a full sit-down, dine-in meal.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: All K-12 educational institutions in San Joaquin County are ordered to remain closed until the county has been off of the state Monitoring List for 14 days or until the school has requested and been provided a waiver.
All K-12 educational institutions in San Joaquin County must only conduct distant/virtual learning until the county is off of the state monitoring list for 14 days or the school is provided a waiver.

Brews, brewpubs, bars, and breweries in San Joaquin County must follow state guidelines (as of Aug. 28). These businesses may continue to operate with an outdoor service of alcohol only if it is served with a full sit-down, dine-in meal.

The State of California issued an order that changed the regulations for private gatherings, and this policy implements those regulations in San Joaquin County. Gatherings must be held outside in a large space that allows for social distancing, may last no longer than 2 hours, and may include no more than 3 households. Face coverings must be worn, and symptomatic individuals may not attend.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Retail stores (not including food); Churches/places of worship; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Due to a rise in COVID-19 cases, San Joaquin County has moved to the more restrictive Purple/Widespread Tier. Many businesses must change their operations to outdoor only and reduce their capacities. However, personal care facilities may resume indoor operations, and any schools that were operating in-person may continue.
Travel is permitted for urgent matters or if such travel is essential to certain permitted work. Non-essential travel (vacations & pleasure) should be avoided.

The County Health Officers ordered that the county jail and juvenile hall order the ongoing testing of all inmates/detained youth suspected of having COVID-19 or suspected of being exposed to COVID-19.
The ban on visitors at nursing homes is rescinded.
The ban on visitors at hospitals and similar facilities is lifted; the ban on visitors at nursing homes is continued, except in limited circumstances (such as patients in end-of-life care).
All bars, breweries, and pubs must close for services during the Fourth of July weekend.

Clinical Laboratories in the County are ordered to accept assignments for COVID-19 Diagnostic Tests administered to individuals (1) who are referred for testing by the County Health Officer or designee, and (2) whose specimens are collected under Optum Serve/Logistics Health Inc. services, as contracted for by the State of California.

All laboratories conducting COVID-19 diagnostic tests are required to report COVID-19 test information, including positive, negative, and inconclusive test results, to Health Officer and the California Department of Public Health, and shall include age, sex, patient address and race/ethnicity data fields.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: A Person with COVID-19 must promptly tell their Close Contacts that they need to self-quarantine themselves and should be tested. Close Contacts who should be notified to self-quarantine are people who were in close physical proximity with them during their infectious period.  For purposes of this order, a “Close Contact” of a Person with COVID-19 includes any person who, during the infectious period of the Person with COVID-19: i. Lived in or stayed at the same residence as the Person with COVID-19 when the Person with COVID-19 was not following Home Isolation Instructions; OR ii. Was an intimate sexual partner of the Person with COVID-19; OR iii. Stayed within 6 feet of the Person with COVID-19 for 10 minutes or more while the Person with COVID-19 was not wearing a face covering; OR iv. Had direct contact for any amount of time with the body fluids and/or secretions of the Person with COVID-19 (e.g., was coughed or sneezed on, shared utensils with, or was provided care by or provided care for them without wearing a v. mask, gown, and gloves).

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: A person with COVID-19 must cooperate fully with Public Health concerning: i) collection, reporting and monitoring of temperature readings and other health data; ii) contact tracing and related investigations, including identification of contacts; and iii) any ongoing monitoring by Public Health, including after Period of Isolation.

All individuals who meet the definition of a close contact of an individual diagnosed with COVID-19 must immediately obtain a diagnostic test for COVID-19. Information on how to obtain diagnostic testing is available through a person’s primary health care provider, or by calling 211 for information concerning community-based testing. A Close Contact who tests positive for COVID-19 immediately becomes a Person with COVID-19 and is subject to the requirements of Health Officer Order c19-6b.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: If a Facility learns that any Facility resident, or Facility Staff living or working at the Facility, or who had been recently living or working at the Facility has tested positive for COVID-19 or is informed by a physician that any resident or Staff is presumed positive for COVID-19, residents and Staff of all Facilities shall also be subject to mandatory COVID-19 testing, and the imposition of such other measures to contain the spread of COVID-19 as deemed necessary for the protection of public health, by the San Mateo County Department of Public Health or its designee.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: For purposes of this Order, an individual, other than a minor child or person with special needs who requires specialized care, becomes a “Person with COVID-19” under this Order immediately upon meeting any of the following criteria: a. The person is informed they have a positive lab test for the COVID-19 virus; OR b. The person has signs and symptoms that are consistent with COVID-19, as set forth in guidance from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) at https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html, within 14 days of knowingly being in close proximity with another person who was known or suspected to be capable of actively transmitting COVID-19 and such symptoms are not explained by another condition that preexisted such close contact; OR c. The person has been informed by a healthcare provider that they are likely to have COVID-19; OR d. The person has signs and symptoms that are consistent with COVID-19 and is awaiting results of testing for COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The gathering must comply with general requirements of the jurisdiction where it occurs, including any permit program established by a jurisdiction. Jurisdictions that require a permitting process must be provided a copy of the Gathering Plan.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Vehicle-Based Gatherings must have a designated organizational host who is responsible for ensuring compliance with this Order and the Shelter in Place Order during the gathering. Only those personnel of the organization necessary to facilitate the gathering and to ensure compliance with this Order can be present.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: No sales or exchanges of any items or food is permitted during the gathering. As a limited exception, the Host may provide a significant item to one participant at a time, e.g. a diploma or other paper, while adhering to Social Distancing Requirements described in the Shelter in Place Order and the Face Covering Order. Any items or food and related refuse brought by occupants of a vehicle must remain in the vehicle.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The Host must develop and provide the local law enforcement, upon request, with a Highly Regulated Vehicle Based Gathering Plan. The Gathering Plan must be substantially in the form attached to this Order.  Ensure participants and Personnel adhere to the Face Covering Order and the Social Distancing Requirements as described in the Shelter in Place Order at all times.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Except as provided to use the bathroom, occupants of a vehicle may only exit the vehicle if and when the Host has specifically given express permission for a brief period of time. Such permission must be limited to one vehicle at a time. For clarity, occupants cannot use their time outside of the vehicle to interact with occupants of other vehicles.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The gathering must proceed by invitation only, with the limit tied to the capacity size of the location.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: If the Host of the gathering makes bathrooms available during the event, bathrooms must be disinfected by the Host or Personnel between uses. A Host, with the optional assistance of Personnel, must establish a line system that adheres to Social Distancing Requirements as described in the Shelter in Place Order and which is actively supervised by the Host or Personnel. No more than 10 people are allowed to wait in line at the same time. The Host must also make hand sanitizer or a hand washing station available to the users of the bathrooms.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The Host must, for gatherings of more than 10 vehicles, request security staffing provided by the local law enforcement agency with primary jurisdiction for the location of the event and pay reasonable costs as established by the Agency. If the Agency declines to provide such security, the Host is responsible for acquiring private security sufficient to ensure compliance with the Order and address any traffic and safety issues at its own cost. The amount of security necessary shall be determined by the entity providing security but should be no more than that deemed necessary to maintain safety and ensure compliance with the Order. For clarity, if the Host already employs security, it may use its existing security officers.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The gathering must take place in an outside location large enough to accommodate the distancing requirements of this Order and the Shelter in Place Order, e.g. a parking lot or similar space. Further, line spacing between vehicles must be sufficient to allow for emergency entry and exit. . The location must be such that it can ensure exclusion of those not invited, but this requirement can be achieved by security. If the location is not the property of the Host, the Host must provide the property owner of the location with the Gathering Plan and obtain written permission or agreement to utilize a location that specifically acknowledges receipt of the Gathering Plan.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The occupants of a vehicle must be members of the same household and shall not change vehicles during the gathering. Further, no more than the legal occupancy in the vehicle is allowed. Personnel and security are not considered occupants of a vehicle and may remain outside.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The Host must develop and provide the local law enforcement, upon request, with a Highly Regulated Vehicle Based Gathering Plan. The Gathering Plan must be substantially in the form attached to this Order.  Ensure participants and Personnel adhere to the Face Covering Order and the Social Distancing Requirements as described in the Shelter in Place Order at all times.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Each gathering is limited to no more than 200 vehicles and can be no longer than 3 hours.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All individuals currently living, working, or visiting within the County are ordered to continue to follow the Shelter in Place Order. In addition to the listed exemptions as defined in the Shelter in Place Order, individuals within the County may also engage in certain Highly Regulated Vehicle-Based Gatherings.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Homeless shelters/homeless individuals
policy_description: For purposes of this Order, a Person with COVID-19 who does not have access to a home or residence for the purpose of quarantine shall not be deemed in violation of this Order if, upon notification of the requirement to quarantine pursuant to this Order, such person promptly contacts the San Mateo County Emergency Operations Center Shelter & Care Branch by dialing 211at any time, day or night, to inform of their Close Contact status and request a quarantine location, cooperates fully with EOC staff, and is otherwise compliant with this Order.

policy_subtarget: Homeless shelters/homeless individuals; Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: A Person with COVID-19 who, at any time during their applicable Period of Isolation  does not have access to a home or residence for the purpose of isolation shall not be deemed in violation of this Order if, upon notification of a positive COVID-19 test, such person promptly contacts the San Mateo County Emergency Operations Center Shelter & Care Branch by dialing 211 at any time, day or night, to inform of their COVID-19 status and request an isolation location, cooperates fully with EOC staff, and is otherwise compliant with this Order.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Persons who have recovered from COVID-19 and/or have been released from isolation or quarantine may visit, and Facilities shall not require evidence of a negative test result prior to allowing such a visit.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Subject to strict compliance with this Order, including the specified Required Preconditions set forth, Subject to strict compliance with this Order, including the specified Required Preconditions set forth.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases; Hotels/lodging
policy_description: A Person with COVID-19 must immediately take the following actions: Isolate themselves in their home or another residence, such as a hotel or motel, for the entirety of the applicable Isolation Period. They may not leave their place of isolation or enter any other public or private place, except to receive necessary medical care or during an emergency that requires evacuation to protect the health and safety of the individual.

All individuals who have COVID-19  must isolate themselves and follow all instructions in this Order and the San Mateo County Public Health (“Public Health”) guidance documents referenced in this Order.

All individuals who are Close Contacts must quarantine themselves and follow all instructions in this Order and the San Mateo Public Health (“Public Health”) guidance documents referenced in this Order.

If a quarantined person becomes sick with fever, cough, or shortness of breath (even if their symptoms are very mild), they shall isolate themselves at home and away from other people and follow the “Home Isolation Instructions”.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: If a quarantined person is diagnosed with COVID-19, they are to follow the County of San Mateo Health Officer Isolation Order No. c19-6b (Revised), including “Home Isolation Instructions”. Exception: Notwithstanding the foregoing, health care workers and first responder agency workers who are household members, intimate partners, or caregivers of a person with COVID-19 are not subject to this Order under the following circumstances: a) the worker informs their employer that the worker is a close contact of a person with COVID-19; and b) the worker is asymptomatic, and the worker's employer determines, based on staffing needs, that the worker needs to report to work; and the worker returns to work.

Persons must self-quarantine under this Order if they are notified, become or are made aware that they have been in close physical proximity with a person who is a Person with COVID-19 during their infectious period, which begins 48 hours before symptoms began (or, in the absence of symptoms, on the collection date of a positive test) and ends when the Person with COVID-19 is released from Isolation. For purposes of this Order, a “Close Contact” of a Person with COVID-19 includes any person who, during the Person with COVID-19’s infectious period: a. Lived in or stayed at the same residence as the Person with COVID-19 when the Person with COVID-19 was not following Home Isolation Instructions; OR b. Was an intimate sexual partner of the Person with COVID-19; OR c. Stayed within 6 feet of the Person with COVID-19 for 10 minutes or more while the Person with COVID-19 was not wearing a face mask; OR d. Had direct contact for any amount of time with the body fluids and/or secretions of the Person with COVID-19 (e.g., was coughed or sneezed on, shared utensils with, or was provided care by or provided care for them without wearing a mask, gown, and gloves).

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: A person with COVID-19 is required for a Period of Isolation in accordance with the following: individuals without symptoms must isolate for ten days from the date of a positive test, individuals with symptoms must isolate until the later of the following:  i. At least three days (72 hours) have passed since recovery, defined as resolution of fever without the us of fever-reducing medications and improvement of respiratory symptoms, if present, AND  ii. At least ten days have passed since their symptoms started. Longer isolation periods may be recommended in certain circumstances.

All individuals who meet the definition of a close contact of an individual diagnosed with COVID-19 must carefully review and closely follow all requirements listed in the “Home Quarantine Instructions”

All individuals who meet the definition of a close contact of an individual diagnosed with COVID-19 must immediately take the following actions: Quarantine themselves in their home or another residence, such as a hotel or motel, for 14 days. They may not leave their place of quarantine or enter any other public or private place, except to access necessary medical care or during an emergency that requires evacuation to protect the health and safety of the individual, including but not limited to being tested for COVID-19, and must observe Social Distancing Requirements as set forth in the current Health Officer order directing all individuals to shelter in place, including maintaining at least 6 feet of distance from others, wearing a face covering, and frequently washing hands.

Participants of gatherings of any size must adhere to Social Distancing and Face Covering Requirements as set forth below in Sections, unless it is a small outdoor gathering of individuals belonging to the same Social Bubble

For the purposes of this Order, all businesses that are operating at locations in the County visited or used by the public or personnel must, as a condition of such operation, prepare, post, implement, and distribute to their personnel a written health and safety plan that addresses how it will comply with all applicable Statewide guidance issued by the State of California, which is hereby incorporated by reference and should be treated as if issued by the Health Officer and made mandatory to the extent applicable. If it is a service business that operates at customer homes, it must instead of posting at the home, send an electronic version of the plan to the customer at least one day in advance of the service being provided.

As a condition of operating under this Order, the operators of all businesses must prepare or update, post, implement, and distribute to their personnel a Social Distancing Protocol for each of their facilities in the County frequented by personnel or members of the public. In addition to the Social Distancing Protocol, all businesses allowed to operate under this Order must follow any industry-specific guidance issued by the Health Officer and the State of California related to COVID-19 and any conditions on operation  5 of 15 specified in this Order. Furthermore, businesses must prepare, post, implement, and distribute to their personnel a written health and safety plan as required by the State of California outlined in its guidance.

Accordingly, except to the extent that the State of California has adopted or adopts in the future a specific limitation or allowance on the size of gatherings, all public and private gatherings must not exceed 50 people.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Suspected cases
policy_description: When scheduling visits and again at the time of the visit, Facility shall inform visitors that they must cancel or postpone their visit if they are feeling unwell, and that any visitor who develops symptoms consistent with COVID-19 and/or is diagnosed with COVID-19 within two days of a visit must immediately alert the Facility and Facility shall immediately notify the Communicable Disease Unit of San Mateo County Health.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Limited Outdoor Visitation must be scheduled in advance with the Facility and  must take place in a designated outdoor space on or adjacent to the Facility premises, with sufficient room to allow for compliance with applicable State law and the  Social Distancing Order, appropriate protections from weather conditions, and otherwise made safe for Facility residents and their permissible visitors.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Facility shall provide hand sanitizer and Staff must supervise the appropriate use of hand hygiene, at the beginning and end of each visit, for all participants in Limited Outdoor Visitation.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: All visitors must remain at least six feet from the resident and attending staff member(s) at all times during the visit, i.e., no touching, hugging, sharing of food, drink or utensils is permitted.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: In order for a Facility to allow Limited Outdoor Visitation for its residents under this Order, it must first certify in writing to County Public Health that it meets the following Required Preconditions: i. Facility has adequate access to COVID-19 testing and has implemented (for Skilled Nursing Facilities) County Public Health’s “COVID-19 Mass Testing Strategy or (for all other licensed facilities subject to this order, County Public Health’s “COVID-19 Recommendations Checklist for LTCFs, RCFs and Congregate Settings” ii. Facility is not experiencing Staff shortages; iii. Facility has adequate supplies of PPE and essential cleaning supplies to care for its residents; iv. Facility has had no new positive COVID-19 cases in Staff or residents identified in at least two sequential rounds of surveillance testing.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: A Facility is prohibited from allowing Limited Outdoor Visitation for any time period of any duration in which it is not in compliance with the applicable Required Preconditions. If a Facility falls out of compliance with the applicable Required Preconditions, it must immediately discontinue any Limited Outdoor Visitation, including visits already scheduled, and notify County Public Health at smccdcontrol@smcgov.org within 24 hours of the reason for noncompliance with the Required Preconditions and the discontinuation of Limited Outdoor Visitation.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Facility must screen all visitors, including for Limited Outdoor Visitation and Necessary Indoor Visitation and Compassionate Care Visits, for symptoms associated with COVID-19 and take their temperatures.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: COVID-19 positive or presumed positive Facility residents shall not be eligible for Limited Outdoor Visitation or the Limited Exception for CCRCs during such time as they are infectious, and until they have recovered, following the protocols issued by County Public Health: COVID-19 Congregate Setting Admission, Readmission and Discontinuation of Transmission-Based Precautions Guidelines.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Administrative Staff of each Facility must  continue to exclude from entry or access to its premises any Unauthorized Visitors and Non-Essential Personnel including, but not limited to, visitors of residents at the Facility, except as expressly permitted under the Limited Outdoor Visitation exception and as permitted under the Limited Exception for CCRCs. Necessary Indoor Visitation (called Necessary Visitation or Contact under the Prior Order), shall expressly include Compassionate Care Visits.  By operation of this Order, Unauthorized Visitors and Non-Essential Personnel, including but not limited to family members of residents, are ordered not to visit any Facility except as expressly permitted by this Order.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: i. For Limited Outdoor Visitation, no more than two adults per visit, and one resident per visit, except that cohabitating residents may participate in the same visit together as if one resident. Visitors must be family members and/or designated support persons such as close friends and/or clergy/spiritual advisor (i.e., visits by hired service providers such as hair stylists, barbers, pet therapists, art therapists, etc. are not permitted) or a person whose visit is necessitated by urgent health or legal matters cannot wait until this Order is no longer in effect, including, but not limited to: visits mandated by law, and visits by legal decisionmakers such as conservators and agents under valid Health Care powers of attorney currently in effect.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Any exchange of documents or signatures necessitated by legal mandate should be done using appropriate infection control measures, e.g., electronic transmission and/or signature, maintaining six feet of distance. Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing in this Order shall be interpreted to impede or prevent the delivery of medically necessary care that requires direct contact with residents or proximity closer than six feet.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Facilities must keep a log of all visitors under this Order until instructed to destroy it. The Visitor Log should be maintained in a secure location when not in use, and maintained as confidential. The Visitor Log must contain the following information: i. Date and time of visit ii. Name/location of person being visited iii. Name, address and phone number of visitor

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Facilities shall be subject to San Mateo County Department of Public Health (“County Public Health”) mandatory testing, containment measures, and reporting requirements for COVID-19 positive and presumed COVID-19 positive residents and Facility Staff.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Facilities are required to implement and maintain a plan (“COVID-19 Plan”) to comply with applicable guidance from the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: For Limited Outdoor Visitation, the Facility must ensure that any resident being transported to and from outdoor visitation space is not transported through any space designated for COVID-19 care or where residents suspected or confirmed to be infected with COVID-19 are present. Likewise, visitors should not pass through any space designated as a COVID-19 care space or any space where residents suspected or confirmed to be infected with COVID19 are present.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Facility must ensure that each visit is supervised by Facility Staff, ideally an individual trained in patient safety/infection control, at all times throughout the duration of the visit. Notwithstanding the foregoing, during visits permitted under this Order that involve matters requiring confidentiality, such as with legal counsel, Facility Staff shall make best efforts to safely facilitate such confidentiality.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Suspected cases
policy_description: Any person with signs and symptoms suggestive of COVID-19, including fever equal to or greater than 100.4 F, chills, cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, sore throat, myalgia, malaise or fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, new onset of loss of taste or smell, conjunctivitis or pink eye, rash, painful purple or red lesions on the feet or swelling of the toes, and in accordance with guidance from the CDC  and the CDPH shall not be allowed to visit. Persons in isolation for COVID-19 or in quarantine for a potential exposure to COVID-19 are prohibited from visiting any Facility during the isolation or quarantine period.

The homeless shelter will follow CDC guidelines to stop the spread of COVID-19 by restructuring the shelter to accommodate social distancing, and utilizing trailers from the State of California as an additional resource.

This policy orders that the staff of hospitals and other types of licensed residential facilities should exclude entry or access of any visitors and non-essential personnel from the premises. Hospitals and residential facilities must make reasonable effort to facilitate contact by other means and may authorize necessary visitation on a case-by-case basis.

This policy orders the closure of brewpubs, breweries, bars, and pubs unless serving a sit-down meal in according with health and safety guidelines. These businesses are not allowed to open under the phased opening guidelines.
This policy orders the closure of all bars, breweries, pubs, and brewpubs unless serving meals, and this also orders the closure of indoor operations of specified industries and sectors.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: This policy orders closure of indoor operations for gyms, places of worship, protests, non-essential critical infrastructure, hair salons, malls, and others. These businesses may operate outdoors if they follow State guidance including face coverings and social distancing.

This policy orders that the staff of hospitals and other types of licensed residential facilities should exclude entry or access of any visitors and non-essential personnel from the premises. Hospitals and residential facilities must make reasonable effort to facilitate contact by other means and may authorize necessary visitation on a case-by-case basis.

policy_subtarget: Suspected cases; Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons
policy_description: This policy requires temperature screening and self-evaluation of all individuals entering critical infrastructure facilities such as the county jail and youth custodial facilities, the county emergency operations center, and the public health department operations center. This policy also prohibits entry of an individual if they have a temperature greater than 100 degrees F, or if the individual identifies symptoms through self-evaluation.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Suspected cases
policy_description: This policy requires temperature screening and self-evaluation of all individuals entering licensed facilities or other agencies such as hospitals, skilled nursing facilities, long term care facilities, home care organizations, etc.  This policy also prohibits entry of an individual if they have a temperature greater than 100 degrees F, or if the individual identifies symptoms through self-evaluation.
