policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: This policy orders the continued closure of indoor operations for gyms, places of worship, protests, non-essential critical infrastructure, hair salons, malls, and others. These businesses may operate outdoors if they follow State guidance including face coverings and social distancing.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: This policy prohibits "gatherings" large and small, unless an exemption applies. A "gathering" is any event or convening that brings together people from different households in a single space at the same time.

This policy orders that the staff of hospitals and other types of licensed residential facilities should exclude entry or access of any visitors and non-essential personnel from the premises. Hospitals and residential facilities must make reasonable effort to facilitate contact by other means and may authorize necessary visitation on a case-by-case basis.

This policy provides guidance on the reopening of some, but not all, businesses as defined within the Count of Santa Barbara. These businesses that are allowed to reopen myst comply with the requirements to protect against COVID-19.

This policy allows businesses to start a phased reopening upon completion of employee training, a detailed risk assessment and site-specific protection plan, face coverings, screening measures, and disinfection protocols.

This policy allows businesses to start a phased reopening upon completion of employee training, a detailed risk assessment and site-specific protection plan, face coverings, screening measures, and disinfection protocols.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: This policy orders the continued closure of indoor operations for gyms, places of worship, protests, non-essential critical infrastructure, hair salons, malls, and others. These businesses may operate outdoors if they follow State guidance including face coverings and social distancing. This policy also updates the State COVID-19 reopening framework and implemented a four-tier color coding system where the County of Santa Barbara is currently classified as Tier One (purple, the highest tier). Consistent with previous orders, some but not all businesses can reopen in the county of Santa Barbara, but additional businesses are allowed to reopen under this order.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: This policy allows the reopening of indoor operations for gyms, places of worship, protests, non-essential critical infrastructure, hair salons, malls, and others. These businesses may operate outdoors if they follow State guidance including face coverings and social distancing. This policy also updates the State COVID-19 reopening framework and implemented a four-tier color coding system where the County of Santa Barbara is currently classified as Tier Two (red, the second highest tier). Consistent with previous orders, some but not all businesses can reopen in the county of Santa Barbara, but additional businesses are allowed to reopen under this order. However, there is continued closure of breweries, bars, pubs, non-essential offices, etc.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: This policy allows the reopening of indoor operations for gyms, places of worship, protests, non-essential critical infrastructure, hair salons, malls, outdoor public playgrounds, higher education institutions, and others. This policy also updates the State COVID-19 reopening framework and implemented a four-tier color coding system where the County of Santa Barbara is currently classified as Tier Two (red, the second highest tier). Consistent with previous orders, some but not all businesses can reopen in the county of Santa Barbara, but additional businesses are allowed to reopen under this order. However, there is continued closure of breweries, bars, pubs, non-essential offices, etc.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: This policy allows the reopening of indoor operations for gyms, places of worship, protests, non-essential critical infrastructure, hair salons, malls, and others. These businesses may operate outdoors if they follow State guidance including face coverings and social distancing. This policy also updates the State COVID-19 reopening framework and implemented a four-tier color coding system where the County of Santa Barbara is currently classified as Tier Two (red, the second highest tier). Consistent with previous orders, some but not all businesses can reopen in the county of Santa Barbara, but additional businesses are allowed to reopen under this order. Wineries and tasting rooms are allowed to operate outdoors only per state guidance, unless they are providing sit-down, dine-in meals.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars

Wineries and tasting rooms are allowed to operate outdoors only per state guidance, unless they are providing sit-down, dine-in meals.
This policy orders the temporary closure of all public beaches in Santa Barbara County, specifically during the July 4th weekend.
This policy orders the temporary closure of all public beaches in Santa Barbara County, specifically during the July 4th weekend.
This policy orders the temporary closure of all public beaches in Santa Barbara County, specifically during Labor Day Weekend.

This policy orders that homeless shelters do daily symptomatic screening and operators should notify the Santa Barbara County Public Health Department if there is a case of laboratory-confirmed COVID-19. This order also recommends that Homeless Shelters provide housing in stable groups to pre-determine cohorts of residents who engage in activities together to reduce COVID-19 transmission.

This order also recommends that Homeless Shelters provide housing in stable groups to pre-determine cohorts of residents who engage in activities together to reduce COVID-19 transmission.

This order also recommends that Homeless Shelters provide housing in stable groups to pre-determine cohorts of residents who engage in activities together to reduce COVID-19 transmission.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: This policy prohibits small or large gatherings, Santa Barbara is in Tier One (widespread risk), so businesses are more restrictive that what was previously allowed in Tier Two. This health policy reduces capacity allowances for some businesses, and requires some businesses to operate outside.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: This order requires all Healthcare Facilities in the county to provide COVID-19 diagnostic testing to all symptomatic persons and those exposed to COVID-19 or who are thought to have increased exposure.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: This order mandates that healthcare workers receive an annual influenza vaccination or provide a proper signed declination by October 31.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer or upon termination of the local health emergency related to COVID-19

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); General population (inclusive)
policy_description: This order requires all Healthcare Facilities in the county to provide COVID-19 diagnostic testing to certain categories of patients according to new amendments which change which patients can receive testing, the timeframe that testing must be provided, and access of testing. .
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer or upon termination of the local health emergency related to COVID-19

policy_description: This update to the shelter in place order allows additional activities and businesses such as outdoor dining to reopen under new social distancing guidelines.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: This order allows most activities, travel, and businesses to function under specific social distancing restrictions and limitations in order to maintain risk reduction.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: This order establishes and maintains social distancing protocols and risk reduction measures across businesses and activities.
intended_duration: Until rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_description: The order directs all laboratories conducting COVID-19 test to report all COVID-19 test results to public health officials (via the calREDIE system) as well as the provider who requested the test. Results must be reported within 24 hours of receiving diagnostic test results (including positive, negative and inconclusive results).
intended_duration: Until rescinded, supersede, or amended in writing by the Health Officer

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Santa Cruz County is launching a testing site in Watsonville, initially focused on frontline health care workers, first responders and employees working in essential services and roles.   Testing is by appointment only. No walk-up or drive-through testing will occur at the site.

The Country and UCSC will increase to 600-800 tests per day. The $805,000 purchase of additional laboratory equipment for the UCSC Molecular Diagnostic Lab will help address increased transmission in the community, and make Santa Cruz County more self-sufficient in its response through increased testing capacity and more rapid diagnosis.

Retail businesses may begin providing curbside pick-up services to customers. These businesses include bookstores, clothing stores, florists, sporting goods stores and other over-the-counter retailers. Manufacturing and supply chain workplaces supporting these businesses may also reopen.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or amended in writing by the health officer

policy_description: CDPH accepted the County variance attestation meaning that dine-in restaurant services and barbershops/hair salons may reopen with modifications
County offices are reopening to provide services to county residents, although the hours differ by office

Visitors to county services will be asked to wear face coverings and maintain physical distancing, and stay home if they have been sick or have a fever. Medical screening may occur at some buildings. Residents should also expect limits on the number of persons in lobbies, protective screens at public counters, additional signage, and other measures to protect the health and safety of residents and staff.
The completion and posting of "Social Distancing Protocol" by all Essential Businesses and facilities providing Essential Governmental Functions is no longer mandatory (now voluntary)

Expanded personal services can reopen including  hair and nail salons, estheticians, skin care, cosmetology, electrology, microblading, waxing, body art, tattoo parlors, body piercing shops and massage therapy. Businesses and professionals should follow State guidance in order to minimize risk to clients and providers.
County Parks is canceling all programs, events, activities in facilities, and any rentals effective March 16 through March 30.
Social distancing requirements remain in place.
Beach restrictions remain in effect.

Those suspected to have COVID 19 are required to isolate. A person is presumptively infected with COVID-19 when: (a) They have a positive lab test for the coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) that causes COVID-19. (b) They have signs and symptoms that are consistent with COVID-19 within 14 days of being in close contact with a person who has or was believed to have had COVID-19; or (c) A medical clinician has informed the individual they are likely to have COVID-19.

All persons who have had close contact with a person presumptively infected with COVID-191 must self- quarantine for at least 14 days. A close contact is defined as any person who: (a) Has been within six feet of a person presumptively infected with COVID-19 during an infectious period; and (b) Has shared saliva (for example, by physical contact, by sneezing or coughing near them, or by sharing cups, plates, and utensils) with a person presumptively infected with COVID-19 during an infectious period.

Beaches throughout the unincorporated area will be closed some hours beginning Saturday, Sept. 5th at 5 a.m. through Monday, Sept. 7th at 5 p.m. However, beaches will remain open for public use on Saturday, Sept. 5, and Sunday, Sept. 6, between the hours of 4 p.m.-8 p.m. each day.  Beach crossings would be permissible to access the ocean for the purposes of activities such as surfing, paddle-boarding, boogie-boarding, swimming, snorkeling and kayaking.

Nursing home visits by non essential persons are now allowed if the following conditions are met: - there have been no new cases of COVID-19 among patients or staff in the past 14 days  - the facility is not experiencing staff shortages & had adequate supplies of PPE and cleaning supplies - the facility had adequate access to COVID testing and staff conducts symptom screening and temperature checks on all staff and visitors (and staff & visitors wear face coverings)
intended_duration: Until the March 4 declaration by the governor is rescinded (declaring a local health emergency)

policy_description: New requirement for laboratories to report COVID-19 test results, including negative or inconclusive results, to the ordering health care provider and appropriate state and local health officials

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Expanded drive-through testing for residents who are showing symptoms and are at a higher risk for developing severe COVID-19 disease; testing continues to be open for healthcare workers essential employees
Two state operated testing sites launched in Solano County that are open to everyone in the community including the homeless and undocumented individuals

Advises that businesses and employers should not require evidence of a negative COVID-19 test result for returning to work safely if individuals who have been ill isolate for 10 days after the onset of symptoms or 10 days after testing date if asymptomatic
Reminder for residents to observe religious holidays, including Holy Week and Easter, Passover, Orthodox Easter, Ramadan and other religious practices, from their homes

Ideally childcare should be provided in the child's home by non-elderly household members, but if this is not possible group childcare should be prioritized for essential employees and there should only be small groups of children together; symptoms of children and staff should consistently be monitored in group childcare settings

Allows for gatherings of people from different households so long as there is social distancing; community members must wear face coverings when necessary as outlined by the California Department of Public Health
Outlines low-risk activities families can participate in to celebrate Halloween and Dia de los Muertos, as well as detailing which activities are high-risk, including trick-or-treating
Draft of roadmap to reopening the county, similar to the State's Resiliency Roadmap, which outlines phases necessary to lift the shelter-at-home order
Amended stay at home order allowing low-risk businesses to reopen provided they follow social distancing guidelines

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Retail stores (not including food); Restaurants/bars
policy_description: California Department of Public Health approves the reopening of some low-risk businesses in Solano County including retail stores and dine-in restaurants so long as social distancing modifications are taking place

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector
policy_description: Low and medium-risk activities allowed to resume including movie theatres, satellite wagering facilities, racetracks and campgrounds

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Restaurants/bars; Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Churches/places of worship; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Solano County moved into Tier 2 according to the State; more local businesses can now resume indoor activities including indoor dining in restaurants, shopping centers, personal care services, movie theaters, gyms, museums and places of worship
Solano County Public Health supports California Governor Newsom's orders for social distancing and encourages vulnerable populations in particular to follow these guidelines

Announcement to follow State's order for closure of bars, brewpubs, breweries and pubs, and all indoor operations at dine-in restaurants, wineries and tasting rooms, family entertainment centers, indoor movie theatres, indoor zoos, museums and cardrooms in Solano County

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Personal care facilities; Non essential workers (inclusive); Private sector
policy_description: Shutdown of business sector indoor operations in Solano County following Governor Newsom's orders

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Everyone entering a congregate care facility should self screen for symptoms and agree to have their temperature checked. This also applies to EMS and first responders.

policy_subtarget: Public services; General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Addendum to April 28 Parks Closure Amended Order allowing additional recreational activities, which includes Bodega Bay coastal boat launch ramps and trailer parking areas.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Expands private sector reopening to restaurants and bars. Also allows summer camps and child care. School graduations, drive-in movies, and faith based drive-thru ceremonies can occur. Social distancing must be practiced at all times.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Public services; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Amends Park Order from May 12 to allow Coastal Zone Parks to reopen and expand parking at parks.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Churches/places of worship; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Restaurants/bars
policy_description: All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a single household or living unit are prohibited, except as allowed by this Order or by the State Orders and Guidance. Indoor gatherings, other than by household unit, are prohibited except as allowed by State or Local Orders e.g., restaurant dining, religious services, and childcare.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities; Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Allows campgrounds, gyms, fitness centers, movie theaters, nail salons, tattoo parlors, museums and galleries, and certain family entertainment businesses like mini golf to reopen.
Allows child care programs to participate in activities, recreation, or sports permitted under the state order and state guidance.
intended_duration: Until Order C19-15 is rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer or by the State Public Health Officer.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Notwithstanding any other provision of this Order, family and friends of residents in Long-Term Care Facilities may visit the resident as long as the facility and the visitor strictly comply with guidance issued by the Health Officer.
intended_duration: until Order C19-02 is rescinded, superseded, or amended in writing by the Health Officer or by the State Public Health Officer

policy_description: Unauthorized Visitors and Non-Essential Personnel, including but not limited to family members of residents, are ordered not to visit any Long-Term Care Facility except as permitted by this Order.
Household members, intimate partners, caregivers of a person with COVID-19, and those exposed to COVID-19 must quarantine themselves for 14 days since the exposure.
Group activities and community meals will be cancelled except in detention facilities, homeless shelters, and group homes for minors. Amends previous congregate care order.

Staff members of and visitors of congregate care facilities must practice physical distancing by remaining at least six feet apart from other persons unless caring for a resident. Amends the previous congregate care order.

All persons who have COVID-19 or are likely to have COVID-19 must immediately isolate themselves in a residence, review and follow all requirements listed in the Home Isolation Instructions, and tell their close contacts that they need to quarantine themselves.

Follows State Stay at Home Order which requires that all individuals stay home or at their place of residence, except for permitted work, local shopping or other permitted errands, or as otherwise authorized.
Extends social distancing requirements for individuals and businesses to maintain a six foot distance and follow distancing protocols.

Updates C19-12-I isolation order by changing the definition of the isolation period to at least 24 hours have passed since recovery, defined as resolution of both fever (100.0F or higher) without the use of fever reducing medication; and an improvement in symptoms; and at least 10 days have passed since their symptoms started.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons
policy_description: Residential group activities and communal dining shall be discontinued at facilities listed in Attachment A. Facilities listed in Attachment B (except detention facilities and group homes for minors) must discontinue group activities. Other facilities listed in Attachment B may allow communal dining as long as the facility complies with state guidance.
Staff members of and visitors to congregate care facilities shall practice physical distancing by remaining at least six feet apart from other persons unless caring for a resident.

Sonoma County Health Officer implements the restrictions on businesses and activities set forth in the December 3, 2020, Regional Stay at Home Order and the December 6, 2020 Supplement to Regional Stay at Home Order issued by the California Department of Public Health.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Hotels/lodging; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Hotels, short-term rentals and campgrounds can now open to recreational travel. Recommends that individuals avoid travelling long distances for vacations or pleasure as much as possible. Individual shall not travel if they are sick, with someone who is sick, or if someone in their household or living unit had coronavirus in the last two weeks.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Each Long-Term Care Facility shall discourage Non-Essential Resident Movement, as defined in Section 11 below, onto and off Long-Term Care Facility Premises where feasible.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: EMS personnel and visitors must self-screen for COVID-19 symptoms and have their temperature checked before entering nursing homes and care facilities.
People entering all food and beverage facilities should be screened for COVID-19 symptoms. Temperature screening is highly recommended.
Rescinds orders from March, April, and May that directed all individuals to shelter in place.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Suspected cases; Confirmed cases
policy_description: All household contacts, intimate partners, caregivers, and close contacts who have been in close contact with a person diagnosed with or likely to have COVID-19, as defined in this Order, must quarantine themselves.

Amends previous isolation order stating that all individuals who have been diagnosed with or are likely to have COVID-19 must immediately isolate themselves in their home or another residence until: (a) at least 10 days since symptoms first appeared, AND (b), at least 3 days (72 hours) have passed since recovery.
Requires that food and beverage manufacturing facilities take social distancing measures, such as symptom screening, face coverings, and physical distancing during work.

Indoor operations of restaurants, wineries, movie theaters, family entertainment centers, museums, zoos, aquariums, and cardrooms must be closed. Breweries, bars, and pubs must close indoor and outdoor operations.
Household contacts, intimate partners, caregivers, and close contacts of a person diagnosed with COVID-19 or presenting COVID-19 symptoms must quarantine at home for 14 days.
Individuals who have COVID-19 or are likely to have COVID-19 must self-isolate in a residence for at least 10 days after having symptoms and one day after recovery.

Amends previous quarantine order: Household contacts, intimate partners, caregivers, and close contacts of a person diagnosed with COVID-19 or presenting COVID-19 symptoms must quarantine at home for 10 days.

Amends previous isolation order stating that all individuals who have been diagnosed with or are likely to have COVID-19 must immediately isolate themselves in their home or another residence until: (a) at least 10 days since symptoms first appeared, AND (b), at least 1 days (24 hours) have passed since recovery.

In the event of a positive COVID-19 case identified in an attendee at a faith-based gathering, it is crucial that prompt identification of all exposed individuals is done by public health. It is strongly advised that all faith-based organizations maintain a list of their congregants including names and contact information so that this information can be quickly provided to the Yuba-Sutter Public Health Department.

Individuals should follow non-pharmacologic interventions (NPIs) to the greatest extent possible, including but not limited to maintaining social distancing of six feet or more from another person not part of their household, good hand hygiene, staying home when having symptoms concerning for COVID-19, and wearing facial coverings whenever social distancing is not feasible.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Gyms and fitness facilities shall implement special hours for those age 65 years and older or with chronic medical issues to ensure that they can exercise in a safe manner and minimize their risk of exposure and infection to COVID-19.

The industry guidance of bars applies to bars, brewpubs, craft distilleries, breweries, bars, pubs, and wineries. All staff and employees are required to wear facial coverings when at work. Customers must also wear facial coverings when not drinking or eating and social distancing between non-household members is not possible. Seating at the same table should be limited to members of the same household only. It is strongly recommended that capacity be reduced as much as possible to allow for adequate social distancing and limit congregating at high traffic areas including the entrances, exits, and bathrooms. Orders should be taken at the table instead of at the bar. Outdoor seating is highly encouraged due to the better ventilation over indoor settings.

Given the concern of out-of-county travel, each hotel must implement a robust system to confirm with each guest prior to their arrival that they are without symptoms concerning for COVID-19, and have not been informed by any public health department in the past 14 days that they have been exposed to a COVID-19 case.
If facial coverings cannot be safely worn during workouts, then social distancing of at least six feet or more should be strictly adhered to between non-household members.

All indoor services must be closed for the following sectors: dine-in restaurants, wineries and tasting rooms, family entertainment centers and movie theaters, indoor attractions at zoos and museums, cardrooms. These sectors may continue to operate outdoor services.

Social gatherings of more than 10 persons are prohibited. Even in these small gatherings, social distancing must be followed and face coverings should be used when social distancing is not achievable.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Farming/Agriculture/Food processing
policy_description: Lower-risk businesses are allowed to open with modifications given that they strictly follow NPI guidance. These businesses include: retailers, shopping malls, gyms, non-contact school sports, parks, athletic fields, playgrounds, libraries, construction, real estate, and agriculture.
Personal care facilities such as salons, spas, and tattoo parlors are allowed to open so long as they create a COVID-19 Protocol, follow NPIs, and limit close contact service to 30 minutes or less.

While previously there was a limitation of 30 minutes or less for personal care services, this order now allows the lifting of that time limit. It is strongly advised that close proximity of less than 6 feet even with the use of facial covering is limited as much as possible. This is to align with the May 26, 2020 California Department of Public Health (CDPH) guidance for hair salons and barbershops.

Places of worship and providers of religious services/cultural ceremonies are allowed to reopen if appropriate modifications are made to ensure social distancing of six feet or more, adherence to other NPIs, and related guidance as enumerated in the COVID-19 Industry Guidance: Places of Worship and providers of Religious Services and Cultural Ceremonies issued by the California Department of Health on May 25, 2020. All attendees above the age of 2 or those who cannot due to medical limitations must wear facial coverings.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Hotels/lodging; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: The Yuba-Sutter Bi-County Health Officer has carefully reviewed all the industry guidance issued by the California Department of Public Health (CDPH) on June 5, 2020, and will allow the reopening of the following sectors if appropriate modifications are implemented for COVID-19 infection prevention and control. These sectors include the reopening of day camps; campgrounds, RV parks, and outdoor recreation; hotels for tourism; cardrooms, satellite wagering facilities and racetracks; family entertainment centers; restaurants, bars, wineries; and museums, galleries, zoos, and aquariums, pro sports without live audiences; and music, film, and television production. Daycare centers have already been allowed to be open in Yuba-Sutter but should still carefully review the updated CDPH's guidance to ensure that they are in full compliance. Regarding casinos operated by sovereign tribal nations, the Bi-County Health Officer respects tribal nations' sovereignty in regards to the decision to operate or not.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: All persons over the age of 65 or living with chronic medical issues that place them at increased risk as noted by the CDC, shall remain in their place of residence. They may only leave to seek medical care or food for themselves or family members, perform work or recreational activities, but must adhere at all times to NPIs.

policy_subtarget: Government/public buildings; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Public transportation; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Essential businesses that are considered "Higher Risk" but are vital for essential functions and have been open prior to this Order shall remain open  with modifications to ensure appropriate adherence to non-pharmacologic interventions (NPIs). NPIs include but are not limited to maintaining social distancing of six feet or more from another person not part of their household, good hand hygiene, staying home when having symptoms concerning for COVID-19, and wearing facial coverings whenever social distancing is not feasible.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Farming/Agriculture/Food processing; Restaurants/bars; Personal care facilities
policy_description: All Lower Risk businesses allowed to open with appropriate modifications shall create and post a COVID-19 Operations Protocol for each facility. The Protocol should be posted near an entrance in public view, and the business must provide a copy to each employee. An onsite employee must monitor and enforce compliance with the Protocol at all times. The Protocol should explain how the business is: limiting the number of employees at the facility, limiting the number of persons who can enter to ensure social distancing is possible (and that masks are worn when persons must interact at closer than 6 feet), providing sanitizer or soap and water, providing contactless or frequently disinfected pay systems, regularly cleaning high touch surfaces, and posting a sign at the entrance enforcing NPIs.

For all businesses allowed to reopen by virtue of this amendment, they must: perform symptoms screening and temperature checks prior to the start of shift/work day; close interactions of less than 6 feet between non-household members should be minimized as much as possible; use facial coverings when social distancing is not possible; minimize sharing of items as much as possible between non-household members.

This amendment modifies the existing Order of the Public Health Officer dated May 4, 2020 and its amendments to close all bars, pubs, breweries, and brewpubs in Sutter County and Yuba County. This applies to both indoors and outdoors services.

All Skilled Nursing Facilities (SNFs) in California must test any and all staff or contractors that have the potential to interact with SNF residents, or who must gain entry into the unit for any reason
Closure of bars, pubs, brewpubs and breweries not offering sit-down, dine-in meals; those which are exempt from closure must follow State's guidelines

Californians can travel for urgent matters or if such travel is essential to their permitted work. Even though businesses around the state are opening up, avoid travelling long distances for vacations or pleasure as much as possible. This is to slow the spread of the coronavirus. Do not travel if you are sick, or if someone in your household has had coronavirus in the last two weeks. Do not travel with someone who is sick. Californians should not travel significant distances for pleasure or recreation and should stay close to home
No cost, no appointment, walk-up COVID testing throughout Ventura County.

policy_subtarget: Churches/places of worship; Outdoor recreation or space; Casinos/gambling facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Hotels/lodging; Restaurants/bars; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: This policy notes that all the above industries should follow the COVID-19 Industry Guidance provided by the state of California.

This policy extends the previous policy that orders businesses to establish, implement, and enforce COVID-19 prevention plans. This policy also gives direction to local adoption of state guidance on specified businesses and activities.

This policy allows more businesses to reopen in Ventura County with modifications. This news release creates stages for reopening. This news release notes the continued closure of night clubs, bars, pools, hotels, and salons.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: This news release modifies social distancing protocols, allowing gyms, day camps, hotels, campgrounds, restaurants, pools, and film productions to run with specific guidelines.

This policy orders for all bars to close. Restaurants may not allow indoor dining, but they can have outdoor dining with restrictions: only members of the same household can sit together, the maximum time a patron may dine is 1.5 hours, and restaurants must close dining between 10:00pm and 5:00am.
This policy allows bars that serve food and wineries can open outdoor operations.
This policy notes that the County of Ventura has been placed in Tier 1 of the State's health order system, allowing hair salons, barbershops, and malls to reopen indoor operations.

This policy allows bars that serve food and wineries can open outdoor operations. This policy amends the previous policy on July 2 and July 16, allowing bars to remain open until 11:00 PM (rather than 10:00 PM). Additional restrictions for outdoor operations remain.
This policy allows specified industries and activities to reopen indoors because the County of Ventura is placed in Tier 2 of the State's health order system.
This policy requires all beaches and beach parking to be closed to the public during the July 4th weekend.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: This policy orders gyms, places of worship, protests, offices for non-essential workers, personal care services, and malls to close.
This policy orders that all individual entering or residing in homeless shelters and H-2A housing must do temperature screenings, self evaluation of symptoms, and report COVID-19 cases.
Ventura County, CA turns back to purple tier, meaning that some businesses can only have outdoor operations, and indoor businesses must operate at 25% capacity.

policy_description: This order modifies restrictions on recreational facilities that were closed have been closed due to the Order Of The Yolo County Public Health Officer Directing Individuals To Shelter In Place.... Golf courses, boat ramps/launches, and hunting clubs and practice ranges may open.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Casinos/gambling facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Hotels/lodging
policy_description: As determined by the State of California, Yolo County has moved to Red Tier/Stage 2. This means the business closures from the Second Amended Order Of The Yolo County Public Health Officer Regarding The Recovery From COVID-19, which is still in place, have been modified. Bars, breweries, and distilleries without food service must remain closed. Professional sports, offices, cardrooms, family entertainment, wineries, restaurants, gyms/fitness centers, hotels/lodging, movie theaters, places of worship, museums/zoos/aquariums, retail, personal care services, and infrastructure may open with modifications.

The statewide stay-at-home order and related guidance is in place for Yolo County. State-level guidance will become available on thee Yolo County website. The order also emphasizes the importance of voluntary compliance throughout the community in confronting COVID-19 and urges county residents to follow the provided health/mitigation measures.

The statewide stay-at-home order and related guidance is in place for Yolo County. State-level guidance will become available on thee Yolo County website. The order also emphasizes the importance of voluntary compliance throughout the community in confronting COVID-19 and urges county residents to follow the provided health/mitigation measures.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Non essential business (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Casinos/gambling facilities
policy_description: This order identifies business types that are required to close or operate subject to certain new restrictions. Brewpubs, breweries, bars, and pubs, must close unless they are offering sit-down, dine-in meals exclusively in an outdoor setting. Alcohol can only be sold in the same transaction as a meal. Takeout and delivery service is permitted. The following industries must close all operations except for outdoor/takeout & delivery services: dine-in restaurants, wineries and tasting rooms, movie theaters, family entertainment centers, zoos and museums, and cardrooms. The following must be modified to operate outdoors and follow other mitigation measures:  fitness centers, worship services, protests, offices for non-essential sectors, personal care services, hair salons and barbershops, and malls.
All individuals who have COVID-19 must isolate and tell their close contacts to quarantine.
All individuals who had close contact with a person with COVID-19 must quarantine.
All individuals who had close contact with a person with COVID-19 must quarantine.
All individuals who have COVID-19 must isolate and tell their close contacts to quarantine.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Grocery store; Retail stores (not including food); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Outdoor recreation or space; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Residents are strongly encouraged to stay home. Gatherings of any size are strongly discouraged; only outdoor gatherings are permitted. Restaurants and wineries may remain open outdoors, but those seated at a single table are limited to household members only and tables must be a minimum of 6 feet apart. Indoor retail establishments (including groceries) may remain open but must operate limited capacity. Gyms and fitness centers may remain open outdoors but face coverings are required. Sports are limited to drills and conditioning only, with physical distancing, and only outdoors. Activities that do not allow for physical distancing are prohibited. Effective 11:59 pm on  December 10, Yolo County will now be under the State's Regional Stay Home Order.

In the event of a positive COVID-19 case identified in an attendee at a faith-based gathering, it is crucial that prompt identification of all exposed individuals is done by public health. It is strongly advised that all faith-based organizations maintain a list of their congregants including names and contact information so that this information can be quickly provided to the Yuba-Sutter Public Health Department.

Individuals should follow non-pharmacologic interventions (NPIs) to the greatest extent possible, including but not limited to maintaining social distancing of six feet or more from another person not part of their household, good hand hygiene, staying home when having symptoms concerning for COVID-19, and wearing facial coverings whenever social distancing is not feasible.
If facial coverings cannot be safely worn during workouts, then social distancing of at least six feet or more should be strictly adhered to between non-household members.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Gyms and fitness facilities shall implement special hours for those age 65 years and older or with chronic medical issues to ensure that they can exercise in a safe manner and minimize their risk of exposure and infection to COVID-19.

Given the concern of out-of-county travel, each hotel must implement a robust system to confirm with each guest prior to their arrival that they are without symptoms concerning for COVID-19, and have not been informed by any public health department in the past 14 days that they have been exposed to a COVID-19 case.

The industry guidance of bars applies to bars, brewpubs, craft distilleries, breweries, bars, pubs, and wineries. All staff and employees are required to wear facial coverings when at work. Customers must also wear facial coverings when not drinking or eating and social distancing between non-household members is not possible. Seating at the same table should be limited to members of the same household only. It is strongly recommended that capacity be reduced as much as possible to allow for adequate social distancing and limit congregating at high traffic areas including the entrances, exits, and bathrooms. Orders should be taken at the table instead of at the bar. Outdoor seating is highly encouraged due to the better ventilation over indoor settings.

All indoor services must be closed for the following sectors: dine-in restaurants, wineries and tasting rooms, family entertainment centers and movie theaters, indoor attractions at zoos and museums, cardrooms. These sectors may continue to operate outdoor services.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Farming/Agriculture/Food processing
policy_description: Lower-risk businesses are allowed to open with modifications given that they strictly follow NPI guidance. These businesses include: retailers, shopping malls, gyms, non-contact school sports, parks, athletic fields, playgrounds, libraries, construction, real estate, and agriculture.
Personal care facilities such as salons, spas, and tattoo parlors are allowed to open so long as they create a COVID-19 Protocol, follow NPIs, and limit close contact service to 30 minutes or less.

Social gatherings of more than 10 persons are prohibited. Even in these small gatherings, social distancing must be followed and face coverings should be used when social distancing is not achievable.

Places of worship and providers of religious services/cultural ceremonies are allowed to reopen if appropriate modifications are made to ensure social distancing of six feet or more, adherence to other NPIs, and related guidance as enumerated in the COVID-19 Industry Guidance: Places of Worship and providers of Religious Services and Cultural Ceremonies issued by the California Department of Health on May 25, 2020. All attendees above the age of 2 or those who cannot due to medical limitations must wear facial coverings.

While previously there was a limitation of 30 minutes or less for personal care services, this order now allows the lifting of that time limit. It is strongly advised that close proximity of less than 6 feet even with the use of facial covering is limited as much as possible. This is to align with the May 26, 2020 California Department of Public Health (CDPH) guidance for hair salons and barbershops.

Signage requirements remain in effect and must be printed in English, Spanish and Creole.
Clarification of Attachment 15 that environmental activities may operate during sunrise-sunset.
Schools are strongly encouraged to follow CDC guidelines even though they are not classified as establishments .

All parks in Broward County may open. Parks can only be used for walking, hiking, biking, jogging, personal boat launching, fishing, mountain biking, disk  golfing and horseback riding. recreational and commercial boating are permitted. All municipal, public and private golf courses may open. Tennis courts are limited to singles. No groups of more than 10 in the park and 50 ft must remain between all groups.
Public and private pools may open.
Drive in movie theaters can operate at 50% capacity. Museums may open at 25% occupancy.
Personal care service businesses such as salons may open as long as they comply with governor's EO 20-120.
Restaurants can open at 50% max occupancy indoors. Outdoor seating permitted with 6ft distancing. Indoor and outdoor seating may not exceed 100% occupancy
Community rooms/fitness centers and gyms in housing developments or community associations can open at 50% for residents only. Saunas, hot tubs, steam rooms and shower facilities are still closed.
Retail business may open at 50% max occupancy .
All non-profits, retail and commercial business except may open unless otherwise prohibited.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Commercial gyms, fitness centers and fitness center pools can open.
Hotels/motels/commercial lodging may open. Ball rooms and function spaces are still closed.Vacation rentals may open for essential lodgers as in Executive order 20-87.
Raquette court sports facilites may now permit doubles play.
Tattoo and massage parlors may open.
Broward beaches are now open for picnicking, sunbathing or lying dow. Umbrellas and chairs etc are now permitted. Organized sports and groups larger than 10 remain prohibited.
Summer camps and youth activities including those at museums, parks and beaches are allowed to open.
Pari-mutuel facilities in order to reopen must submit a reopening plan and receive state approval. They may open Friday the 12th.
Vacation rentals are now permitted.
Indoor amusement facilities such as bowling alleys, arcades and movie theaters may open at 50% capacity. Museums may now operate at 50% capacity.
Pari-mutuel facilities may open.
Short term Vacation rentals are allowed to operate subject to restrictions.
Restaurants may now serve customers on premise until 11:00 PM.

Under section 3, Childcare facilities are essential. Childcare must be in groups of less than 10 and groups may not interact. Children with symptoms consistent with COVID-19 shall not be allowed in the childcare facility.
Hotels, motels and commercial lodging may not accept new reservations apart from essential lodgers defined under section 3(gg) and  the limitations set by governor's order 20-70.
Essential businesses listed in section 3 may remain open. This order does not restrict religious services.

Broward county transit. Customers can only exit and enter buses via the rear doors except those who require the wheelchair ramp. Fare collections are also suspended on all bus services. Buses will additionally operate on a Saturday schedule every day.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Marinas, boat launches, docking, fueling, marine supply are permitted for situations  in section 3.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Order 20-01 amended to include pawn shops as essential. Clarification of marina services definition.
Individuals "urged" to remain at home except for essential activities. Those outside the home shall comply with all governors orders, county emergency orders, and CDC measures on social distancing.
No more than 10 people may congregate near a restaurant/ food service and those in line must adhere to CDC standards.
All non-essential non profits ordered to close. Essential and nonessential descriptions  from orders 20-01 and 20-02 remain with underlined amendments.
movie theaters are closed.

Pursuant to Governors order 20-91 Broward county defers to the states definition of essential services and closes all establishments not listed as essential by this order. Non-essential services may continue with Minimum Basic Operations as long as complying with CDC social distancing standards. Places of Worship are not included.
Only one or multiple riders from the same household are permitted on jet skis.
Broward county beaches are still closed.
Pursuant to governor's executive order 20-112 groups of more than 10 are prohibited from gathering in public spaces.
Bars, nightclubs, movie theaters, concert houses are still closed.
Restaurants must post signage about COVID-19, social distancing and face coverings.
Restaurants may not serve on site between midnight and 5am.

Face covering are  required in all public spaces where social distancing is not possible. People in a business, whether working or visiting, individuals in a common area of a residential facility, workers involved with the preparation of food must wear a face mask regardless of social distancing. Those under the age of 2, or in the custody of a licensed childcare/daycare facility, those receiving services where face masks are not possible such as a eating/drinking, a person with a medical condition.
Beaches are closed from July 3 through July 5.
Restaurants may not serve on site between 10:00 pm and 5am.

All businesses that violate local emergency orders will be forced to close for 24 hours after their first citation, with each subsequent citation incurring an additional 72 hours of closure (e.g. 96 hour closure after a second citation, 168 hour closure after a third citation etc.)
Broward county under a curfew from 11:00 PM - 5:00 AM. Essential workers traveling to and from their job, first responders and people walking pets within 250 ft of their homes are exempt.
Private gatherings of more than 10 people are banned. Violators shall be subject to penalties.
Short term vacation rentals are not allowed.
Ordering food from a bar counter is prohibited. All food ordering must be done at a table.

11:00 from 5:00 am curfew is extended until August 3 at 5 AM Essential workers traveling to and from their job, first responders, those returning from vehicular travel of more than 100 miles/ those returning from commercial travel ending in an airport or seaport and people walking pets within 250 ft of their homes are exempt.
Outdoor open air events are not permitted .
The sale of to go alcohol by restaurants is prohibited between 11 PM and 5 AM. Food take out is still permitted.
Open alcohol containers are prohibited between 11pm and 5 am.
Bars, pubs, breweries, billiard halls and clubs and cocktail lounges  that derive more than 50% of revenue from the sale of alcohol remain closed.

local_area: Broward County, FL; Miami-Dade County, FL
policy_description: Beginning 9/14/2020, Miami-Dade and Broward counties are approved to move into Phase 2 of the Safe. Smart. Step-by-Step. Plan for Florida's Recovery.
Residents and visitors "are urged" to stay at home unless doing essential activities
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Clarifies that after a tropical storm or hurricane warning has been issued, or after a declaration of a state of emergency due to a tropical storm or a hurricane, that hotels, motels or other commercial lodging establishments may allow in-person dining at on-premises restaurants, may exceed social distancing requirements in ballrooms and meeting rooms for the purposes of providing temporary sheltering or for other emergency purposes arising from the tropical storm or hurricane; and clarifies that short term vacation rentals where otherwise permitted that are located in any structure operated in whole or in part as a hotel or a condominium may accept daily rentals, as those short term vacation rentals are not commonly used for large gatherings or parties
Emergency order 23-20 is repealed. Emergency order 26-20 is repealed.
Emergency orders 5-20 and 21-20 as amended are cancelled
Cancels emergency orders 1-20,16-20 and 28-20

All parks and recreation facilities including golf courses may open from 7 am -8 pm. Certain amenities such as bike racks, playgrounds and exercise  equipment etc.. (see full list in section 4) are still prohibited.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: All marinas, boat launches, docks, fueling, marine supply  are open with certain restrictions laid out in section 5.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: This order DOES NOT limit religious services. religious services are urged not required to practice social distancing measures.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Previously non-essential retail and commercial establishment may open as long as they comply with requirements. As a condition of reopening all establishments shall do everything in section 2.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Short term vacation rentals may operate in accordance with guidelines

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Banquet Facilities and similar venues may open. Must operate at 50% capacity and comply with standards set in 23-20.Public pools may open as long as operating with standards set in 23-20.
Reopens beaches, swimming pools, and hotels with social distancing rules.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Removes "beaches" from order. 21-20 Beaches now open.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Expansion of permitted sports activities

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector
policy_description: Charter vessels may have their full capacity on board

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Gyms, Recreation buildings, Campgrounds, dog parks, skateparks and concession stands may open

Bars pubs, night clubs, cabarets, cocktail lounges and breweries remain closed, but may sell food and alcohol beverages on sight if licensed as a public food service establishment. Performances are permitted as long as performers are no less than 10 ft from customers.
Summer camps and youth sports allowed but must follow order 23-20 and the handbook. Dog parks and swimming pools removed from the closed list.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Private sector
policy_description: Banquet halls, gyms fitness centers, summer camps, youth activities, massage studios or parlors and tattoo parlors are re-open but must comply with the "Moving to New  a Normal Handbook" and order 23-20
Dogs may be off leashes at dog parks.

Maximum occupancy for short term vacation rentals shall not exceed a max of 2 people per bedroom plus 2 additional people and cannot exceed 10. Section 10 explains that during a tropical storm/hurricane warning has been issued social distancing regulations for lodging establishments may relax.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Private sector; Casinos/gambling facilities
policy_description: Every retail and commercial establishment or other establishment is permitted to open except for those explicitly listed in paragraph 4.
Emergency Order 27-20 is amended to include "traveling to or from any religious service" in its curfew exemption.
Outdoor amusement and other outdoor recreational facilities and events may operate at 50% capacity

All parks may open form 7 am to 10:00 pm. Parks/ recreational facilities shall be limited to active/ passive uses by individual and families. Social distancing shall be observed and groups more than 10 are not permitted. Concessions and food trucks may operate. Organized sports team activities are permitted but competitions and league play remain prohibited except for tennis, raquetteball, softball/baseball and if masks are worn by all players. Sports equipment cannot be shared unless between members of the same household. Select trails and walkways will be a one way flow. Restrooms shall be cleaned and have an attendant. Use of playgrounds, exercise equipment, shelters, splash-pads and mechanical attractions remain prohibited. Additional measures for Golf courses, charter vessel and tour boats, fishing peers, public restrooms, fish cleaning stations and boat ramps can be found in this order
Use of shared motorized scooters and bicycle  is now permitted.

Curfew now starts at 11:00 p.m instead of 10:00 p.m. he curfew does not apply to those making deliveries, essential workers, those returning from or going to work and those walking their dogs within 250 ft of their residence. and traveling to or from any religious service
Limited competitive play is permitted including scrimages
Movie theaters, concert houses, convention spaces, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, arcades and indoor amusement facilities may open.
Playgrounds and mechanical equipment may open for use so long as they are cleaned.

Curfew is imposed for all of Miami dade from 12:00 am until 6:00 am. Exceptions include those working at essential establishments, those returning directly to their homes from work or going to work, those making deliveries from essential establishments, those walking their dogs, those traveling to or from a religious service, and those traveling to and from and NCAA, major league baseball etc.. sporting event.
Businesses are no longer required to consent to inspections and submit compliance plans after violating this order
There is a new version of the  "Moving to New Normal Handbook"
Parks no longer have limited hours of operation.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Facilities that provide meal service to the elderly are ordered to close or to stop programs that deliver personal services. This does not apply to assisted living, adult day cares, or nursing homes.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Prohibits the use of commercial shared mopeds/ motorized scooters. This does not apply to those owned by an individual.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Rafting, or tying boats together so that there is less than 5 ft between boats is prohibited.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: People at high risk to COVID-19 such as the elderly and those with medical conditions are urged to stay home.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Employers "are urged" to allow at risk employees to work from home and flexible leave time.

policy_description: Tattoo and massage parlors remain closed

policy_description: Establishments with an on site employee/contractor who tests positive shall close either for the time needed for all staff to be tested and the establishment sanitized OR 14 days from the date the employee/contractor was last on site.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Pools and hot tubs continue to follow  order 16-20.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Bars pubs night clubs, banquet halls, cocktail lounges, cabarets, and breweries are still closed except for delivery services. movie theatres, concert houses auditoriums and, playhouses and arcades are still closed.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Indoor amusement facilities, casinos that are not on tribal, massage parlors, and summer camps remain closed.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: In section 5 of order 23-20, only staff who were in contact with the person who tested positive need to be tested and cleared. The establishment must remain closed only if deep sanitation is not performed. Further amendments  under section on specifications of screening and closures in the event of a positive case in an establishment.
intended_duration: end of local state of emergency

policy_description: Concerts and conventions are not allowed  except for outdoor events with social distancing.

policy_description: Social distancing requirements do not apply families that live in the same household.
