policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Private sector
policy_description: Any establishment that fails to comply with face covering requirements, the new normal handbook shall close. Any business that closes shall take 24 hours to review the order and comply.
Hookah lounges remain closed. Places that sell alcohol may not do so on site between 12:01 AM and 6:00 AM
Restaurant that seat more than 8 people shall close in person dining from 12:01 pm to 6:00 AM. Delivery and take out services however may continue between these times.

Miami-Dade is under curfew from 10 pm until 6 am. The curfew does not apply to those making deliveries, essential workers, those returning from or going to work and those walking their dogs within 250 ft of their residence.

commercial lodging establishments hotels and motels must also close pools between  8pm and 6:00 am, limit pool use to guest and capacity to 50% pool dec. Alcohol sale and consumption is not allowed before 11:00. Only guests may access rooms and room occupancy limits must be strictly observed.
No parades will be allowed between July 3 and July 6. Municipal fireworks shows are permitted but must follow the social distance and facial covering requirements.
All public and private beaches are closed between July 3 and July 6.

policy_subtarget: Casinos/gambling facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Movie theaters, concert houses, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, arcades, indoor amusement facilities, and casinos shall close
Outdoor amusement facilities and attractions, adult theaters, special cabarets and unlicensed massage establishments shall close.

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Casinos/gambling facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Replaces order 26-20. Movie theaters, concert houses, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, arcades, indoor/outdoor amusement facilities/attractions, casinos, adult theaters, special cabarets,, unlicensed massage establishments, banquet halls, and ballrooms shall close.
Short term vacation rentals limited to 2 per bedroom and 2 per property not exceeding 10. New rental agreements cannot be entered except for on a monthly basis
Restaurants with seating for more than 8 people may only serve outdoor dining.  between 6:00 am and 10:00 pm. Table size additionally limited to 4 including members of the same household.
Restaurants with seating for more than 8 people shall close on premise dining during curfew hours. Restaurants may provide outdoor dining areas

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Establishments permitted to open must meet the requirements in paragraph 2 of this order, the requirements in the "Moving to a New Normal Handbook", and the facial covering order 20-20. Establishments that do not comply will be required to close. Section 5 of the order describes what employers must do in the case of a positive employee.

Bars, night clubs, ballrooms, banquet halls, cocktail lounges, cabarets, hookah lounges and breweries are closed. Those that are licensed as a public food service establishment may operate under the rules for restaurants. Movie theaters, concert houses, convention spaces, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, arcades, indoor amusement, adult entertainment, concerts, conventions, and other temporary events except outdoor events.

Movie theaters, concert houses, convention spaces, auditoriums, playhouses, bowling alleys, arcades and indoor amusement facilities are at a 50% capacity max. Eating is permitted inside in designated areas only.i
Bars, pubs, night clubs, cocktail lounges cabarets, adult entertainment venues, hookah lounges or breweries remain closed.
Live performances are permitted so long as performers are at least 10 ft from patrons. Patrons must watch performances from seats or tables.
Organized inter team sports and league games remain prohibited, except for tennis, raquetball and baseball if face coverings are worn .
Live performances are permitted so long as performers are at least 10 ft from patrons. Patrons must watch performances from seats or tables.
Bleachers remain closed to spectators for organized sports
Clarifies Restaurants and other businesses are subject to the requirements of the curfew
Palm Beach County Emergency Order 20-014 is hereby repealed in its entirety and replaced with this Order 20-015.
Executive Order 2020-012 is hereby extended until 23 August 2020.

All public county and municipal parks, and natural areas, with the exception of beach parks, shall reopen as set forth in Attachment 4 entitled "Public Parks and Natural Areas Reopening Guidelines.” Such activities shall be done in accordance with CDC Guidelines and in compliance with the requirements set forth in Attachment 4.

All tennis and outdoor racquet facilities, as well as community pools, shall reopen as set forth in Attachment 5 entitled "Tennis Courts and Community Pools Reopening Guidelines.” Such activities shall be done in accordance with CDC Guidelines and in compliance with the requirements set forth in Attachment 5.
All individuals shall continue to adhere to the "CDC guidelines" as amended in section 4.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Boating and marine activities, including recreational and commercial boating activity, may resume only if in accordance with CDC Guidelines and in compliance with the requirements set forth in Attachment 2 entitled “Boating and Marine Activity Requirements.” Any activities that deviate from said guidelines and requirements remain prohibited.

All municipal, public, and privately-run golf courses may reopen only if in accordance with CDC Guidelines and in compliance with the requirements set forth in Attachment 3 entitled "Golf Requirements.” Any activities that deviate from said guidelines and requirements remain prohibited

Replaces section 7 of Palm Beach EO 2020-005: now including beach parks, all public and private parks and natural areas may reopen as set forth in Attachment 4, Revision 1. Such activities should comply with CDC guidelines and Attachment 4, Revision 1 requirements.
All "Beaches" defined in section 4 shall be authorized to reopen and are subject to the requirements set forth in section 4.
Replaces Attachment 5 of Palm Beach EO 2020-005 with Attachment 5, Revision 1 entitled "Tennis Courts and Community Pools Reopening Guidelines."

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector
policy_description: Replaces Attachment 3 of Palm Beach EO 2020-005 with Attachment 3, Revision 2 entitled “Golf Requirements.”

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Replaces Attachment 2 of Palm Beach EO 2020-005 with Attachment 2, Revision 2 entitled “Boating and Marine Activity Requirements.”
Replaces Attachment 4 of Palm Beach EO 2020-005 with Attachment 4, Revision 2 entitled “Public Parks, Private Parks, and Natural Areas Reopening Guidelines.”

Organized youth activities may operate, including youth sports teams and leagues, youth clubs and programs, and child care. Summer camps and youth recreation camps may operate including, but not limited to, those defined in Sections 409.175 and 513.02, Florida Statutes, respectively.
Palm Beach County is approved to move into Phase 2 of my Safe. Smart. Step-by-Step. Plan for Florida's Recovery.
All islands, sandbars, intracoastal lands are prohibited for use by the public.
All boat docks, ramps, marinas, and any other venues used for launching vessels are closed. Commercial fishing, commercial marine operations, and related support services are permitted to operate.

All boat docks, ramps, marinas, and any other venues used for launching vessels to be used for recreational purposes (e.g. fishing charters, boat tours, diving excursions, etc.) are closed. Commercial fishing, commercial marine operations, and related support services are permitted to operate.
All golf courses are closed to public access.
All parks shall be closed to public access.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All public and private golf courses are closed.
Individuals "are urged" to stay at home unless doing essential activities outlined in section 7.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All pools are closed.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All public and private parks are closed.
All businesses and establishments in Section 4 of this Order 2020-012 shall conspicuously post signage as detailed under Section 7.

All businesses and establishments in Section 4 of this Order 2020-012 shall establish a process for verification of compliance upon customer entry into the establishment and shall ensure compliance with the Order's provisions.

All beaches, including beach parks, shall be closed from 12:01AM on 3 July 2020 to 11:59PM on 5 July 2020. Restaurants and retail establishments within beach parks may remain open subject to restrictions of current State and local emergency orders.

No establishment permitted to serve alcohol or food for on-site consumption, whether indoor or outdoor, shall serve food/alcohol between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. Nothing in this section prohibits delivery, drive-through, pick-up, or take-out services, for off-site consumption.
Amusement parks; hookah and smoking bars and lounges; kava, kratom and similar bars and lounges; banquet halls; and ballrooms shall be closed between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m.

Amusement parks; kava, kratom, and similar bars and lounges; banquet halls; and ballrooms shall be closed between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. The list of businesses in Section 6 remain closed.

No establishment permitted to serve food or alcohol for on-site consumption, whether indoor or outdoor, shall serve food/alcohol or allow food/alcohol to be consumed on premises between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. Said establishments shall be closed and vacated between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. with the exception of staff performing necessary functions; and drive-through, pick-up, or take-out services for off-site consumption. Indoor and outdoor seating shall be vacated between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. and shall not be available for customers utilizing pick-up or take-out services. The list of businesses in Section 6 remain closed.
Groups of people greater than ten are not permitted to congregate in any public space that does not readily allow for appropriate social distancing.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Mayor Bottoms institutes telework for all municiple, non-essential workers.
Mayor Bottoms closes City Hall to the public on 03/12/2020.
The City of Atlanta's  Department of Parks and Recreation and the Atlanta Police Department are to no longer accept applications for permits for events to be held in the city of Atlanta.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: All restaurants and other public establishments that have an approved occupancy of 50 persons or more are ordered by the City of Atlanta to comply with CDC guidance and limit their maximum occupancy to 50 persons on 03/16/2020.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Government/public buildings
policy_description: Mayor Bottoms closed City hall for all essential and non-essential employees.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: The City of Atlanta orders that all meetings of city boards, authorities, commissions, committees, or other similar bodies are closed to the public.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The City of Atlanta Declares permits residents to leave their residences only to complete essential activities.

The Magistrate Court will continue to stay open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week to review the probable cause application(s) for search and arrests warrants, Domestic Abuse Temporary Protective Orders, Restraining Orders, and Preliminary Hearings.
No jurors or grand jury shall report and no jury trials shall be held. No civil or non-essential matters will be heard by courts, unless it can be held with teleconferencing.
This is a declaration of the existence of a judicial emergency in Clayton Judicial Circuit.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Suspected cases; Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must require workers who are exhibiting signs of illness to not report to work or to seek medical attention.

Residents of the county over 65, who reside in nursing homes or long term care facilities are encouraged to continue to reside there, unless necessary to get medical treatment. These individuals are also encouraged to wear cloth face coverings in public.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Personal care facilities
policy_description: Gyms, fitness centers, bowling alleys, body art centers, and salons are to start in-person operations, just as Governor Kemp had declared in his executive order. Citizens are urged take precautions to stop the spread in light of these establishments reopening.
All individuals in public must maintain strict social distance of 6 feet apart.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: All businesses and employers must take the necessary steps, to the maximum extent possible, to provide employees with the means and equipment to perform their job functions remotely.
All individuals and families are encouraged to shelter in place as much as possible.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All DeKalb playgrounds and outdoor fitness equipment are closed and cannot be used.
All individuals are asked to participate in a voluntary curfew from 9p.m. to 6a.m., excluding trips for work, food, medication, medical treatment, or other emergencies.
All public gatherings of 10 or more are prohibited in accordance with CDC guidelines.
Any person showing COVID-19 symptoms recognized by the CDC must not enter public buildings, shops, restaurants, and public transportation. They should not return to the public until given clearance.
Any establishment that is licensed for on premise consumption of alcoholic beverages may sell such unopened beverages curbside or to take out customers only during times specified on their license.

All houses of worship will strive for density reduction, whether at a scheduled service or life event (baptism/funeral), and shall practice physical distancing. Houses of worship are encouraged to broadcast services online.
All non-essential businesses will have an operation hours curfew of 6a.m. to 9p.m.
All employers and businesses that remain open to the public must restrict person to person contact and have people maintain a distance of 6 feet from each other in the establishment.
There cannot be any dine-in service at any restaurant, brewery, or bar. These establishments may only operate take-out or delivery services.
All indoor funeral gatherings must be limited to no more than 10 individuals. Also, graveside services are highly encouraged to be 10 or less people.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Personal care facilities
policy_description: Bowling alleys, gyms, hair salons, beauty salons, or other establishment offering personal grooming must limit capacity to 10 or less people.

All individuals, especially the medically fragile, living in DeKalb County are directed to stay at their place of residence. All individuals are permitted to leave their places of residence only to provide or receive certain essential services or engage in certain essential activities and work for essential businesses and essential governmental functions.

Any person showing symptoms recognized by the CDC as indicators of COVID19 shall refrain from entering public buildings, restaurants, shops, public transportation facilities and all other public areas.
All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a single household or living unit are prohibited, except for limited purposes.
DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must deliver intangible services remotely wherever possible.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must increase physical space between workers' worksites to a least 6 feet.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must enhance sanitation of the workplace as appropriate. Also, they must require hand washing by workers at appropriate locations on the premise.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must permit workers to take breaks and meals outside, in their office or other personal workspace, or in such other places where social distancing is attainable.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must provide disinfectant and sanitation products for workers to clean their workspace, equipment, and tools.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must increase physical distance between workers and customers.
DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must enforce social distancing of non-cohabitating persons while present on entity's leased or owned property.
DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must place notices that encourage hand hygiene at the entrance of the workplace and other clearly visited spots in the establishment.

DeKalb retailers and service providers reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must provide for alternative points of sale outside of buildings, including curbside pickup or delivery of products and/or services if an alternative point of sale is allowed under Georgia law.
DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must prohibit handshaking and any other unnecessary human to human contact.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must implement staggered shifts for all possible employees.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must discourage workers from using other workers' phones, desks, offices, or other work tools or equipment.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must prohibit gatherings of workers during work hours.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must hold all meetings and conferences virtually, wherever possible.

DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must suspend use of Personal Identification Number ("PIN") pads, PIN entry devices, electronic signature capture, and any other credit card receipt signature requirements to the extent that credit card company agreements allow.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Suspected cases; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must screen workers who exhibit signs of illness, such as fever of 100.4 degrees Fahrenheit, cough, or shortness of breath.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: DeKalb businesses reopening under the governor's 4/20/20 order must implement teleworking for all possible workers.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Grocery store; Homeless shelters/homeless individuals; Restaurants/bars; Hotels/lodging; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics
policy_description: This policy extends the list of essential business that people can visit while the stay at home order is in place. The list includes healthcare facilities, grocery stores, farmer markets, farms, media services, gas stations, auto repair and suppliers, banks, hardware stores, lodging businesses, shipping services, educational institutions (public and private pre K-12 and universities), etc.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: This creates a restriction of fewer than 10 people gathering in non-essential businesses in Fulton County that require direct human contact or that tend to involve crowding in close spaces.

This creates a restriction of fewer than 10 people gathering in essential businesses in Fulton County that require direct human contact or that tend to involve crowding in close spaces. Also, requires people to maintain a safe distance of 6 feet between individuals.
This creates a limitation countywide to gatherings fewer than ten people.
This demands that all residents, especially the medically fragile, of Fulton County to stay at their place of residence and may only leave to receive or engage in certain essential services.
Any persons showing symptoms recognized by the CDC as COVID-19 indicators shall refrain from going to public places. These people should remain at home until given the clearance to leave.
All public and private gatherings of any number of people outside of a household are prohibited.
All dine-in restaurants must close, provided that they may conduct delivery, drive-through,
Sampling of the city's wastewater to increase understanding of the spread of COVID-19 in the city
Recommendation to use an Open Streets model where open streets are temporarily closed to cars and open to people to encourage physical distancing

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics
policy_description: Offers clarity concerning which entities are required to close for on-site consumption and outlines new requirements for public meetings

Mayor's Strategic Priorities include protecting community health - this entails partnering with Central District Health to ensure community members wear masks and avoid crowds as well as working with community organizations to fund hotel rooms for those experiencing homelessness who test positive for COVID-19
Recommendations for category levels of school districts

New recommendations for category levels of school districts that keep Red, Yellow and Green color categories and recommended level of operations but replace the previous category definitions with average case rates calculated for each county
Reissues provisions set forth in Order 20-12

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Opening of 8th Street business and restaurant newly expanded patio footprints following mayor and City Council's adopted resolution supporting local businesses

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Private sector; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics
policy_description: Stage 4 of reopening plan which requires businesses and individuals to comply with COVID-19 guidelines; individuals are prohibited from gathering in groups of more than 250; airport public area access is restricted; some public meetings are allowed to take place
Reopening of Zoo Boise following new health and safety protocols

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Opening of Kid City Camp childcare program at five school-based community centers for children going into first through sixth grades while in-school instruction is suspended

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Once Ada County is designated as category 2 (Yellow) schools and bars and nightclubs previously closed are allowed to open to the public after the district approves their individual plans for reopening

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Primary education; Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Government/public buildings; Non essential business (inclusive); Minors and children
policy_description: Slow re-opening of some facilities for in-person services including but not limited to City Hall, Parks and Recreation Administration Office, Fort Boise Community Center and Boise Airport
Students in preschool through second grade are allowed to return to in-person learning in groups to ensure social distancing
7th- through 12th-graders will return to classrooms using in-person learning on a hybrid basis despite Central District Health moving Ada County schools back into the "red" category

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Update to order to allow for visitation to Long Term Care facilities

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: The Dick Eardley Senior Center is closed effective 03/14/2020.
Services at the Boise Public Library and the Friends of the Boise Public Library will be temporarily suspended
Closure of bars and dine-in restaurant operations excluding drive-thru, delivery or takeout

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All park playgrounds are closed effective 03/21/2020 to prevent the transmission of COVID-19 disease.
Businesses must follow safety protocols, except bars which must close; new guidelines restricting public access to airports; limitation on number of people gathering in groups
Return to guidelines in Idaho’s Stage 3 for COVID-19 response; Ada County bars and nightclubs are not allowed to remain open under this order
Additional guidelines for Stage 4 of reopening plan including face masks requirement; on-site consumption at bars and nightclubs is closed
Addition to order prohibiting gatherings of greater than 10 people
Announcement that Boise schools will start the year in online classes
Announcement of the closure of bicycle bars in addition to Stage 4 safety measures already in place

Strong recommendations for community members such as wearing face coverings, working from home, minimizing non-essential travel, avoiding social gatherings; businesses should implement delivery/curb-side services and activities where social distancing is not possible should be temporarily suspended
intended_duration: until a sustainable two-week decline in cases AND a two-week case rate of under 30/100,000/day occur

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Public services; Primary education; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Temporary closure of several city facilities to the public; some facilities including Idaho IceWorld, the Boise Senior Center and Boise Municipal Pools will be closed through the Summer of 2021
Order consists of requiring face coverings; limiting city board and commissions meetings; restricting Boise Airport access and other unique city businesses
Transition to online learning only; all athletic and extracurricular activities are suspended
COVID-19 Testers are required to notify the Chicago Department of Public Health about the location of testing sites and the specific test offered at each site.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: COVID-19 Testers are required to publish testing availability, testing sites, and type of testing online.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: This order establishes that the meaning of "COVID-19 Illness" and "place of residence" when referred to in the order and future orders.`
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: All Intermediaries shall receive the full text of the governor's Stay At Home Order and shall affirm that they will abide by the order when they book the reservation.  Violators of the order may be fined up to $3,000 and be subject to arrest.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Information provided by the Intermediary shall be reported to the Commissioner by close of business on Tuesdays and Fridays.  The information shall be treated as confidential trade secrets.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Unless exempted by Section 4 of this order, individuals cannot partake in Prohibited Gatherings.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Individuals are required to maintain Social Distancing to the best of their abilities with all individuals who do not live with them.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Non-governmental organizations; Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education; General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The following order is an extension of Public Health Order No. 2020-9.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: The amended order excludes the prior sections pertaining to the sell of liquor for on-premise consumption and the termination of liquor sales and pick-up between 9:00 pm and the hour at which alcoholic liquor sales are permitted to resume.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: The amended order of No. 2020-2. removes the previous requirement to screen employees for COVID-19 at the end of their shift.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: The amended Public Health Order No. 2020-5 permits restaurants to now sell liquor as late as 11 pm.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Emergency functions and governmental functions are exempt from this order.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Chicago parks, beaches, walking, running and cycling paths, trails, and other recreational facilities unless noted for exemption are open for use.  Individuals who use park properties must follow the Chicago Park District guidelines.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: The amended order permits hospitals to develop and implement their own limited visitor policies.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: The amended order allows restaurants and bars to sell liquor until 1:00 am with an establishment closure at 1:30 am.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: The order maintains that liquor stores are required to close at 9:00 pm, but restaurants and bars may sell liquor until 11:00 pm.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: The amended order permits non-essential business to operate until as late as11:00 pm rather than 10:00 pm.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Residents of the City of Chicago who contract COVID-19 are required to shelter in place at their residence and may only leave to seek necessary care or to obtain medicine and food. Violators of the order will be subject to fines.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Hospitals and clinics are required to implement a strict visitor policy that limits entry into patients rooms to only essential healthcare workers. Exemptions shall be made if it is determined that the absence of visitors may have a negative impact on the health of the patient.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: All employees must be checked for symptoms of COVID-19 at the beginning and end of their shift.  Failure to do so will result in a fine.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Chicago parks, beaches, paths, trails, and other recreational facilities are closed unless used for emergency access by first responders or for Essential Travel. Individuals who use these public spaces are subject to arrest or fines.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Gatherings of ten or more people on public or private property are prohibited and individuals can  Exceptions to the order are listed in the state's EO2020-10.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: All individuals in public or private outdoor spaces must maintain at least six feet of distance to the best of their ability. Close-contact group sports are prohibited.  Failure to abide by this order will result in arrest or a fine.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Establishments with a Chapter 4-60 license must cease alcohol sales between 9 p.m. and the hour at which the license permits them to resume sales.  Each establishments must post a prominent signage to inform customers of the new order.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: It is prohibited to boat, although individuals may access a boat docked, moored, harbored, or anchored for maintenance. Golf and fishing are prohibited.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Individuals are prohibited from gathering with more than ten people in both public and private spaces.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Due to large gatherings at held in rented residences, Short Term Residential Rental Intermediaries are required to provide information regarding each Intermediary's personal information and the property being rented.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: All individuals entering the City of Chicago from a High Incidence State is required to self-quarantine for 14 days.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Individuals who are demonstrating or experiencing COVID-19 symptoms are required to isolate from others.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Non-governmental organizations; Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Business and educational entities must ensure employees  maintain social distancing, do not engage in prohibited gatherings, wear a mask, regularly undergo sanitation procedures, self-screen for symptoms, establish an appropriate maximum capacity number, adopt the Gradually Resume Guidelines, and retrain for liquor sales unless a retail food establishment.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: All individuals who are at a higher risk of contracting a severe illness from COVID-19 are encouraged to reside in their residence and minimize-in person contact.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Non-essential business must close to the public between 10:00 pm and 6:00 am central time.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: Notwithstanding Order 2020-5, at 9:00 pm liquor sales and pick-up must end the hour at which the licensee is allowed to resume alcohol sales.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: No licensee is permitted to sell liquor for on-premises consumption indoors when the Order is in effect.  Licensed retail food establishments may sell liquor and airports are exempt.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: The amended Emergency Travel Order will categorize states into three categories based on the state's proportion of COVID cases in comparison to the City of Chicago.
intended_duration: Until the Commissioner of Health releases a written determination that it is safe to repeal the Order.

policy_description: All employees and residents must engage in social/physical distancing as they work on-site, off-site or remotely.

All directives regarding whether employees of the Office of the President or Cook County shall work on-site or remotely must follow the State's "Restore Illinois" plan. The first wave of select employees should expect to work on-site beginning June 15, 2020.
Employees and residents must engage in physical and social distancing while working on-site at work, off-site, or remotely.

All directives regarding whether employees of the Office the President or Cook County shall work on-site or remotely must continue to follow the State's "Restore Illinois" plan. Department heads will communicate employee responsibilities throughout the re-opening phase, and on-site employees must follow social distancing guidelines.
On July 6th, 2020 Cook County buildings and facilities will be re-opened to the public through a phased-in approach that shall adhere to social distancing standards.
County buildings and facilities will continue to operate in adherence to the phased-in approach and other social distancing standards established by the County.

All employees in on-site or remote locations should practice social distancing through the following measures: stay at home when an individual is sick, avoid in-person meetings, have short unavoidable in-person meetings, cease unnecessary travel, keep six feet apart from others, and avoid physical contact.
Any county employees who is returning from a Level 3 Warning-Alert country is required to isolate as based off of the CDC's guidelines.
Re-issues and extends the order cancelling the state fairs in Springfield and DuQuoin scheduled for 2020.
All individuals other than Springfield City employees are prohibited from assembling.
Elkhart continue with stage 4
Elkhart will remain in with stage 4

Bars, taverns, wineries, breweries, distilleries, night clubs can reopen and restrictions on when alcohol can be sold are also lifted

Bars, taverns, wineries, breweries, distilleries, night clubs in Johnson and Story counties continue to be closed, but can sell alcohol for off premise consumption. And restaurants can stay open but must stop selling alcohol after 10:00PM
Cancels Easter and Passover gatherings

policy_description: Under the rural reopening plan, restaurants in the listed counties are permitted to open with certain restrictions and added precautions.
Order Baltimore City to locate and reserve non-congregate shelters for vulnerable persons in need of shelter to protect their health and health of others.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Continuation of Governor's May 6th Executive Order not prohibiting political subdivisions to open outdoor activities on the Stay at Home Order including individual and small group sports, as well as state beaches and parks
intended_duration: Until the termination of the state of emergency and the proclamation of the catastrophic health emergency has been rescinded or ammended

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Staff, owners, and clients of non essential businesses/ offices may only be on the premises at 50% maximum capacity.
Shopping centers in Maryland may not exceed 50% capacity
Indoor recreation areas allowed to open may only at 50% maximum capacity

Personal care facilities that are allowed to open in Baltimore City may not exceed 50% maximum capacity and must keep a record of the name of the client, anyone who accompanied the client, and the service provider. Personal care facilities must clean and disinfect area after serving customer.
Rescinds Stay at Home Order but encourages residents to stay home when possible
Retail establishments are allowed to reopen to the public at limited capacity

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Non essential businesses may open

Outdoor public spaces such as parks, playgrounds, sports fields and courts, and beaches may open to the public. Persons using such outdoor spaces must follow applicable Secretary's Directives, Health Officer Directives, and social distancing guidance
Beginning June 19th 5 pm shopping centers in Maryland with one or more enclosed pedestrian concourses may open to the public
Beauty salons, barber shops, tattoo parlors, tanning salons, massage parlors, and esthetic services (such as nail salons) may open in Baltimore City
Places of worship may reopen at 50% maximum capacity

The following indoor recreation areas may open in Baltimore City at 5 pm June 19: bingo halls, bowling alleys, pool halls, roller and ice skating rinks, social and fraternal clubs, and indoor establishments subject to the Admission and amusement tax
Foodservice establishments may serve food and beverages at outdoor seating areas, conduct carry out, drive through, and delivery business, and beginning 5 pm June 19, serve food and beverage indoors.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: The following outdoor recreation areas may open in Baltimore City at 5 pm June 19: golf courses, archery and shooting ranges, marinas and watercraft rental businesses, campgrounds, horse boarding and riding facilities, drive-in movie theaters, outdoor swimming pools, outdoor day camps, tour boats, sports gatherings with no spectators, youth sports gatherings with no spectators

Starting 5 pm June 19, the governor's order "Closing Casinos, Racetracks, and Simulcast Betting Facilities" is rescinded. The gaming facilities listed in the order may open to the general public. The racing establishments listed in the order may open for racing but not to the general public.

Fitness centers, health clubs, health spas, gyms, aquatic centers, and self defense schools in Baltimore starting 5 pm June 19 may open to the public <airtable:mention id="menBdrBuyhVYdtf0G">@Siobhan Robinson-Marshall</airtable:mention>
Manufacturing businesses may open
Businesses not part of the critical infrastructure sector and not addressed specifically in the order may open at 50% maximum capacity.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Youth Sports Camps and Youth Day Camps are allowed to open for in person activities in accordance with safety requirements and CDC guidelines including no more than 15 people (an increase from 10 people) allowed for indoor activities and no more than 50 for outdoor activities

Childcare facilities may reopen in accordance with the following guidelines: no more than 15 children (increase from 10) plus staff per room, daily health checks, frequent hand washing and surface sanitation, social distancing when age-appropriate, and face coverings for parents
Stay at Home order is again rescinded by this order. Residents are still encouraged to avoid large gatherings.
The prohibition of gatherings of 10  or more is rescinded. Gatherings indoor and outdoor are allowed following safety guidelines.
Outdoor and indoor gatherings are limited to 25 people, and there must be enough space to socially distance.

Indoor gatherings at event venues are limited to under 25 people or 25% maximum capacity of the venue. If facility can hold multiple events, the capacity limitation applies to each space so that the facility does not exceed 25% maximum capacity at any point.
Religious facilities may open to the public at 25% maximum occupancy allowing for social distancing.
Food service establishments starting 5 pm August 7 may serve food and beverages to customers indoors
Fitness center staff and patrons are required to clean equipment and wear face coverings. Total number of people in fitness centers may not exceed 50% maximum capacity
The total number of people in the gaming facility may not exceed 50% of the gaming facility's maximum capacity
Retail establishments and shopping centers cannot exceed 50% of maximum occupancy
Businesses not part of the critical infrastructure sector and not addressed specifically in the order may open at 50% maximum capacity.
Religious facilities may open to the public at 50% maximum occupancy
Starting at 5 pm September 8, indoor recreational establishments are allowed to open at 50% maximum capacity

Personal care facilities that are allowed to open in Baltimore City may not exceed 50% maximum capacity and must keep a record of the name of the client, anyone who accompanied the client, and the service provider. Personal care facilities must clean and disinfect area after serving customer.

Foodservice establishment occupancy may not exceed 50% of establishment's maximum occupancy. Foodservice establishments must require staff to wear facial coverings, not serve food in buffet style, not serve customers who are not seated, and must clean and disinfect tables between seating.
Starting at 5 pm September 8, foodservice establishments are allowed to serve food and beverages in indoor seating areas
Indoor theaters may open to the public. Outdoor entertainment venues may open to the public.
Fitness centers, health clubs, health spas, gyms, aquatic centers, and self defense schools in Baltimore starting 5 pm September 8 may open to the public
Food and agriculture businesses are permitted to remain open. This includes Northeast Market, Lexington Market, Hollins Market, Avenue Market, etc.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Youth sports gatherings are authorized
Libraries may continue to operate with curbside pickup service.

Retail establishments are subject to limited capacity of no more than 50% of maximum occupancy and no more than 5 people per 1000 sq ft. Other guidelines include: no more than 10 people in a breakroom, face masks and social distancing required, enforce surface sanitation, screening procedures for employees, and signage reminding customers to wear masks
The total number of people in the gaming facility may not exceed 50% of the gaming facility's maximum capacity

Foodservice establishments may not exceed 50% maximum capacity in the establishment, may not serve buffet style, must clean and disinfect tables, must require all staff to wear face coverings, and may not serve those who are not seated.
Fitness center staff are required to clean equipment and wear face coverings. Total number of people in fitness centers may not exceed 50% maximum capacity

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: For indoor gatherings, occupancy may not exceed 50% maximum capacity. Indoor and outdoor gatherings require social distancing and face coverings. Large scale community, city, and convention events continue to be prohibited.
Rescinds Mayoral Order of June 22 allowing indoor dining.

Food service establishments operating outdoors must have the proper permits to operate with outdoor seating, seat patrons six feet away from each other (unless from the same household), not allow groups larger than 6 (unless from the same household), require staff to wear face coverings, clean and disinfect surfaces, and not serve in a buffet format
City permits for events will be paused through September 30
Religious facilities will make efforts to clean the facility, require social distancing, and require face coverings except when necessary for religious service.
Indoor recreation areas allowed to open may only at 25% maximum capacity and allow for sufficient social distancing
Retail establishments and shopping centers cannot exceed 25% of maximum occupancy and must allow for social distancing
The total number of people in the gaming facility may not exceed 25% of the gaming facility's maximum capacity and must allow for sufficient social distancing

Food service establishments must close indoor dining at 10 pm, not exceed 25% maximum occupancy, require staff and patrons to wear face coverings, clean and disinfect surfaces, not serve in a buffet format, not serve customers who are not seated, and not serve customers beverages if they are not also ordering food

All senior citizen activity centers must remain closed. Staff and owners may only be on site to facilitate remote working, maintain essential property, performing essential administration functions, or caring for live animals.
Indoor theaters may not exceed 50% maximum occupancy or 100 persons. Outdoor Entertainment Venue may not exceed 50% maximum occupancy or 250 persons.

State and local government buildings/ facilities with an expected occupancy of over 10 people must post a copy of MDH social distancing recommendations and a copy of this Mayoral Executive Order in the building. The facility must also allow occupants the capability to wash their hands.

Indoor gatherings at event venues are limited to 10 people or 25% of the fire marshal-rated maximum occupancy of the venue. If facility can hold multiple events, the capacity limitation applies to each space so that the facility does not exceed 25% maximum capacity at any point.
Religious facilities may open to the public at 25% maximum occupancy

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Spectators at the Baltimore Raven's Stadium is limited to 10% for each designated section of the stadium. Spectators must social distance.
Retail establishments and shopping centers cannot exceed 25% of maximum occupancy

Extension that state and local government buildings/ facilities with an expected occupancy of over 10 people must post a copy of MDH social distancing recommendations and a copy of this Mayoral Executive Order in the building. The facility must also allow occupants the capability to wash their hands.
Starting at 5 pm November 12, indoor recreational establishments are allowed to open at 25% maximum capacity provided that there is sufficient space for social distancing

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Spectators are allowed at sports gatherings provided that event venues are limited to 10 people or 25% of the fire marshal-rated maximum occupancy of the venue. If facility can hold multiple events, the capacity limitation applies to each space so that the facility does not exceed 25% maximum capacity at any point.
Outdoor recreational establishments may open at 25% capacity
Fitness center staff are required to clean equipment between uses. Total number of people in fitness centers may not exceed 25% maximum capacity
Religious facilities will make efforts to clean the facility, require social distancing, and require face coverings except when necessary for religious service.
Businesses not part of the critical infrastructure sector and not addressed specifically in the order may open at 25% maximum capacity.
Outdoor and indoor gatherings are limited to 10 people, and there must be enough space to socially distance.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Youth sports gatherings may have no spectators (except parents/ guardians) and social distancing is required
The total number of people in the gaming facility may not exceed 25% of the gaming facility's maximum capacity

Foodservice establishment occupancy may not exceed 25% of establishment's maximum occupancy in the indoor seating area. Foodservice establishments must close indoor dining at 11 pm, not serve food in buffet style, not serve customers who are not seated, not serve beverages indoors without also serving food, and must clean and disinfect tables between seating.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Extension that all senior citizen activity centers must remain closed. Staff and owners may only be on site to facilitate remote working, maintain essential property, performing essential administration functions, or caring for live animals.
Indoor areas are limited to 25% maximum capacity

Personal care facilities that are allowed to open in Baltimore City may not exceed 25% maximum capacity and must keep a record of the name of the client, anyone who accompanied the client, and the service provider. Personal care facilities must clean and disinfect area after serving customer.
Indoor theaters may not exceed 25% maximum occupancy. Outdoor Entertainment Venue may not exceed 25% maximum occupancy.
Extension allowing religious facilities to operate at 25% of maximum occupancy so long as they make efforts to clean facility between uses, follow face covering order, and social distance.

Extension: Personal services are limited to 25% of maximum occupancy. Services must be provided on an appointment-only basis, a log must be kept of names of customers, staff providing services, and other residents who enter the shop, and staff must wear face coverings at all times when indoors.
Extension: Fitness Centers are limited to 25% of maximum occupancy and patrons must abide by the face covering order.

Indoor Recreational Establishments including bingo halls, bowling alleys, roller and ice skating rinks, social and fraternal clubs, cigar & hookah establishments, and adult entertainment venues must close on December 11, 2020 at 5PM.
Group fitness activities are prohibited.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Sports gatherings at facilities controlled by Rec & Parks are prohibited.

Extension that state and local government buildings/ facilities with an expected occupancy of over 10 people must post a copy of MDH social distancing recommendations and a copy of this Mayoral Executive Order in the building. The facility must also allow occupants the capability to wash their hands.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Extension that senior citizen activity centers must remain closed. Staff and owners may be on site for maintenance purposes only.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor gatherings at public and private facilities will be limited to no more than 25 persons.
Extension: Casinos are limited to 25% of maximum occupancy.
Foodservice Establishments are closed to indoor & outdoor dining but carry-out, delivery and drive-through service may continue.
Extension allowing retail establishments and malls to remain open at 25% of maximum occupancy.
Indoor gatherings at public and private facilities will be limited to no more than 10 persons.
All indoor and outdoor theaters and entertainment venues are prohibited. Live performances and live streamed performances from any venue is prohibited.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Museums, zoos, and aquariums are limited to 25% of maximum occupancy.

Extension: Outdoor Recreational Establishments including golf courses and driving ranges, outdoor archery and shooting ranges, marinas and watercraft rental businesses, campgrounds, horse boarding and riding facilities, outdoor day camps and tour boats are limited to 25% of maximum occupancy.
Fitness centers must close except for those that provide licensed child care services.
Restaurants and bars may only serve food via carryout or delivery. Customers must be off the premises.
All theaters and bingo halls must close.
All government buildings and facilities will be closed to the public with services offered online.
States that the Governor's order issued June 10, 2020 relating to the reopening of certain businesses and facilities, is in effect in the City of Frederick.

States that the Governor's Executive Order 10-09-18-01 is in effect within the City of Frederick, except that foodservice establishments, bars, and event venues must follow certain maximum capacity guidelines.
The Governor's Order No. 20-11-10-01 is in effect in the City of Frederick, and the Mayor's Executive Order No. 20-08 is hereby rescinded.
States that the Governor's Order (20-09-18-01) shall not take effect at this time.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Frederick County allows certain non-essential businesses to re-open and establishes adaptation and mitigation measures that these businesses must uphold.
intended_duration: This order remains in effect until it is superseded, amended, or revised, or until the Governor's Order 20-06-03-01 is no longer in effect (as it be amended from time to time).

policy_description: States that the Governor's Executive Order 20-09-28-01 may take effect in Frederick County, except that foodservice establishments shall not allow the number of persons in the foodservice establishments indoor seating area to exceed 75% of the venue's maximum occupancy.

States that the Governor's Executive Order 20-09-28-01 may take effect in Frederick County, except that bars, nightclubs, and other event venues may not allow the number of persons attending an event exceed 50% of the venue's maximum occupancy.

Directs that the Governor's Executive Order 20-09-18-01 regarding an increase in foodservice establishment capacity shall not take effect in Frederick County at this time. Foodservice Establishment capacity is paused at 50%.

Indoor recreation establishments' occupancy are limited to 50% of the establishment's maximum occupancy unless that occupancy is more than 50 persons, in which case the occupancy is limited to 25% of the establishment's maximum capacity.
Retail establishments may open for curbside service.
Restaurants and bars may now have outdoor dining, so long as tables are 6 feet apart.
Recreational establishments may be open to 50% maximum capacity. Summer and day camps may open for 10 or fewer participants (including leaders) per room and a maximum of 50 people indoors.
Fitness centers may open to 50% capacity.
Only low contact youth sports are allowed. They may resume with no more than 9 children and 1 coach and a maximum of 100 people in an area while maintaining small group size.
Fully automatic car washes and self-service car washes can remain opened.
Farmers markets may now reopen to full capacity.
Places of worship may now open to 50% maximum capacity, and outdoor services of up to 250 people are permissible.
Manufacturers may open to full capacity if social distancing is followed and proper PPE is used.
Restaurants may open outdoor dining as long as social distancing is followed. Indoor dining is also permitted at 50% maximum capacity as long as social distancing is maintained.
All childcare programs may now open to full capacity so long as social distancing is maintained and there are staggered drop-offs and pick-ups.
Barbershops and other personal services may be opened at 50% capacity.
Retail establishments may open to 50% maximum capacity as long as they follow social distancing.
Outdoor swimming pools may open to 25% maximum capacity. Indoor swimming pools remain closed.
Fully automatic and self-service car washes may remain open.
Fitness centers are allowed to open at 50% maximum capacity.
Recreational establishments (such as recreational fishing and outdoor archery) are permitted at 50% of maximum capacity.
Places of worship may open to 50% of maximum capacity indoors or may have outdoors services of 250 people or less.
Manufacturers may continue working as long as PPE is provided to all staff and physical distancing is maintained.
Retail establishments may open to 50% maximum capacity as long as social distancing is maintained and employees and customers are adhering to the face covering order.
Barbershops and other personal services may open to 50% maximum capacity.
Parks and outdoor play equipment shall remain open.
Restaurants and bars are allowed to have outdoor dining (with a maximum of 50 people) and are permitted to have indoor dining at 50% maximum capacity.
Farmers markets are permitted to open at full capacity.
All childcare programs are permitted to open so long as physical distancing is followed and there are staggered drop-offs and pick-ups.
Social and fraternal clubs (such as American Legion posts) may re-open for indoor recreation for up to 50% of maximum capacity.
Fitness centers may open to 50% of maximum capacity.
Recreation facilities will be open on a limited basis. Other recreational establishments like recreational fishing may open to 50% of maximum capacity.
Places of worship may open to 50% of maximum capacity indoors or have outdoor services of 250 people or less.
Barbershops and other personal service facilities may open to 50% of maximum capacity.
Retail stores may open to 50% of maximum capacity.
Restaurants and bars may open to 50% of maximum capacity indoors and full capacity outdoors, as long as social distancing is maintained.
Farmers Markets may open as long as they maintain social distancing.
Fully automatic and self-service car washes can remain open.
Childcare programs may open at full capacity, as long as social distancing is maintained and there are staggered drop-offs and pick-ups.
