Social and fraternal clubs, such as American Legion posts, may open to 50% of maximum capacity indoors.
Manufacturers may open to full capacity as long as social distancing is maintained.
Recreational establishments (such as recreational fishing) may open to 50% of maximum capacity.
Outdoor exercise and outdoor fitness instruction is allowed. All city outdoor play equipment can remain open as can parks.
Medium-risk sports are allowed at this time (this includes soccer, baseball, and lacrosse).
Retail establishments can open to 50% of maximum capacity.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor swimming pools may open to 25% maximum capacity. Indoor pools may open to 50% maximum capacity.
Banquet halls, receptions, and meeting rooms may open to 50% maximum capacity or less than 150 people. No buffets will be allowed.
Places of worship may open for gatherings that do not exceed 50% of maximum capacity or 250 people.
Social and fraternal clubs may open for indoor recreation up to 50% maximum capacity.
Manufacturing may open to full capacity as long as social distancing is enforced.
Barbershops, beauty salons, and other personal services are allowed to open to 50% of maximum capacity.
Fully automatic and self-service car washes can remain open.
Fitness centers may open to 50% of maximum capacity.
Restaurants may open outdoor seating to up to 50 people and indoor dining may resume at 50% maximum capacity.
Childcare programs are open to full capacity.
Farmers Markets will be able to open to full capacity.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All city basketball courts are closed.
Cigar, hookah, and vape establishments may open for retail sales only to 50% of maximum capacity.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Senior Centers will remain closed.
All basketball hoops shall remain closed.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Senior centers, theaters, and concert venues will remain closed.
Summer/day camps may only have 10 or fewer participants. All recreational facilities shall remain closed.
Only low-contact youth sports are allowed at this time, with 9 children and 1 coach per small group. A maximum of 100 people can be in a given area while maintaining small group size.
All gatherings, whether it be social, community, religious, etc., are limited to one person/family unit per 200 square feet, or a maximum of 100 persons (whichever is lower).
All basketball courts remain closed.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All outdoor swimming pools may open to 25% of maximum capacity. Indoor pools are to remain closed.
Non-essential businesses shall remain closed to the general public. This includes senior centers, theaters, and concert venues.
Non-essential businesses shall remain closed, including senior centers, theaters, and concert venues.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor pools may open to 25% of maximum capacity. Indoor pools must remain closed.
All parks will remain open as long as social distancing is able to be maintained. However, basketball courts must remain closed.
Large gatherings and events are limited to one person/family unit per 200 square feet or a maximum of 100 persons (whichever is lower).
Only low-contact youth sports are allowed at this time. These sports may resume in small groups, no more than 9 children and 1 coach.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: All non-essential businesses are to remain closed. Senior centers, theaters, and concert venues are also closed.

Indoor dining is prohibited. Restaurants may open only if food is to be taken from the premises, delivered to customers off the premises, or outdoor seating is available that does not exceed 50% maximum capacity and no more than 6 people sit at one table (unless it is one household).
Gaming facilities and casinos may operate at 25% of maximum capacity.
Retail establishments may open as long as there is only one person/household per 200 square feet, or a maximum capacity of 25%, whichever is lower.

Restaurants and bars must collect the name and contact information of at least one person in each dine-in party, and must maintain this information for at least 30 days in order to assist contact tracers.

In response to a memorandum issued by the Secretary of the Maryland Department of Health on August 6, 2020, which prohibited the blanket closure on nonpublic schools, the Montgomery County Health Officer rescinded his order closing nonpublic schools.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: The list of businesses required to remain closed is shortened, now only explicitly including senior citizen activities centers, theaters, recreational facilities (including amusement parks), and certain personal care businesses.
The limit on mass gatherings is raised to 50; gatherings must still meet other distancing requirements.
The list of businesses required to remain closed is shortened, now only explicitly including senior citizen activities centers, theaters, and recreational facilities (including amusement parks).
The ban on mass gatherings over 50 is continued; however, outdoor religious gatherings are now permitted to have up to 150 participants. All gatherings must still meet other distancing requirements.

The ban on mass gatherings over 50 is continued and is now expanded to apply to athletic events; outdoor religious gatherings of up to 150 participants continue to be permissible. All gatherings must still meet other distancing requirements.

The list of businesses required to remain closed is shortened, now only explicitly including senior citizen activities centers, theaters, and certain recreational facilities (including amusement parks).

The ban on mass gatherings over 50 is continued, with up to 150 individuals permitted at outdoor religious gatherings absent special approval from the county; for indoor religious gatherings and approved outdoor religious gatherings, there is no longer a limit on gathering size, though occupancy limits and other distancing requirements apply. All gatherings must still meet certain distancing requirements.
Theaters, senior citizen activities centers, and certain recreational facilities (including amusement parks) must remain closed.

The ban on mass gatherings over 50 is continued, with up to 150 individuals permitted at outdoor religious gatherings absent special approval from the county; for indoor religious gatherings and approved outdoor religious gatherings, there is no limit on gathering size, though occupancy limits and other distancing requirements apply. All gatherings must still meet certain distancing requirements.

Continuation: restaurants and bars may not serve alcohol after 10pm, must continue to limit indoor dining to only at 50%, and must continue other adaptation/mitigation measures. However, restaurants and bars may now apply for a permit to serve alcohol between 10pm and midnight, contingent on low transmission levels of COVID-19 in the county.
Theaters, senior citizen activities centers, and certain recreational facilities (including amusement parks) must continue to remain closed.
Theaters, senior citizen activities centers, and certain recreational facilities (including amusement parks) must continue to remain closed.
Inmates may not receive outside visitors and outside programs are stopped; inmates instead receive two free 15-minute phone calls per week.
The Department of Correction and Rehabilitation has implemented various distancing and sanitation measures at its facilities.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Grocery stores, pharmacies, and large retail chains must (a) have customers and employees wear face masks, (b) establish occupancy limits and outside queues, (c) provide masks and hand-washing supplies to employees, (d) establish physical distancing signage and measures, and (e) adhere to state and local sanitation requirements.
All government buildings with an expected occupancy of 10 or more must post social distancing requirements and facilitate hand-washing.
Required adaptation measures (including occupancy limits) are strengthened for a broad swath of businesses, and additional requirements are established for all businesses.
Restaurants must only allow indoor dining at 50% capacity, and must take other adaptation/mitigation measures.
All businesses must have customers and employees maintain 6 feet of distance wherever possible.
Nonpublic schools are not permitted to open until August 1, 2020.
Required adaptation/mitigation measures (including occupancy limits), both for all open businesses and for specific industries, are updated and continued.
With various technical amendments and clarifications, nonpublic schools are not permitted to open until August 1, 2020.
All businesses must continue to have customers and employees maintain 6 feet of distance wherever possible.
Restaurants and bars newly may not serve alcohol after 10pm; they must continue to limit indoor dining to 50% capacity, and must continue other adaptation/mitigation measures.
Required adaptation/mitigation measures (including occupancy limits), for all open businesses and for specific industries, are updated and continued.
Continuation: restaurants and bars may not serve alcohol after 10pm, must continue to allow indoor dining at only up to 50% capacity, and must continue other adaptation/mitigation measures.
All businesses must continue to have customers and employees maintain 6 feet of distance wherever possible.
All businesses must continue to have customers and employees maintain 6 feet of distance wherever possible.
Required adaptation/mitigation measures (including occupancy limits), for all open businesses and for specific industries, are continued with limited modifications.
Continuation: restaurants and bars may not serve alcohol after 10pm, must continue to allow indoor dining at only up to 50% capacity, and must continue other adaptation/mitigation measures.
Required adaptation/mitigation measures (including occupancy limits), for all open businesses and for specific industries, are continued.
All businesses must continue to have customers and employees maintain 6 feet of distance wherever possible.

Continuation with modifications: restaurants and bars may not serve alcohol after 10pm, must continue to limit indoor dining to only at 50%, and must continue other adaptation/mitigation measures. The previous program allowing restaurants and bars to apply to serve alcohol after 10pm is ended.

Continuation with modifications: restaurants and bars may not serve alcohol after 10pm, must continue to limit indoor dining to only at 50%, and must continue other adaptation/mitigation measures. The previous program allowing restaurants and bars to apply to serve alcohol after 10pm is ended.

Gatherings of over 25 individuals are prohibited, with up to 150 individuals permitted at outdoor religious gatherings absent special approval from the county; for indoor religious gatherings and approved outdoor religious gatherings, there is no absolute limit on gathering size, though gatherings may not exceed 25% of normal occupancy or one person per 50 square feet. All gatherings must still meet certain distancing requirements.

Required adaptation/mitigation measures (including occupancy limits) continue for all open businesses and for specific industries, with occupancy limits lowered to 25% of capacity in a large swath of businesses (restaurants, gyms, retail, etc.).
All businesses must continue to have customers and employees maintain 6 feet of distance wherever possible.

The indoor cap on gatherings is lowered to 10 individuals, while the outdoor cap remains at 25 individuals. Up to 150 individuals remain permitted at outdoor religious gatherings absent special approval from the county; for indoor religious gatherings and approved outdoor religious gatherings, there is no absolute limit on gathering size, though gatherings may not exceed 25% of normal occupancy or one person per 50 square feet. All gatherings must still meet certain distancing requirements.

The Prince George's County Health Department is partnership with local entities to open a pilot COVID-19 assessment and screening location in Landover, Maryland. This site is a screening area that will have limited testing capabilities for those who meet stringent CDC testing guidelines.
Prince George's County is expanding its screening and testing operations.
Prince George's County opens a second free community COVID-19 testing site.

Prince George's County Health Department will end community COVID-19 testing at 3 temporary locations and begin expanding the number of partner test sites across the county. COVID-19 testing from the Health Department remains free and no appointment needed.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Restaurants/bars; Manufacturers; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Personal care facilities; Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Retail establishments can open with 50% capacity, and restaurants can provide indoor dining at 50% maximum capacity. Manufacturing can continue with physical distancing and PPE, fitness centers can open with 50% capacity, and childcare programs are allowed to open with limited capacity and PPE. Beauty salons, barbershops, and other personal services are allowed to open with restriction on operating capacity.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Restaurants/bars; Manufacturers; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Personal care facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: This policy extends the previous order. Retail establishments can open with 50% capacity, and restaurants can provide indoor dining at 50% maximum capacity. Manufacturing can continue with physical distancing and PPE, fitness centers can open with 50% capacity, and childcare programs are allowed to open with limited capacity and PPE. Beauty salons, barbershops, and other personal services are allowed to open with restriction on operating capacity.

This press release allows the opening of banquet halls, hookah and vape establishments, tanning salons, and indoor pools at 50% capacity. Youth sports defined as "medium risk" may resume in small groups.
This directive closes all programs and events in Maryland National parks. Trails and playgrounds will remain open.
This directive suspends all visitation with the exception of attorney/legal visits. All volunteer services are suspended, and inmate programs within the jail are canceled.
This directive requires teleworking for non-essential employees for all County agencies. The County buildings will also be restricting County employees.
This directive suspends all non-essential community meetings.
The Prince George's County Government are limited to essential functions only.
Senior centers, theaters, nightclubs, and concern venues must remain closed.
This policy orders that  social, community, spiritual, religious, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events ("large gatherings and events") are limited to a maximum of 50 persons

This policy clarifies and extends requirements related to mask wearing. This policy also orders appropriate distancing measures in all businesses, sanitization, capacity limits, and recommended plexiglass installment.
Prince George's County is to remain in Phase 2 of reopening. There is guidance on Thanksgiving travels. The county relaunched  the Emergency Rental Assistance Program (ERAP).

The Prince George's County Health Department releases Halloween guidance and offers tips for safer activities. The Health Department is not allowing indoor haunted houses and does not recommend tradition door-to-door trick-or-treating this year.

Prince George's County will stay in Phase 2 of reopening with some restrictions:   All indoor public businesses or establishments that are already open under the County’s phase 2 of reopening, with the exception of essential businesses and retail stores, must reduce capacity limits to a maximum of 25% capacity.   Gathering sizes are further limited.  The County Executive also announced details of the $6 million Restaurant Resiliency Fund

Prince George’s County Executive Angela Alsobrooks announced today that Health Officer Dr. Ernest Carter has issued a Health Directive and Order imposing a curfew at National Harbor for unaccompanied minors (ages 17 and under) beginning Friday, November 20 at 5:00 PM.
Events in Braintree town properties will be postponed or cancelled
The library is closed, along with other town events.
Local Special Election in Braintree Postponed (originally dated for 3/28/2020)
Licensees offering food for take-out or delivery have been deemed essential and may continue operations pursuant to the Order and the Advisory.
Restaurants may only sell wine or malt beverages for off-premise consumption. Spirits may not be sold for off premise consumption.

Announcement that the Board voted to pass an emergency amendment to its General Rules codifying its existing administrative review of temporary extensions of licensed premise onto outdoor space using its existing One Day Amendment to Existing License Application

Announcement that the Board voted to administratively lift citywide the preexisting condition of "alcohol with food only" on outdoor space or any other similar condition that prohibits the sale and service of alcohol on outdoor space without the service of a food item.
Neither standing nor sitting at the bar area is permitted.

Upon commencing outdoor table service, Licensees must ensure that there is a minimum of six (6) feet of separation between tables and high foot traffic areas at all times and that each party consists of no more than six (6) individuals.
All patrons must be seated at tables

Licensees must abide by all terms of both the Massachusetts Restaurants COVID-19 Checklist and the Massachusetts Restaurants Safety Standards issued by the Commonwealth. These documents provide mandatory standards critical to a safe reopening including social distancing, staffing, operations, cleaning, disinfecting, hygiene protocols, and other safety standards

Licensees must complete the self certification process mandated by the state prior to commencing outdoor table service. The required COVID-19 poster must be signed and conspicuously posted in an area visible to both patrons and employees.

Licensees must abide by all terms of both the Massachusetts Restaurants COVID-19 Checklist and the Massachusetts Restaurants Safety Standards issued by the Commonwealth. These documents provide mandatory standards critical to a safe reopening including social distancing, staffing, operations, cleaning, disinfecting, hygiene protocols, and other safety standards.

Licensees must complete the self certification process mandated by the state prior to commencing outdoor table service. The required COVID-19 poster must be signed and conspicuously posted in an area visible to both patrons and employees.
Beer gardens may open if they have seated food service. Patrons must remain seated and adhere to all social distancing guidelines
Restaurants can open indoor dining with restrictions.
Neither standing nor sitting at the bar area is permitted. The bar area may be repurposed to provide seated dining by patrons pursuant to the requirements herein.

No Licensee may exceed the approved capacity listed on its Certificate of Inspection issued by the Inspectional Services Department. Additional guidance from the Board regarding capacity, the required Certificate of Inspection, and the required Fire Assembly Permit is forthcoming.
Licensees may operate pursuant to their existing hours of operation approved by the Board.

Licensees must abide by all terms of both the Massachusetts Restaurants COVID-19 Checklist and the Massachusetts Restaurants Safety Standards issued by the Commonwealth. These documents provide mandatory standards critical to a safe reopening including social distancing, staffing, operations, cleaning, disinfecting, hygiene protocols, and other safety standards
All patrons must be seated at tables and food service must be available.

Licensees must complete the self certification process mandated by the state prior to commencing indoor or outdoor table service if the same has not previously been completed. The required COVID-19 poster must be signed and conspicuously posted in an area visible to both patrons and employees.

Upon commencing indoor table service, Licensees must ensure that there is a minimum of six (6) feet of separation between tables and high foot traffic areas at all times and that each party consists of no more than six (6) individuals. Tables may be positioned closer only if separated by protective non-porous barriers at least six (6) feet in height installed between tables and high foot traffic areas.

Any Licensee previously approved by the Board and the Mayor’s Office of Consumer Affairs and Licensing (“MOCAL”) to provide live entertainment indoors,  must provide a written safety and operations plan to the Board for review and approval prior to commencing any operations. The Licensee also must provide a summary explaining whether the offering of live entertainment is the primary purpose of its operation. Live entertainment includes any entertainment other than background music and televisions including, but not limited to, lawn games, trivia, comedy, acoustic performances, and amplified performances. Dance floors and dancing by patrons is not permitted.

Any event for which the primary purpose is viewing entertainment must follow the Commonwealth’s guidance regarding theaters and performances as well as the requirements in this Advisory. No indoor performances are permitted.

The capacity for any proposed indoor special event is limited to eight (8) individuals per one thousand (1,000) square feet of accessible space in the  specific room or otherwise enclosed space but never more than twenty five (25) individuals in a single enclosed indoor space. All attendees must be seated, tables must be separated by a minimum of six (6) feet, and the maximum number of individuals to a table is six (6) including children. The only permissible form of entertainment is background music or television.

Licensees providing outdoor live entertainment must have at least 25 feet between performers and the audience, and at least ten feet between performers. Groups are limited to parties of ten, and each party must be separated by at least 6 feet. All patrons must be seated, and no standing or dancing is permitted. There cannot be interaction between performers and patrons.
Low and moderate contact amateur sporting events (ex. baseball, softball) may have a maximum of 50 individuals.

In addition to all COVID-19 related guidance and the maximum capacity requirements issued by the City and noted herein, all outdoor events and amateur sports must follow all other existing permitting and licensing requirements.

Licensees must abide by any and all rules, regulations, advisories, orders, guidance, or laws promulgated or adopted by City, state, or federal government as the same may be amended from time to time including but not limited to the General Rules of the Board, the Commonwealth's Guidance, and the Center for Disease Control’s standards regarding social distancing

Outdoor theater and performance venues, indoor movie theaters, and bowling alleys may open. Indoor theater and performance venues remain closed. Large capacity event venues and those theaters and performance venues (ex. stadiums, arenas, ballparks, exhibition and convention halls, nightclubs etc.) not providing food service at tables must remain closed.
If the primary purpose of the Licensee is to provide entertainment it must adhere to the Commonwealth’s guidelines for COVID-19 safety and operation procedures for theaters and performance venues.
Waivers may be permitted to allow a maximum of 100 individuals with the submission of a health, safety and operations plan to the Board.
Outdoor events on City property and events with Special Event Committee review and approval may have a maximum capacity of 50 individuals.
Only non-live entertainment consisting of televisions and background music is permitted inside of licensed premises
Indoor movie theaters may open at 40% of permitted capacity. Outdoor space for performance venues are permitted to open at 25%.

Businesses deemed essential include grocery stores, gas stations, pharmacies, retail package stores, and licensed medical marijuana establishments and, as such, must limit the total number of individuals to ten (10) at all times including staff.

Businesses deemed essential include grocery stores, gas stations, pharmacies, retail package stores, and licensed medical marijuana establishments and, as such, may remain in operation during normal business hours at this time.
Any restriction or regulation prohibiting take-out or delivery of food is temporarily lifted.
All establishments must abide by the CDC’s social distancing guidelines.
Guests, owners, and employees of Lodging Units must abide by the CDC’s social distancing guidelines.
Guests with future reservations to occupy a Lodging Unit not related to a purpose deemed a COVID-19 Essential Service may not fulfil those reservations.

Guests that are occupying a Lodging Unit as of March 31, 2020, for a purpose other than those deemed a COVID-19 Essential Service in the Guidance may remain in the Lodging Unit until the end of the scheduled duration but may not extend the duration unless it is for a purpose deemed a COVID-19 Essential Service.
Lodging Units may only be offered or operated for efforts related to COVID-19 and the ongoing public health crisis.

In section 2, "On-site activities at hospitality, educational, sports and entertainment, venues, businesses, and facilities with an occupancy limit of 1,500 or greater are directed to remain closed to the public; online activities, deliveries, and other business functions can continue to operate" has been omitted.

Essential businesses may remain open, subject to conditions set forth in this order and previous orders including but not limited to adhering to  proper social distancing and face mask guidelines; businesses such as grocery stores and pharmacies should make best efforts to establish hours during which their services are available to high at-risk populations such as the elderly

policy_description: Educational institutions, public, and private K-12 schools, private colleges and universities, trade schools, post-secondary and technical colleges can remain open, subject to conditions in Nashville's plan for a safe, efficient, and equitable return to school

Restaurants and bars serving food from a menu may operate at 75% or less of occupancy subject to the conditions set forth in Section 4 of this order. Bars not serving food and social clubs may operate at 50% capacity subject to conditions set forth in Section 5.

Essential businesses may remain open, subject to conditions set forth in this order and previous orders including but not limited to adhering to  proper social distancing and face mask guidelines; businesses such as grocery stores and pharmacies should make best efforts to establish hours during which their services are available to high at-risk populations such as the elderly

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Public services; Private sector; General population (inclusive); Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education; Minors and children
policy_description: Educational institutions, public, and private K-12 schools, private colleges and universities, trade schools, post-secondary and technical colleges can remain open, subject to conditions in Nashville's plan for a safe, efficient, and equitable return to school

A Limited Service restaurant may operate at the lesser of 50% of the maximum capacity or 25 patrons on premises. Full service restaurants may operate at the lesser of 50% of the max capacity or 100 patrons per floor, subject to conditions set forth in this order including but not limited to: no more than 6 people to a party, customers shall remain seated except when going to the bathroom or exiting or entering the premises, bar counters must be closed to the public, no self-serve food or condiment station, etc. Bars may operate at the lesser of 50% of the max capacity or 25 patrons on premises, subject to the conditions in this order, partially described above.

Sexually oriented businesses or establishments may operate at the lesser of 50% of the maximum capacity or 25 patrons on premises, provided the business equally distributes patrons throughout the entire amount of space, and complies with the following conditions

A Limited Service restaurant may operate not exceeding 50 patrons on premises, provided the max number allowed INDOORS is the lesser of 50% of 25 patrons. Full service restaurants may operate at the lesser of 50% of the max capacity or 100 patrons per floor, subject to conditions set forth in this order including but not limited to: no more than 6 people to a party, customers shall remain seated except when going to the bathroom or exiting or entering the premises, bar counters must be closed to the public, no self-serve food or condiment station, etc  Bars can operate at 50% capacity or 50 patrons indoor and 50 patrons outdoor. Bar counter areas at restaurants may open to the public at 50% or less of seated counter capacity - no customer is allowed to stand at bar.

Notwithstanding Section 1 in this Order, community, civic or sporting events; parades, concerts, festivals, conventions, fundraisers, private gatherings and similar activities, whether held on private property or at venues, businesses, or facilities for rent or open to the public, are allowed at 30% or less of building occupancy up to a maximum of 125 people

Limited service restaurants may operate not exceeding 50 patrons on premises, provided the maximum number of patrons allowed indoors is the lesser of 50% of the maximum capacity or 25 patrons Full service restaurants may operate at 50% of the max capacity or 100 patrons per floor subject to conditions including the following: 6 people or less per party; Bar counter areas may open to the public at 50% or less of seated counter capacity. Bars may operate not exceeding 50 patrons on premises, provided the maximum number of patrons allowed indoors is the lesser of 50% of the maximum capacity authorized by Tennessee’s Building and Fire Code or 25 patrons. All customers must be off the premises of all such establishments between 10:30p.m. and 5:00 a.m. Takeout and delivery services can continue to operate except that take-out, window, or curb-side delivery and sale of alcohol shall be prohibited between that time window.

Businesses holding a certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the Metropolitan Transportation Licensing Commission and limousines may operate at 50% capacity operating passenger vehicles for hire more up to a maximum of 10 people; businesses that are designed to transport more than 15 passengers may operate at: 1. 50% capacity up to a maximum of 25 people, provided the vehicle is equipped with seats attached to the vehicle, and all passengers remain seated except when loading or unloading; or 2. A maximum of 10 people of the same party if any passenger is allowed to stand.  Businesses or individuals subject to the provisions in this paragraph shall comply with the conditions in the third paragraph in this Section including but not limited to: no alcohol shall be consumed by any person in or on the vehicle; all passengers shall be off the vehicle and the business closed to the public between 1030 p.m. and 5:00 a.m.; all passengers must load at and be returned to the same location with no stops for establishments that sell or serve food or beverage. Public transportation may continue to operate.

Limited service and full service restaurants, bars, social clubs, and sexually oriented businesses may remain open to the public after 10:30 p.m. on September 14, 2020 until 30 minutes after the conclusion of the NFL game between the Tennessee Titans and the Denver Broncos.

Limited service restaurants may operate at up to 50 patrons per floor and 50 patrons outdoors, the total number on premises not to exceed 50% of te max capacity. Full service restaurants may operate at 50% of the max capacity or 100 patrons per floor subject to conditions including the following: 6 people or less per party; Bar counter areas may open to the public at 50% or less of seated counter capacity. Bars may operate not exceeding 50 patrons per floor and 50 patrons outdoors, provided the maximum number of total patrons is the lesser of 50% of the maximum capacity authorized by Tennessee’s Building and Fire Codes. All customers must be off the premises of all such establishments between 11:00p.m. and 5:00 a.m. Takeout and delivery services can continue to operate except that take-out, window, or curb-side delivery and sale of alcohol shall be prohibited between that time window.

Notwithstanding Section 1 in this Order, community, civic or sporting events; parades, concerts, festivals, conventions, fundraisers, private gatherings and similar activities, whether held on private property or at venues, businesses, or facilities for rent or open to the public, are allowed at 30% or less of building occupancy up to a maximum of 125 people

Close contact personal care and appearance services may open to the public at 50% or less of occupancy . Appointments or similar methods for customer entry should be required. Gymnasiums and fitness facilities can also open at 50% capacity subject to conditions set forth in Section 5 of Order 12 including but not limited to the following: social distancing extended to a minimum of 10 feet (except low intensity aerobic activities) and no steam room or sauna allowed; sports and recreation leagues may resume, provided that they abide by crowd size limitation and distancing guidelines. If gym serves food, number of customers should be limited to 50% for each dining area

Retail stores may operate at 75% or less of store occupancy subject to the conditions set forth in section 3 of order 7, including but not limited to: food and beverage dining areas in retail and commercial businesses must limit the number of customers to 75% of max occupancy

Those at high risk are still urged to shelter at home; crowd sizes of more than 25 people are prohibited except for places of worship and as otherwise specified in Order 12. Outdoor recreational parks and activities can continue to operate, though social distancing and mask wearing guidelines should be adhered to and crowd-size should be limited

Bar counter areas at restaurants may open to the public at 50% or less of seated counter capacity - no customer is allowed to stand at bar.

All customers shall be off premises and the premises closed to the public between 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. Takeout, delivery, and sale of prepared food or non-alcoholic beverages may remain open and may continue to operate after 11:00 pm - sale of alcohol is prohibited, except when sold for consumption on premises or for off-premise delivery

Institutes testing requirements for long-term care facilities. The facility should begin testing at the frequency prescribed in the Routine Testing Table (in document) based on the county 7-day rolling average positivity rate.   Asymptomatic staff and residents who have recovered from COVID-19 infection do not need to be tested within 3 months unless they become symptomatic again.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Requires procedure for certain elderly care facilities to perform molecular testing on all of their employees: A. Molecular testing shall be performed every other week on all staff who have never tested positive for COVID-19. B. Molecular testing shall be performed every other week until all staff members test negative. C. If, or once all, staff tests negative, then molecular testing should be performed monthly for a period of three (3) months. D. A determination regarding the continuation of staff testing shall be made by the Local Health Authority after the third month of testing after consideration of the prevalence of COVID-19 cases in the County of El Paso. E. Facilities are required to keep a record of their testing data, including dates of testing, the names of staff members, and staff test results. Such data must be provided to the Local Health Authority for use by the Local Health Authority in determining the need for continued testing pursuant to paragraph 1 (D), above

Facilities which have all residents and staff test negative after conducting baseline testing should only perform monthly testing for 3 months. If a facility identifies a positive case, they should perform weekly testing.

An individual that receives a positive COVID-19 test result but that has not yet been contacted by the City’s Department of Public Health within 24 hours of receiving the laboratory results, must isolate, and those from within their household must quarantine, and report to (915) 212-6520 within 24 hours of receiving the positive test result.   Healthcare workers and first responders should follow the current Department of Public Health’s Guidelines for Healthcare Workers and First Responders, as published on epstrong.org.

Institutes testing requirements for long-term care facilities. The facility should begin testing at the frequency prescribed in the Routine Testing Table (in document) based on the county 7-day rolling average positivity rate.   Asymptomatic staff and residents who have recovered from COVID-19 infection do not need to be tested within 3 months unless they become symptomatic again.

Terminates previous order from 6/29/20. All permitted Outdoor Mass Gatherings in the city-county area must comply with the Texas Governor's Executive Orders, minimum standard health protocols, and state and federal agency guidelines.

Terminates previous order from 6/29/20. All permitted Parades and other Outdoor Markets in the city-county area must comply with the Texas Governor's Executive Orders, minimum standard health protocols, and state and federal agency guidelines.

Terminates previous order from 6/29/20. All permitted Outdoor Markets in the city-county area must comply with the Texas Governor's Executive Orders, minimum standard health protocols, and state and federal agency guidelines.
Requires employers to make certain prevention materials available for staff, to display educational materials, to train employees how to use certain equipment (gloves, masks, etc.)

For discontinuation of self-isolation, the Local Health Authority requires the use of the symptom-based method for those with symptoms during their infection or the time-based method for those who tested positive without symptoms. The test-based method is no longer recommended by the CDC.
Requires employers to conduct health screenings on employees/contractors; they are required to send home anyone who has symptoms and ask them to test for COVID-19

Requires shelters to take all preventative measures necessary to protect residents, such as monitoring symptoms, quarantine of symptomatic patients and isolation, cleaning and disinfecting policy, and requiring social distancing.
Facilities must completely decontaminate after a cluster of positive cases has been identified. Financial support can be offered (email for consideration).
Renews Emergency Ordinance No. 019036 and amends its Section 4 to allow for virtual City Council meetings to be held at 3:30PM on Mondays and Tuesdays.
Terminates the Local Health Authority Orders for All Independent School Districts and Private Schools in El Paso County for Reopening On-Campus Instruction, issued on 8/20/20
Requires El Paso County Election Administrator to adopt and implement a health screening policy for staff and poll workers based on symptoms.

Health care workers are permitted to enter faciliites as long as they are not subject to a work exclusion due to COVID-19 exposure or show signs/symptoms of COVID-19 after screening. EMS personnel do not need to be screened.

Prohibits visitation except for Compassionate Care Visitation (CCV). Visits are only allowed following facilities' COVID-19 infection control plan. Facilities may still restrict CCV according to reasonable clinical or safety causes.
Dine-in restaurant services must close after 10PM, but may continue as take-out. They may resume at 6AM.
The City will begin a safe and phased reopening of some City facilities, such as parks, tennis courts, basketball courts, pools, the soo, public museums, and public libraries.

Renews Emergency Ordinance No. 019036 and amends several sections:  Section 2: Suspends all City board and commission meetings. Any boards that meet should obey the Texas Open Meetings Act and attempt to reduce in person meetings.

Arcades must remain closed. Restaurants may remain open (as according to Health Authority).
Parades and outdoor gatherings limited to 10 people.

- Schools cannot re-open on-campus, face-to-face instruction until after 9/7/20. Schools will create their own plans for re-opening on-campus activities.   - Children with special healthcare needs that are considered medically fragile will not return to on-campus instruction until 2021-2022. - Extra curricular sports shall not take place until reopened.

Prohibits visitation except for Compassionate Care Visitation (CCV). Visits are only allowed following facilities' COVID-19 infection control plan. Facilities may still restrict CCV according to reasonable clinical or safety causes.

Requires adherence to CMS Opening Up American Guidance Phase I:  - Visitation is prohibited, except for compassionate care situations. In those situations, visitors must be screened, wear a face mask, and follow all social distancing/hygiene procedures.  - Restricted entry of non-essential healthcare personnel - Limited communal dining. Residents may eat in the same room if socially distanced.  - Avoid non-medically necessary trips. If necessary, resident must wear a face mask and facility must share the resident's COVID-19 status with transportation. - All persons entering the facility must be screened for symptoms and wear a face mask - All staff must be tested weekly - Dedicate space in facility for cohorting and managing care for residents with COVID-19

- Schools cannot re-open on-campus, face-to-face instruction until after 9/7/20. Schools will create their own plans for re-opening on-campus activities.   - Children with special healthcare needs that are considered medically fragile will not return to on-campus instruction until 2021-2022. - Extra curricular sports shall not take place until reopened.

Declares 50% of normal operating limits (as determined by owner) for outdoor professional and similar sporting events (like rodeos). No spectators may attend with the exception of professional sporting events.
Amusement parks shall operate at no more than 50% of the normal operating limits as determined by the owner.

People may not visit nursing homes, state supported living centers, assisted living facilities, or long-term care facilities. These facilities should follow infection control policies and practices set forth by HHSC, including minimizing the movement of staff between facilities whenever possible.
Every business establishment in Texas shall operate at no more than 50% of the total listed occupancy of the establishment, unless specific exemptions.

Individuals cannot be in groups larger than 10 (including their own household) and should maintain 6 feet of social distancing from those not in their household. No home gatherings with those not in their household.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: People over the age of 65 are strongly encouraged to stay at home as much as possible; to maintain appropriate distance from any member of the household who has been out of the residence in the previous 14 days; and if leaving home, to follow social distancing rules and to practice good hygiene, environmental cleanliness, and sanitation.

Allows the following businesses to operate at up to 75% of total occupancy of the establishment, except for those in  In  areas with with  high hospitalizations: a. In-store, non-CISA retail establishments; b. Dine-in restaurants (<51% gross receipts from alcohol) c. Non-CISA office buildings; d. Museums and libraries; and e. Gyms and exercise facilities and classes.  "Areas with high hospitalizations" means any Trauma Service Area that has had seven consecutive days in which the number of COVID-19 hospitalized patients as a percentage of all hospitalized patients exceeds 15 percent, until such time as the Trauma Service Area has seven consecutive days in which the number of COVID-19 hospitalized patients as a percentage of all hospitalized patients is 15 percent or less. A current list of areas with high hospitalizations will be maintained at https:/,\vww .dshs.texas.gov/ga303 I/.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities; Churches/places of worship; Outdoor recreation or space; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Non-essential businesses are allowed to be open at 50% capacity, except for (no capacity restrictions): - religious services - local government operations - child-care services - youth camps - outdoor recreational sports programs - public or private schools/higher education institutions - drive-in concerts, movies, etc - personal care services (must implement social distancing between stations)

Individuals that are not employees, vendors, or medical personnel shall not visit nursing homes, state supported living centers, assisted living facilities, or long-term care facilities. Nursing homes, state supported living centers, assisted living facilities, and long-term care facilities should follow infection control policies and practices set forth by HHSC, including minimizing the movement of staff between facilities whenever possible

In order for the Medical Examiner’s Office, local hospitals, and mortuary services to respond to the overwhelming strain and high number of deaths related to COVID-19 in El Paso County it is STRONGLY RECOMMENDED AND URGED that, - individuals make funeral arrangements within 15 days - funeral homes limit guest capacity to 10 individuals from the same household.

There is no occupancy limit for outdoor areas, events, or establishments, with the exception of the following outdoor areas, events, or establishments that may operate at no more than 50 percent of the normal operating limits as determined by the owner: - Amusement parks - Water parks - swimming pools - museums and libraries - zoos and similar facilities  All outdoor professional and similar sporting events, including rodeos and equestrian events, shall remain limited to 50% of the normal operating limits as determined by the owner. No spectators may attend sporting events unless they are professional sporting events

An individual that receives a positive COVID-19 test result but that has not yet been contacted by the City’s Department of Public Health within 24 hours of receiving the laboratory results, are strongly encouraged to isolate, and those from within their household should quarantine, and report to (915) 212-6520 within 24 hours of receiving the positive test result. Healthcare workers and first responders should follow the current Department of Public Health’s Guidelines for Healthcare Workers and First Responders, as published on epstrong.org
A curfew shall be imposed between the hours of 10:00 PM to 5:00 AM for all social activities.  Curfew restrictions shall end at 5:00 AM on Monday, November 30, 2020.

All restaurant dine-in services, to include outdoor service, such as on a patio or similar seating area, shall end at 9PM, but restaurants may continue to operate after 9PM via take out and drive thru only. Restaurants may resume dine-in services, to include outdoor service, beginning at 6AM. All restaurants are strongly encouraged and urged to offer only curbside or take-out services.

All County parks, and recreational areas shall close. Hiking, biking, walking and fishing shall be allowed, but all social distancing measures to include the use of face coverings shall be followed and will be enforced. This shall include the closure of County owned golf courses, handball courts, basketball courts, tennis courts, and pools. All tournaments and special events at parks and recreation areas shall be cancelled and prohibited during this period.   It is highly encouraged/recommended that school districts suspend all extracurricular activities

All individuals within the county are strongly urged to shelter at home and maintain physical distancing. Residents 65 years and older are particularly encouraged to stay at home. Individuals that leave homes shall limit their visit to one member of the household

Highly encourages and recommends that all commercial non-essential businesses cease all in-person activities.

I, GREG ABBOTT, Governor of Texas, under the authority vested in me by the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas, do hereby suspend Sections 41.007(d) and 41.008 of the Texas Election Code to the extent necessary to allow the City of Sundown to order its special election, to occur on July 14, 2020, as an emergency election on the question of whether to reauthorize a local street maintenance program. I further suspend Section 85.001(a) of the Texas Election Code to the extent necessary to allow early voting by personal appearance for the special election to begin not earlier than Monday, July 6, 2020, and to run concurrently with the early voting period for the runoff primary election.

local_area: Carbon County, UT; Summit County, UT; Uintah County, UT; San Juan County, UT; Sanpete County, UT; Grand County, UT; Garfield County, UT; Beaver County, UT; Sevier County, UT; Weber County, UT; Davis County, UT; Wasatch County, UT; Washington County, UT; Cache County, UT; Emery County, UT; Morgan County, UT; Box Elder County, UT; Duchesne County, UT; Utah County, UT; Salt Lake County, UT; Tooele County, UT; Juab County, UT
policy_description: Continuation: In high transmission counties, social gatherings (i.e. all gatherings except educational and religious gatherings) are capped at 10 individuals. Event hosts must have attendees maintain six feet of distance, unless the local county executive waives this requirement.

local_area: Davis County, UT; Carbon County, UT; Wasatch County, UT; Utah County, UT; Washington County, UT; Cache County, UT; Sanpete County, UT; Morgan County, UT; Summit County, UT; Salt Lake County, UT; Grand County, UT; Tooele County, UT; Box Elder County, UT; Iron County, UT; Weber County, UT; Rich County, UT; San Juan County, UT; Juab County, UT
policy_description: Continuation: in jurisdictions in the Yellow Phase (now including Salt Lake City but no longer including Sevier County), mass gathering restrictions require formal event venues to fill out a plan and take various steps toward social distancing. Mass gatherings restrictions allow individuals and entertainment and event venues to host up to 3000 attendees (6000 when outdoors) without the need to keep 6 feet of distance between attendees (so long as masks are worn and other precautions are taken). For gatherings hosted by individuals that do not take these extra precautions, mass gatherings of up to 50 are allowed, subject to distancing guidelines.

local_area: Davis County, UT; Carbon County, UT; Wasatch County, UT; Utah County, UT; Washington County, UT; Cache County, UT; Sanpete County, UT; Morgan County, UT; Summit County, UT; Salt Lake County, UT; Grand County, UT; Tooele County, UT; Box Elder County, UT; Iron County, UT; Weber County, UT; Rich County, UT; San Juan County, UT; Juab County, UT
policy_description: Continuation: In jurisdictions in the Yellow Phase (now including Salt Lake City but no longer including Sevier County), child cares must follow distancing and sanitation guidelines, but no longer need to limit groups of children to 20 or fewer. They must close and notify the local public health department if there are any cases among clients.

local_area: Davis County, UT; Carbon County, UT; Wasatch County, UT; Utah County, UT; Washington County, UT; Cache County, UT; Sanpete County, UT; Morgan County, UT; Summit County, UT; Salt Lake County, UT; Grand County, UT; Tooele County, UT; Box Elder County, UT; Iron County, UT; Weber County, UT; Rich County, UT; San Juan County, UT; Juab County, UT
policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Continuation: In jurisdictions in the Yellow Phase (now including Salt Lake City but no longer including Sevier County), health screening/symptom checking is required in public and business interactions (via checklist or verbal interaction, with temperature checks where feasible). Employers must continue to use non-punitive sick leave policies and may not allow employees who are sick to come to work. General guidelines for employers (Page 24 of the guidelines) are amended in some cases.

policy_description: In low transmission counties, casual social gatherings are capped at 50 attendees, unless masks are worn, in which case there is no limit on attendance. (This limit does not apply to organized events, including religious services.)

Continuation with modifications: In moderate transmission counties, social gatherings (i.e. all gatherings except educational and religious gatherings) are capped at 25 attendees unless attendees all wear masks. Event hosts must also have attendees maintain six feet of distance, unless the local county executive waives this requirement.
Continuation: In moderate transmission counties, bars must limit occupancy to 75% of regular levels.

In moderate transmission areas (although no areas currently fall under this categorization as of the November 23 update), restaurants would be required to maintain six feet of distance between parties in waiting areas (but not elsewhere in the building), and bars would be required to lower occupancy to 75% of legal capacity.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Now that Orem and Provo cities have entered the Orange Phase, in these jurisdictions, employers must allow high-risk employees to work remotely, and employers must have employees work from home where possible.

Now that Orem and Provo cities have entered the Orange Phase, in these jurisdictions, the limit on social gatherings is set at 20 people for gatherings not overseen by a formal organizations. Events hosted by formal organizations may exceed 20 attendees if planning and distancing requirements are enforced.

Now that Orem and Provo cities have entered the Orange Phase, in these jurisdictions, child cares must close and notify the local public health department if there are any cases among clients. They must follow distancing and sanitation guidelines and limit groups of children to 20 or fewer.

Now that Orem and Provo cities have entered the Orange Phase, in these jurisdictions, distancing and sanitation requirements for businesses (including retail, personal care, entertainment, gyms, etc.) are put in place.
Now that Orem and Provo cities have entered the Orange Phase, in these jurisdictions, visits to hospitals are prohibited.
Now that Orem and Provo cities have entered the Orange Phase, in these jurisdictions, individuals must maintain 6 feet of distance when outside of the home.

policy_subtarget: Travelers; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Now that Orem and Provo cities have entered the Orange Phase, in these jurisdictions, individuals must quarantine for 14 days when returning to the state from high-risk areas. Employers must have employees do so. Exception for transportation workers.

Mass gatherings restrictions allow individuals and entertainment and event venues to host up to 3000 attendees (6000 when outdoors) without the need to keep 6 feet of distance between attendees (so long as masks are worn and other precautions are taken). For gatherings hosted by individuals that do not take these extra precautions, mass gatherings of up to 50 are allowed, subject to distancing guidelines.

policy_description: Continuation: In jurisdictions in the Yellow Phase (no longer including Rich County, Orem City, and Provem City), higher education campuses are subject to distancing, cleaning, and planning requirements.
County Board will take applications for restaurants to establish temporary outdoor seating areas in parking lots, sidewalks, and other public areas.
Arlington County to reopen 148 public parks.

Arlington County to enter Phase 1 of Governor's Forward Virginia Reopening plan. Non-essential businesses can open at 50 percent capacity, with strict requirements. Take-out and curbside pickup for restaurants and beverage services can continue and outdoor seating will be allowed at 50 percent capacity (see more on this below). Gyms and fitness facilities can offer limited outdoor exercise options. Outdoor swimming pools may be open for lap swimming only, with one person per lane. Beauty and nail salons, barbershops and other personal grooming services can provide services by appointment only and must follow strict guidelines. Places of worship can open for drive-in services or services inside at 50 percent capacity. Spray parks, basketball courts, and racquetball courts must remain closed, as well as entertainment facilities such as movie theaters. Social gatherings of more than 10 people are still banned.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Park amenities, including athletic fields and courts, picnic shelters, tennis courts, tracks, and skate parks, to reopen.

Arlington County to enter Phase 2 of Governor's Forward Virginia Reopening plan. Under Phase 2, Arlington will maintain a Safer at Home strategy, with continued recommendations for social distancing, teleworking and requiring individuals to wear face coverings in indoor public settings. The maximum number of individuals permitted in a social gathering will increase from 10 to 50 people. All businesses should still adhere to physical distancing guidelines, frequently clean and sanitize high contact surfaces, and continue enhanced workplace safety measures. Restaurant and beverage establishments may offer indoor dining at 50 percent occupancy, fitness centers may open indoor areas at 30 percent occupancy and certain recreation and entertainment venues without shared equipment may open with restrictions.
County dog parks, basketball courts, and volleyball courts to reopen.
Playgrounds reopened.

Arlington County to enter Phase 3 of Governor's Forward Virginia Reopening plan. In Phase 3, Arlington will maintain a Safer at Home strategy with continued recommendations for social distancing and teleworking, and the requirement that individuals wear face coverings in indoor public settings. All businesses should continue to follow physical distancing guidelines, frequently clean and sanitize high contact surfaces and keep enhanced workplace safety measures in place. The maximum number of individuals allowed in social gatherings will increase from 50 to 250 people. Restaurant and beverage establishments are required to maintain six feet of distance between tables. Fitness centers may open indoor areas at 75 percent occupancy. Recreation and entertainment venues at may operate at 50 percent occupancy, or a maximum of 1,000 persons. Swimming pools may expand operations to free swim in addition to indoor and outdoor exercise, diving, and swim instruction, up to 75 percent occupancy.
Fitness rooms and gyms will reopen in four of Department of Parks and Recreation centers.
Sidewalk physical distancing ordinance terminated.

County Attorney directed to file a petition on behalf of the County Board seeking an extension of the July 7, 2020 special election to August 4, 2020, or such later date as the Virginia Supreme Court selects.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: All summer camps in Arlington cancelled for summer 2020.
Arlington County restaurants must follow the mandatory requirements outlined in the Phase 3 "Guidelines for all Business Sectors" document released by the governor.
Pedestrians must obey signs requiring six feet of social distancing and limiting gatherings to three persons posted on designated public sidewalks.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Government/public buildings
policy_description: Visitors who are sick must not enter county facilities.

The City of Manassas is temporarily designating several parking spaces in the Historic Downtown as 15 Minute Parking Only to facilitate Pick Up and Delivery options to practice social distancing while supporting small businesses.

As Virginia waits for Phase 1 of reopening, City of Manassas released a guideline to facilitate retailers and restaurants to safely comply with the social distancing requirement. In short, restaurants can only accommodate 50% of their normal customers and must serve them outside. Because most restaurants have limited (or no) outdoor seating, City Council has amended an Ordinance governing the use of public streets and sidewalks and the City’s Department of Community Development has taken administrative action to make it easier for businesses to operate in the common areas on private property.

All City of Manassas buildings are closed to the public effective immediately until further notice. However, residents may still call to access City of Manassas government services or visit the city website for information.

The City Council of the City of Manassas, upon closing all government and city buildings in light of the COVID-19 pandemic, has declared that any meetings related to the public may be held through real time electronic means. This ordinances also gives permission to the Mayor and the City Manager to limit matters placed on the City Council's regular meeting agenda.

School closure has been extended and full distance learning will be implemented for the 2020-2021 school year. The School Board of the City of Manassas has also approved moving the start date for students to August 31, 2020 to give ample time for both students and faculty to adapt to these new changes.
When it first opens, the Manassas Park City Library will be open by appointment only
All city events are cancelled or suspended.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Public services
policy_description: The following government buildings and services will be open to the public in person on location: courthouse services, elections office, animal shelter, Board of County Supervisors meetings, Planning Commission meetings, Historical Commission meetings, and the Office of Social Services for SNAP EBT cards.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Public services
policy_description: The Department of Parks, Recreation, and Tourism will open parking lots at outdoor parks, hiking trails, picnic shelters, golf courses, and skate parks.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; General population (inclusive); Public services
policy_description: Libraries in Prince William County will be open for curbside book pick-up.

Prince William County will enter Stage Three according to the Commonwealth guidelines set forth by the governor. The McCoart Building, Sudley North, Development Services Building, and Hellwig will be open to the public.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: All Senior Centers in Prince William County will be closed, and all BlueBird bus tours are cancelled.
According to the CDC guidelines, Prince William County asks all residents to limit crowds to 50 or less people.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: The Adult Day Healthcare program in Prince William County will be closed.
All residents of Prince William County are urged to stay at home unless performing essential activites.
The Board amended their Rules of Procedure to allow members to attend meetings from remote locations.
All outdoor pools and waterparks in Prince William county will be closed for the summer 2020 season.

Warren County Parks and Recreation will reopen portions of outdoor facilities for group exercise on May 15, 2020 for groups under 10 people with social distancing measures in place. Individuals over the age of 65 or those with medical conditions are not recommended to participate. Playgrounds, picnic shelters, trails, skatepark, and open spaces will be open to the general public with new signs posted.
Warren County will enter Stage 2 according to the Governor of Virginia's Executive Order #65.
The Warren County Government Center will be open to the public, provided that all wear masks inside and abide by the social distancing rules of six feet between people.
Warren County will enter Phase 3 of reopening according to the Governor of Virginia's Executive Order #67.

policy_subtarget: Non essential workers (inclusive); Private sector; Restaurants/bars; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: All restaurants, fitness centers, and theaters in Warren County are mandated to significantly reduce seating capacity to ten patrons or fewer or close. They are encouraged to continue carry-out and takeaway options and increase the social distancing in restaurants.

policy_description: RSW Regional Jail will suspend all visitation until further notice. To keep families and friends connected with their loved ones during this time, they will provide inmates with one free phone call every three days.
The Samuels Public Library in Warren County will be closed until further notice. No fines will be charged during this time.

local_area: Franklin County, WA; Yakima County, WA; Benton County, WA
policy_description: In Benton, Franklin, and Yakima counties (which are in a modified version of Phase 1), the attendance limit for faith-based gatherings/weddings/funerals is lowered to 30 (or 20% capacity, whichever is lower). Behavioral health support groups of 4 or fewer may continue. No non-essential gatherings may take place.

All events of 250 people or more are prohibited. Events with fewer than 250 attendees are required to have social distancing, proper hygiene, and all employees must be screened for coronavirus symptoms each day.

All events with 50 people or more are prohibited until further notice. All events with fewer than 50 people are discouraged and prohibited unless event organizers observe the COVID-19 prevention measures.

Everyone with COVID-19 symptoms who has a test result pending, shall stay in a quarantine location in accordance with the CDC and Public Health guidance. If your result is positive, you must then remain in isolation.

All individuals who tested positive for COVID-19 shall enter and remain in isolation. They should not leave their home or facility except to receive medical care and should wait at least 10 days after their symptoms first appeared.

The Director of Finance and Administrative Services and his/her designee t negotiate and execute one or more short-term lease(s) for real property substantially in the form of "COVID-19 Testing Site Lease Agreement," attached to this order as Exhibit 1.

Loading zones will be temporarily added to restaurants to allow residents and delivery services to pick up food from local restaurants.

Seattle Parks and Recreation facilities, such as community centers, playgrounds, athletic fields, sport courts, swimming areas at beaches, pools, environmental learning centers, and select parking lots will be closed until further notice.
